disinterested: Not influenced by regard to personal interest or advantage;free from selfish motive; having no relation of interest or feeling;not biased or prejudiced; as, a disinterested decision or judge.The happiness of disinterested sacrifices. Channing.
dibstone: A pebble used in a child's game called dibstones. Locke.
disparager: One who disparages or dishonors; one who vilifies or disgraces.
dilatability: The quality of being dilatable, or admitting expansion; --opposed to contractibility. Ray.
dichroite: Iolite; -- so called from its presenting two different colorswhen viewed in two different directions. See Iolite.
disinvestiture: The act of depriving of investiture. [Obs.] Ogilvie.
deposal: The act of deposing from office; a removal from the throne.Fox.
divot: A thin, oblong turf used for covering cottages, and also forfuel. [Scot.] Simmonds.
diodont: Like or pertaining to the genus Diodon.-- n.
delphinoidea: The division of Cetacea which comprises the dolphins,porpoises, and related forms.
desquamation: The separation or shedding of the cuticle or epidermis in theform of flakes or scales; exfoliation, as of bones.
deliberateness: The quality of being deliberate; calm consideration;circumspection.
disgospel: To be inconsistent with, or act contrary to, the precepts ofthe gospel; to pervert the gospel. [Obs.] Milton.
dolium: A genus of large univalve mollusks, including the partridgeshell and tun shells.
diplogenic: Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing twosubstances. Wright.
dismayedness: A state of being dismayed; dejection of courage;dispiritedness.
duckweed: A genus (Lemna) of small plants, seen floating in greatquantity on the surface of stagnant pools fresh water, and supposedto furnish food for ducks; -- called also duckmeat.
didynamous: Of or pertaining to the Didynamia; containing four stamensdisposed in pairs of unequal length.
deflagrable: Burning with a sudden and sparkling combustion, as niter;hence, slightly explosive; liable to snap and crackle when heated, assalt.
darn: To mend as a rent or hole, with interlacing stitches of yarn orthread by means of a needle; to sew together with yarn or thread.He spent every day ten hours in his closet, in darning his stockins.Swift.Darning last. See under Last.-- Darning needle. (a) A long, strong needle for mending holes orrents, especially in stockings. (b) (Zoöl.) Any species of dragonfly, having a long, cylindrical body, resembling a needle. Theseflies are harmless and without stings.
delph: Delftware.Five nothings in five plates of delph. Swift.
diamond-shaped: Shaped like a diamond or rhombus.
deep-mouthed: Having a loud and sonorous voice. "Deep-mouthed dogs." Dryden.
dichroism: The property of presenting different colors by transmittedlight, when viewed in two different directions, the colors beingunlike in the direction of unlike or unequal axes.
desponsage: Betrothal. [Obs.]Ethelbert . . . went peaceably to King Offa for desponsage ofAthilrid, his daughter. Foxe.
duly: In a due, fit, or becoming manner; as it (anything) ought tobe; properly; regularly.
damassin: A kind of modified damask or blocade.
defunct: Having finished the course of life; dead; deceased. "Defunctorgans." Shak.The boar, defunct, lay tripped up, near. Byron.
depeculation: A robbing or embezzlement. [Obs.]Depeculation of the public treasure. Hobbes.
deflagrator: A form of the voltaic battery having large plates, used forproducing rapid and powerful combustion.
diluvian: Of or pertaining to a deluge, esp. to the Noachian deluge;diluvial; as, of diluvian origin. Buckland.
diaphane: A woven silk stuff with transparent and colored figures; diaperwork.
dishcloth: A cloth used for washing dishes.
decahedron: A solid figure or body inclosed by ten plane surfaces. [Writtenalso, less correctly, decaedron.]
dispunct: Wanting in punctilious respect; discourteous. [Obs.]That were dispunct to the ladies. B. Jonson.
dogberry: The berry of the dogwood; -- called also dogcherry. Dr. Prior.Dogberry tree (Bot.), the dogwood.
divaricator: One of the muscles which open the shell of brachiopods; acardinal muscle. See Illust. of Brachiopoda.
dividuous: Divided; dividual. [R.]He so often substantiates distinctions into dividuous,selfsubsistent. Coleridge.
diskless: Having no disk; appearing as a point and not expanded into adisk, as the image of a faint star in a telescope.
date line: The hypothetical line on the surface of the earth fixed byinternational or general agreement as a boundary on one side of whichthe same day shall have a different name and date in the calendarfrom its name and date on the other side.
dermatogen: Nascent epidermis, or external cuticle of plants in a formingcondition.
doni: A clumsy craft, having one mast with a long sail, used fortrading purposes on the coasts of Coromandel and Ceylon. [Writtenalso dhony, doney, and done.]
dukeship: The quality or condition of being a duke; also, the personalityof a duke. Massinger.
definitely: In a definite manner; with precision; precisely; determinately.
didymium: A rare metallic substance usually associated with the metalcerium; -- hence its name. It was formerly supposed to be an element,but has since been found to consist of two simpler elementarysubstances, neodymium and praseodymium. See Neodymium, andPraseodymium.
drysalter: A dealer in salted or dried meats, pickles, sauces, etc., andin the materials used in pickling, salting, and preserving variouskinds of food Hence drysalters usually sell a number of salinesubstances and miscellaneous drugs. Brande & C.
descriptive: Tending to describe; having the quality of representing;containing description; as, a descriptive figure; a descriptivephrase; a descriptive narration; a story descriptive of the age.Descriptive anatomy, that part of anatomy which treats of the formsand relations of parts, but not of their textures.-- Descriptive geometry, that branch of geometry. which treats ofthe graphic solution of problems involving three dimensions, by meansof projections upon auxiliary planes. Davies & Peck (Math. Dict. ) --De*scrip"tive*ly, adv.-- De*scrip"tive*ness, n.
despisal: A despising; contempt. [R.]A despisal of religion. South.
dural: Pertaining to the dura, or dura mater.
dilling: A darling; a favorite. [Obs.]Whilst the birds billing, Each one with his dilling. Drayton.
debaser: One who, or that which, debases.
dentex: An edible European marine fish (Sparus dentex, or Dentexvulgaris) of the family Percidæ.
doggish: Like a dog; having the bad qualities of a dog; churlish;growling; brutal.-- Dog"*gish*ly, adv.-- Dog"gish*ness, n.
dicephalous: Having two heads on one body; double-headed.
dipropargyl: A pungent, mobile, volatile liquid, C6H6, produced artificiallyfrom certain allyl derivatives. Though isomeric with benzine, it isvery different in its chemical relations. Called also dipropinyl.
during: In the time of; as long as the action or existence of; as,during life; during the space of a year.
deprecative: Serving to deprecate; deprecatory.-- Dep"re*ca*tive*ly, adv.
divulgation: The act of divulging or publishing. [R.]Secrecy hath no use than divulgation. Bp. Hall.
discure: To discover; to reveal; to discoure. [Obs.]I will, if please you it discure, assay To ease you of that ill, sowisely as I may. Spenser.
disillusion: The act or process of freeing from an illusion, or the state ofbeing freed therefrom. Lowell.
didelphic: Having the uterus double; of or pertaining to the Didelphia.
debuscope: A modification of the kaleidoscope; -- used to reflect imagesso as to form beautiful designs.
disengaged: Not engaged; free from engagement; at leisure; free fromoccupation or care; vacant.-- Dis`en*ga"ged*ness, n.
depression: The angular distance of a celestial object below the horizon.
dispatchment: The act of dispatching. [Obs.] State Trials (1529).
drumlin: A hill of compact, unstratified, glacial drift or till, usuallyelongate or oval, with the larger axis parallel to the former localglacial motion.
disapprobation: The act of disapproving; mental condemnation of what is judgedwrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; feeling of censure.We have ever expressed the most unqualified disapprobation of all thesteps. Burke.
desirer: One who desires, asks, or wishes.
dial: To survey with a dial. Raymond.
datiscin: A white crystalline glucoside extracted from the bastard hemp(Datisca cannabina).
duller: One who, or that which, dulls.
disorient: To turn away from the cast; to confuse as to which way is east;to cause to lose one's bearings. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
dioristic: Distinguishing; distinctive; defining. [R.] --Di`o*ris"tic*al*ly, adv. [R.] Dr. H. More.
diaphragmatic: Pertaining to a diaphragm; as, diaphragmatic respiration; thediaphragmatic arteries and nerves.
drive: To dig Horizontally; to cut a horizontal gallery or tunnel.Tomlinson.
dehumanize: To divest of human qualities, such as pity, tenderness, etc.;as, dehumanizing influences.
dispersal: The act or result of dispersing or scattering; dispersion.Darwin.
diathermometer: An instrument for examining the thermal resistance or heat-conducting power of liquids.
dissyllabic: Consisting of two syllabas, a dissyllabic foot in poetry. B.Jons
daddle: To toddle; to walk unsteadily, like a child or an old man;hence, to do anything slowly or feebly.
demonian: Relating to, or having the nature of, a demon. "Demonianspirits." Milton.
dedecorate: To bring to shame; to disgrace. [Obs.] Bailey.
dossier: A bundle containing the papers in reference to some matter.
decurrent: Extending downward; -- said of a leaf whose base extendsdownward and forms a wing along the stem.-- De*cur"rent*ly, adv.
dignation: The act of thinking worthy; honor. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
dasheen: A tropical aroid (of the genus Caladium, syn. Colocasia) havingan edible farinaceous root. It is related to the taro and to thetanier, but is much superior to it in quality and is as easily cookedas the potato. It is a staple food plant of the tropics, beingprepared like potatoes, and has been introduced into the SouthernUnited States.
defectible: Liable to defect; imperfect. [R.] "A defectible understanding."Jer. Taylor.
disaccommodation: A state of being unaccommodated or unsuited. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
doomage: A penalty or fine for neglect. [Local, New England]
domestically: In a domestic manner; privately; with reference to domesticaffairs.
dentize: To breed or cut new teeth. [R.]The old countess . . . did dentize twice or thrice. Bacon.
direct: In the direction of the general planetary motion, or from westto east; in the order of the signs; not retrograde; -- said of themotion of a celestial body. Direct action. (Mach.) See Direct-acting.-- Direct discourse (Gram.), the language of any one quoted withoutchange in its form; as, he said "I can not come;" -- correlative toindirect discourse, in which there is change of form; as, he saidthat he could not come. They are often called respectively by theirLatin names, oratio directa, and oratio obliqua.-- Direct evidence (Law), evidence which is positive or notinferential; -- opposed to circumstantial, or indirect, evidence.-- This distinction, however, is merely formal, since there is nodirect evidence that is not circumstantial, or dependent oncircumstances for its credibility. Wharton.-- Direct examination (Law), the first examination of a witness inthe orderly course, upon the merits. Abbott.-- Direct fire (Mil.), fire, the direction of which is perpendicularto the line of troops or to the parapet aimed at.-- Direct process (Metal.), one which yields metal in workingcondition by a single process from the ore. Knight.-- Direct tax, a tax assessed directly on lands, etc., and polls,distinguished from taxes on merchandise, or customs, and from excise.
decerptible: That may be plucked off, cropped, or torn away. [Obs.] Bailey.
designable: Capable of being designated or distinctly marked out;distinguishable. Boyle.
decussation: Act of crossing at an acute angle, or state of being thuscrossed; an intersection in the form of an X; as, the decussation oflines, nerves, etc.
deservedly: According to desert (whether good or evil); justly.
doris: A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks having a wreath of branchi¯n the back.
diaster: A double star; -- applied to the nucleus of a cell, when,during cell division, the loops of the nuclear network separate intotwo groups, preparatory to the formation of two daughter nuclei. SeeKaryokinesis.
disassimilative: Having power to disassimilate; of the nature ofdisassimilation.Disassimilative processes constitute a marked feature in the life ofanimal cells. McKendrick.
demonstration: The exhibition and explanation of a dissection or otheranatomical preparation.
differingly: In a differing or different manner. Boyle.
drill: To practice an exercise or exercises; to train one's self.
dyspeptone: An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and otherproteid substances by the action of gastric juice. Meissner.
deductively: By deduction; by way of inference; by consequence. Sir T.Browne.
dorr: The dorbeetle; also, a drone or an idler. See 1st Dor. Robynson(More's Utopia).
disinflame: To divest of flame or ardor. Chapman.
duple: Double. Duple ratio (Math.), that in which the antecedent termis double the consequent, as of 2 to 1, 8 to 4, etc.
dashpot: A pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as inthe valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.
doucker: A grebe or diver; -- applied also to the golden-eye, pochard,scoter, and other ducks. [Written also ducker.] [Prov. Eng.]
dermestes: A genus of coleopterous insects, the larvæ of which feed animalsubstances. They are very destructive to dries meats, skins, woolens,and furs. The most common species is D. lardarius, known as the baconbeetle.
diamylene: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H20, of the ethylene series, regardedas a polymeric form of amylene.
disordination: The state of being in disorder; derangement; confusion. [Obs.]Bacon.
discommodious: Inconvenient; troublesome; incommodious. [R.] Spenser.-- Dis`com*mo"di*ous*ly, adv.-- Dis`com*mo"di*ous*ness, n.
drift: The horizontal thrust or pressure of an arch or vault upon theabutments. [R.] Knight.
disembay: To clear from a bay. Sherburne.
doree: A European marine fish (Zeus faber), of a yellow color. SeeIllust. of John Doree.
distain: To tinge with a different color from the natural or proper one;to stain; to discolor; to sully; to tarnish; to defile; -- usedchiefly in poetry. "Distained with dirt and blood." Spenser.[She] hath . . . distained her honorable blood. Spenser.The worthiness of praise distains his worth. Shak.
duskish: Somewhat dusky. " Duskish smoke." Spenser.-- Dusk"ish*ly, adv.-- Dusk"ish*ness, n.
dryly: In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; withoutsympathy; coldly.
desilver: To deprive of silver; as, to desilver lead.
disparity: Inequality; difference in age, rank, condition, or excellence;dissimilitude; -- followed by between, in, of, as to, etc.; as,disparity in, or of, years; a disparity as to color.The disparity between God and his intelligent creatures. I. Taylor.The disparity of numbers was not such as ought to cause anyuneasiness. Macaulay.
diomedea: A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. SeeAlbatross.
double-breasted: Folding or lapping over on the breast, with a row of buttonsand buttonholes on each side; as, a double-breasted coat.
displacement: The process of extracting soluble substances from organicmaterial and the like, whereby a quantity of saturated solvent isdisplaced, or removed, for another quantity of the solvent. Pistondisplacement (Mech.), the volume of the space swept through, orweight of steam, water, etc., displaced, in a given time, by thepiston of a steam engine or pump.
demesne: A lord's chief manor place, with that part of the landsbelonging thereto which has not been granted out in tenancy; a house,and the land adjoining, kept for the proprietor's own use. [Writtenalso demain.] Wharton's Law Dict. Burrill. Ancient demesne. (Eng.Law) See under Ancient.
dryandra: A genus of shrubs growing in Australia, having beautiful, hard,dry, evergreen leaves.
disrate: To reduce to a lower rating or rank; to degrade. Marryat.
disturbance: The hindering or disquieting of a person in the lawful andpeaceable enjoyment of his right; the interruption of a right; as,the disturbance of a franchise, of common, of ways, and the like.Blackstone.
demagogue: A leader of the rabble; one who attempts to control themultitude by specious or deceitful arts; an unprincipled and factiousmob orator or political leader.
disdain: To be filled with scorn; to feel contemptuous anger; to behaughty.And when the chief priests and scribes saw the marvels that he did .. . they disdained. Genevan Testament (Matt. xxi. 15).
douse: To strike or lower in haste; to slacken suddenly; as, douse thetopsail.
deprecable: That may or should be deprecated. Paley.
deprecatory: Serving to deprecate; tending to remove or avert evil byprayer; apologetic.Humble and deprecatory letters. Bacon.
dioecia: A Linnæan class of plants having the stamens and pistils ondifferent plants.
declinable: Capable of being declined; admitting of declension orinflection; as, declinable parts of speech.
distort: Distorted; misshapen. [Obs.]Her face was ugly and her mouth distort. Spenser.
dowse: To beat or thrash. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
deification: The act of deifying; exaltation to divine honors; apotheosis;excessive praise.
digitiform: Formed like a finger or fingers; finger-shaped; as, adigitiform root.
defecation: The act or process of voiding excrement.
drag: A confection; a comfit; a drug. [Obs.] Chaucer.
disproportional: Not having due proportion to something else; not havingproportion or symmetry of parts; unsuitable in form, quantity orvalue; inadequate; unequal; as, a disproportional limb constitutesdeformity in the body; the studies of youth should not bedisproportional to their understanding.
dispread: To spread abroad, or different ways; to spread apart; to open;as, the sun dispreads his beams. Spenser.
detriment: To do injury to; to hurt. [Archaic]Other might be determined thereby. Fuller.
dispurpose: To dissuade; to frustrate; as, to dispurpose plots. [R.] A.Brewer.
duograph: A picture printed from two half-tone plates made with thescreen set at different angles, and usually printed in two shades ofthe same color or in black and one tint.
darby: A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothingceilings, etc.
deltoid: Shaped like the Greek Deltoid leaf (Bot.), a leaf in the formof a triangle with the stem inserted at the middle of the base.-- Deltoid muscle (Anat.), a triangular muscle in the shoulder whichserves to move the arm directly upward.
deceit: Any trick, collusion, contrivance, false representation, orunderhand practice, used to defraud another. When injury is therebyeffected, an action of deceit, as it called, lies for compensation.
detecter: One who, or that which, detects or brings to light; one whofinds out what another attempts to conceal; a detector.
disformity: Discordance or diversity of form; unlikeness in form.Uniformity or disformity in comparing together the respective figuresof bodies. S. Clarke.
dictate: A statement delivered with authority; an order; a command; anauthoritative rule, principle, or maxim; a prescription; as, listento the dictates of your conscience; the dictates of the gospel.I credit what the Grecian dictates say. Prior.
dissympathy: Lack of sympathy; want of interest; indifference. [R.]
demonocracy: The power or government of demons.A demonocracy of unclean spirits. H. Taylor.
discodactylia: A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, asthe tree frogs.
disinthrallment: A releasing from thralldom or slavery; disenthrallment.[Written also disinthralment.]
demoiselle: The Numidian crane (Antropoides virgo); -- so called on accountof the grace and symmetry of its form and movements.
detrital: Pertaining to, or composed of, detritus.
dennet: A light, open, two-wheeled carriage for one horse; a kind ofgig. ("The term and vehicle common about 1825." Latham.)
daniel: A Hebrew prophet distinguished for sagacity and ripeness ofjudgment in youth; hence, a sagacious and upright judge.A Daniel come to judgment. Shak.
discede: To yield or give up; to depart. [Obs.]I dare not discede from my copy a tittle. Fuller.
donable: Capable of being donated or given. [R.]
disharmony: Want of harmony; discord; incongruity. [R.]A disharmony in the different impulses that constitute it [ournature]. Coleridge.
dentalism: The quality of being formed by the aid of the teeth.
denitrify: To deprive of, or free from, nitrogen.
dismastment: The act of dismasting; the state of being dismasted. [R.]Marshall.
depressant: An agent or remedy which lowers the vital powers.
decasyllabic: Having, or consisting of, ten syllables.
duotype: A print made from two half-tone plates made from the samenegative, but etched differently.
duces tecum: A judicial process commanding a person to appear in court andbring with him some piece of evidence or other thing to be producedto the court.
demureness: The state of being demure; gravity; the show of gravity ormodesty.
diffuser: One who, or that which, diffuses.
debar: To cut off from entrance, as if by a bar or barrier; topreclude; to hinder from approach, entry, or enjoyment; to shut outor exclude; to deny or refuse; -- with from, and sometimes with of.Yet not so strictly hath our Lord imposed Labor, as to debar us whenwe need Refreshment. Milton.Their wages were so low as to debar them, not only from the comfortsbut from the common decencies of civilized life. Buckle.
dolomize: To convert into dolomite.-- Dol`o*mi*za"tion, n.
dig: To take ore from its bed, in distinction from makingexcavations in search of ore.
diploma: A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring someprivilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degreeconferred by a literary society or educational institution.
discamp: To drive from a camp. [Obs.] Holland.
delineable: Capable of being, or liable to be, delineated. Feltham.
dogmaticalness: The quality of being dogmatical; positiveness.
defailance: Failure; miscarriage. [Obs.]Possibility of defailance in degree or continuance. Comber.
devon: One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country ofDevon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small,longhorned variety, called North Devons, is distinguished by thesuperiority of its working oxen.
discordful: Full of discord; contentious. [Obs.] "His discordful dame."Spenser.
dipterocarpus: A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species ofwhich produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit hastwo long wings.
declensional: Belonging to declension.Declensional and syntactical forms. M. Arnold.
distortion: An unnatural deviation of shape or position of any part of thebody producing visible deformity.
docimacy: The art or practice of applying tests to ascertain the nature,quality, etc., of objects, as of metals or ores, of medicines, or offacts pertaining to physiology.
doegling: The beaked whale (Balænoptera rostrata), from which doeglingoil is obtained.
dodecastyle: Having twelve columns in front.-- n.
debouche: A place for exit; an outlet; hence, a market for goods.The débouchés were ordered widened to afford easy egress. TheCentury.
doctrinaire: One who would apply to political or other practical concernsthe abstract doctrines or the theories of his own philosophicalsystem; a propounder of a new set of opinions; a dogmatic theorist.Used also adjectively; as, doctrinaire notions.
desudation: A sweating; a profuse or morbid sweating, often succeeded by aneruption of small pimples.
distinguishingly: With distinction; with some mark of preference. Pope.
domebook: A book said to have been compiled under the direction of KingAlfred. It is supposed to have contained the principal maxims of thecommon law, the penalties for misdemeanors, and the forms of judicialproceedings. Domebook was probably a general name for book ofjudgments. Burrill.
divert: To turn aside; to digress. [Obs.]I diverted to see one of the prince's palaces. Evelyn.
duplication: The act or process of dividing by natural growth or spontaneousaction; as, the duplication of cartilage cells. Carpenter.Duplication of the cube (Math.), the operation of finding a cubehaving a volume which is double that of a given cube.
desertness: A deserted condition. [R.] "The desertness of the country."Udall.
derailment: The act of going off, or the state of being off, the rails of arailroad.
dutiable: Subject to the payment of a duty; as dutiable goods. [U.S.]All kinds of dutiable merchandise. Hawthorne.
disk: The circular figure of a celestial body, as seen projected ofthe heavens.
dignify: To invest with dignity or honor; to make illustrious; to givedistinction to; to exalt in rank; to honor.Your worth will dignity our feast. B. Jonson.
devow: To disavow; to disclaim. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
dentile: A small tooth, like that of a saw.
dravidian: Of or pertaining to the Dravida. Dravidian languages, a groupof languages of Southern India, which seem to have been the idioms ofthe natives, before the invasion of tribes speaking Sanskrit. Ofthese languages, the Tamil is the most important.
deliquescence: The act of deliquescing or liquefying; process by whichanything deliquesces; tendency to melt.
detonator: One who, or that which, detonates.
disaffirm: To refuse to confirm; to annul, as a judicial decision, by acontrary judgment of a superior tribunal.
discolith: One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body,with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion.One of them measures about
differential: Of or pertaining to a differential, or to differentials.
debosh: To debauch. [Obs.] "A deboshed lady." Beau. & Fl.
dab: A skillful hand; a dabster; an expert. [Colloq.]One excels at a plan or the titlepage, another works away at the bodyof the book, and the therd is a dab at an index. Goldsmith.
doleful: Full of dole or grief; expressing or exciting sorrow;sorrowful; sad; dismal.With screwed face and doleful whine. South.Regions of sorrow, doleful shades. Milton.
dorado: A southern constellation, within which is the south pole of theecliptic; -- called also sometimes Xiphias, or the Swordfish.
dubitation: Act of doubting; doubt. [R.] Sir T. Scott.
delassation: Fatigue.Able to continue without delassation. Ray.
dispeople: To deprive of inhabitants; to depopulate.Leave the land dispeopled and desolate. Sir T. More.A certain island long before dispeopled . . . by sea rivers. Milton.
deadness: The state of being destitute of life, vigor, spirit, activity,etc.; dullness; inertness; languor; coldness; vapidness;indifference; as, the deadness of a limb, a body, or a tree; thedeadness of an eye; deadness of the affections; the deadness of beeror cider; deadness to the world, and the like.
documentary: Pertaining to written evidence; contained or certified inwriting. "Documentary evidence." Macaulay.
dairyman: A man who keeps or takes care of a dairy.
disembody: To disarm and disband, as a body of soldiers,-Wilhelm.
dosimetry: Measurement of doses; specif., a system of therapeutics whichuses but few remedies, mostly alkaloids, and gives them in dosesfixed by certain rules. --Do`si*met"ric (#), a. --Do*sim"e*trist (#),n.
depolarizer: A substance used to prevent polarization, as upon the negativeplate of a voltaic battery.
dropwort: An Old World species of Spiræa (S. filipendula), with finelycut leaves.
displosion: Explosion.The vast displosion dissipates the clouds. Young.
doublehearted: Having a false heart; deceitful; treacherous. Sandys.
double-acting: Acting or operating in two directions or with both motions;producing a twofold result; as, a double-acting engine or pump.
disport: Play; sport; pastime; diversion; playfulness. Milton.
discradle: To take from a cradle. [R.]This airy apparition first discradled From Tournay into Portugal.Ford.
derisive: Expressing, serving for, or characterized by, derision."Derisive taunts." Pope.-- De*ri"sive*ly, adv.-- De*ri"sive*ness, n.
dummy: One who plays a merely nominal part in any action; a shamcharacter.
delegate: Sent to act for a represent another; deputed; as, a delegatejudge. "Delegate power." Strype.
deridingly: By way of derision or mockery.
declarative: Making declaration, proclamation, or publication; explanatory;assertive; declaratory. "Declarative laws." Baker.The "vox populi," so declarative on the same side. Swift.
dominus: Master; sir; -- a title of respect formerly applied to a knightor a clergyman, and sometimes to the lord of a manor. Cowell.
deutoxide: A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of oxygenunited with some other element or radical; -- usually called dioxide,or less frequently, binoxide.
diametrically: In a diametrical manner; directly; as, diametrically opposite.Whose principles were diametrically opposed to his. Macaulay.
differentiator: One who, or that which, differentiates.
dumfound: To strike dumb; to confuse with astonishment. [Written alsodumbfound.] Spectator.
dobson: The aquatic larva of a large neuropterous insect (Corydaluscornutus), used as bait in angling. See Hellgamite.
dixie: A colloquial name for the Southern portion of the UnitedStates, esp. during the Civil War. [U.S.]
dunder: The lees or dregs of cane juice, used in the distillation ofrum. [West Indies]The use of dunder in the making of rum answers the purpose of yeastin the fermentation of flour. B. Edwards.
disadvise: To advise against; to dissuade from. [R.] Boyle.
discountenance: Unfavorable aspect; unfriendly regard; cold treatment;disapprobation; whatever tends to check or discourage.He thought a little discountenance on those persons would suppressthat spirit. Clarendon.
dodman: Any shellfish which casts its shell, as a lobster. [Prov. Eng.]
decardinalize: To depose from the rank of cardinal.
discalceation: The act of pulling off the shoes or sandals. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
decharm: To free from a charm; to disenchant.
dorsum: The back or dorsal region of an animal; the upper side of anappendage or part; as, the dorsum of the tongue.
depure: To depurate; to purify. [Obs.]He shall first be depured and cleansed before that he shall be laidup for pure gold in the treasures of God. Sir T. More.
descend: To move toward the south, or to the southward.
debruised: Surmounted by an ordinary; as, a lion is debruised when a bendor other ordinary is placed over it, as in the cut.The lion of England and the lilies of France without the batonsinister, under which, according to the laws of heraldry, they wheredebruised in token of his illegitimate birth. Macaulay.
dane: A native, or a naturalized inhabitant, of Denmark. Great Dane.(Zoöl.) See Danish dog, under Danish.
dungyard: A yard where dung is collected.
disfriar: To depose or withdraw from the condition of a friar. [Obs.]Many did quickly unnun and disfriar themselves. Fuller.
disassociate: To disconnect from things associated; to disunite; todissociate. Florio.
dilettante: An admirer or lover of the fine arts; popularly, an amateur;especially, one who follows an art or a branch of knowledge,desultorily, or for amusement only.
dowagerism: The rank or condition of a dowager; formality, as that of adowager. Also used figuratively.Mansions that have passed away into dowagerism. Thackeray.
discalced: Unshod; barefooted; -- in distinction from calced. "Thefoundation of houses of discalced friars." Cardinal Manning's St.Teresa.
dilogical: Ambiguous; of double meaning. [Obs.] T. Adams.
dodecagynia: A Linnæan order of plants having twelve styles.
decrepitation: The act of decrepitating; a crackling noise, such as salt makeswhen roasting.
dorp: A hamlet. "A mean fishing dorp." Howell.
darnel: Any grass of the genus Lolium, esp. the Lolium temulentum(bearded darnel), the grains of which have been reputed poisonous.Other species, as Lolium perenne (rye grass or ray grass), and itsvariety L. Italicum (Italian rye grass), are highly esteemed forpasture and for making hay.
doting: That dotes; silly; excessively fond.-- Dot"ing*ly, adv.-- Dot"ing*ness, n.
diocesan: Of or pertaining to a diocese; as, diocesan missions.
diswitted: Deprived of wits or understanding; distracted. [Obs.] Drayton.
driven: of Drive. Also adj. Driven well, a well made by driving a tubeinto the earth to an aqueous stratum; -- called also drive well.
damnum: Harm; detriment, either to character or property.
decastich: A poem consisting of ten lines.
dam: A firebrick wall, or a stone, which forms the front of thehearth of a blast furnace. Dam plate (Blast Furnace), an iron platein front of the dam, to strengthen it.
decidedly: In a decided manner; indisputably; clearly; thoroughly.
dispersed: Scattered.-- Dis*pers"ed*ly, adv.-- Dis*pers"ed*ness, n. Dispersed harmony (Mus.), harmony in whichthe tones composing the chord are widely separated, as by an octaveor more.
discumber: To free from that which cumbers or impedes; to disencumber.[Archaic] Pope.
divergent: Causing divergence of rays; as, a divergent lens.
disgavel: To deprive of that principal quality of gavelkind tenure bywhich lands descend equally among all the sons of the tenant; -- saidof lands. Burrill.
decore: To decorate; to beautify. [Obs.]To decore and beautify the house of God. E. Hall.
dispositor: The planet which is lord of the sign where another planet is.[Obs.] Crabb.
demoniac: One of a sect of Anabaptists who maintain that the demons ordevils will finally be saved.
destroyable: Destructible. [R.]Plants . . . scarcely destroyable by the weather. Derham.
devest: To be taken away, lost, or alienated, as a title or an estate.
diphyllous: Having two leaves, as a calyx, etc.
depicture: To make a picture of; to paint; to picture; to depict.Several persons were depictured in caricature. Fielding.
deaconess: A female deacon; as:(a) (Primitive Ch.) One of an order of women whose duties resembledthose of deacons. (b) (Ch. of Eng. and Prot. Epis. Ch.)
dogmatically: In a dogmatic manner; positively; magisterially.
dynam: A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound.See Foot pound. Whewell.
dahlin: A variety of starch extracted from the dahlia; -- called alsoinulin. See Inulin.
distribute: To employ (a term) in its whole extent; to take as universal inone premise.A term is said to be distributed when it is taken universal, so as tostand for everything it is capable of being applied to. Whately.
dagger: A mark of reference in the form of a dagger [|]. It is thesecond in order when more than one reference occurs on a page; --called also obelisk. Dagger moth (Zoöl.), any moth of the genusApatalea. The larvæ are often destructive to the foliage of fruittrees, etc.-- Dagger of lath, the wooden weapon given to the Vice in the oldMoralities. Shak.-- Double dagger, a mark of reference [||] which comes next in orderafter the dagger.-- To look, or speak, daggers, to look or speak fiercely orreproachfully.
drawgear: The means or parts by which cars are connected to be drawn.
deed poll: A deed of one part, or executed by only one party, anddistinguished from an indenture by having the edge of the parchmentor paper cut even, or polled as it was anciently termed, instead ofbeing indented. Burrill.
daintify: To render dainty, delicate, or fastidious. "Daintifiedemotion." Sat. rev.
dithyramb: A kind of lyric poetry in honor of Bacchus, usually sung by aband of revelers to a flute accompaniment; hence, in general, a poemwritten in a wild irregular strain. Bentley.
distensibility: The quality or capacity of being distensible. [R.]
devitalize: To deprive of life or vitality.-- De*vi`tal*i*za"tion, n.
disapparel: To disrobe; to strip of apparel; to make naked.Drink disapparels the soul. Junius (1635).
di-: A prefix, signifying twofold, double, twice; (Chem.)
dartoid: Like the dartos; dartoic; as, dartoid tissue.
demonetization: The act of demonetizing, or the condition of being demonetized.
dare-deviltry: Reckless mischief; the action of a dare-devil.
desuetude: The cessation of use; disuse; discontinuance of practice,custom, or fashion.The desuetude abrogated the law, which, before, custom hadestablished. Jer. Taylor.
dactylology: The art of communicating ideas by certain movements andpositions of the fingers; -- a method of conversing practiced by thedeaf and dumb.
dishabit: To dislodge. [Obs.]Those sleeping stones . . . from their fixed beds of lime Had beendishabited. Shak.
dromatherium: A small extinct triassic mammal from North Carolina, theearliest yet found in America.
dearn: Secret; lonely; solitary; dreadful. [Obs.] Shak.-- Dearn"ly, adv. [Obs.] Chaucer.
decillionth: Pertaining to a decillion, or to the quotient of unity dividedby a decillion.
dedicatory: Constituting or serving as a dedication; complimental. "Anepistle dedicatory." Dryden.
detestation: The act of detesting; extreme hatred or dislike; abhorrence;loathing.We are heartily agreed in our detestation of civil war. Burke.
dorsal: Pertaining to, or situated near, the back, or dorsum, of ananimal or of one of its parts; notal; tergal; neural; as, the dorsalfin of a fish; the dorsal artery of the tongue; -- opposed toventral.
darrein: Last; as, darrein continuance, the last continuance.
daggle-tail: A slovenly woman; a slattern; a draggle-tail.
double dealer: One who practices double dealing; a deceitful, trickish person.L'Estrange.
dormancy: The state of being dormant; quiescence; abeyance.
dialytic: Having the quality of unloosing or separating. Clarke. Dialytictelescope, an achromatic telescope in which the colored dispersionproduced by a single object lens of crown glass is corrected by asmaller concave lens, or combination of lenses, of high dispersivepower, placed at a distance in the narrower part of the convergingcone of rays, usually near the middle of the tube.
denization: The act of making one a denizen or adopted citizen;naturalization. Hallam.
debacchate: To rave as a bacchanal. [R.] Cockeram.
desponsation: A betrothing; betrothal. [Obs.]For all this desponsation of her . . . she had not set one steptoward the consummation of her marriage. Jer. Taylor.
decagynia: A Linnæan order of plants characterized by having ten styles.
divinity calf: Calf stained dark brown and worked without gilding, often usedfor theological books.
dromedary: The Arabian camel (Camelus dromedarius), having one hump orprotuberance on the back, in distinction from the Bactrian camel,which has two humps.
dambonite: A white crystalline, sugary substance obtained from an Africancaotchouc.
do-all: General manager; factotum.Under him, Dunstan was the do-all at court, being the king'streasurer, councilor, chancellor, confessor, all things. Fuller.
density: The ratio of mass, or quantity of matter, to bulk or volume,esp. as compared with the mass and volume of a portion of somesubstance used as a standard.
decacerata: The division of Cephalopoda which includes the squids,cuttlefishes, and others having ten arms or tentacles; -- called alsoDecapoda. [Written also Decacera.] See Dibranchiata.
delphinus: A genus of Cetacea, including the dolphin. See Dolphin,
digression: The elongation, or angular distance from the sun; -- saidchiefly of the inferior planets. [R.]
dewar vessel: A double-walled glass vessel for holding liquid air, etc.,having the space between the walls exhausted so as to preventconduction of heat, and sometimes having the glass silvered toprevent absorption of radiant heat; -- called also, according to theparticular shape, Dewar bulb, Dewar tube, etc.
dicentra: A genus of herbaceous plants, with racemes of two-spurred orheart-shaped flowers, including the Dutchman's breeches, and the moreshowy Bleeding heart (D. spectabilis). [Corruptly written dielytra.]
dichromatic: Having two color varieties, or two phases differing in color,independently of age or sex, as in certain birds and insects.
dissipative: Tending to dissipate. Dissipative system (Mech.), an assumedsystem of matter and motions in which forces of friction andresistances of other kinds are introduced without regard to the heator other molecular actions which they generate; -- opposed toconservative system.
donate: To give; to bestow; to present; as, to donate fifty thousanddollars to a college.
dictamnus: A suffrutescent, D. Fraxinella (the only species), with strongperfume and showy flowers. The volatile oil of the leaves is highlyinflammable.
defunction: Death. [Obs.]After defunction of King Pharamond. Shak.
depurative: Purifying the blood or the humors; depuratory.-- n.
didelphys: Formerly, any marsupial; but the term is now restricted to anAmerican genus which includes the opossums, of which there are manyspecies. See Opossum. [Written also Didelphis.] See Illustration inAppendix.  Cuvier.
diddle: To totter, as a child in walking. [Obs.] Quarles.
decursively: In a decursive manner. Decursively pinnate (Bot.), having theleaflets decurrent, or running along the petiole; -- said of a leaf.
dynastidan: One of a group of gigantic, horned beetles, including DynastusNeptunus, and the Hercules beetle (D. Hercules) of tropical America,which grow to be six inches in length.
dogdraw: The act of drawing after, or pursuing, deer with a dog. Cowell.
defix: To fix; to fasten; to establish. [Obs.] "To defix theirprincely seat . . . in that extreme province." Hakluyt.
dissolubility: The quality of being dissoluble; capacity of being dissoluble;capacity of being dissolved by heat or moisture, and converted into afluid.
didine: Like or pertaining to the genus Didus, or the dodo.
donnee: Lit., given; hence, in a literary work, as a drama or tale,that which is assumed as to characters, situation, etc., as a basisfor the plot or story.  W. E. Henley.
departure: The desertion by a party to any pleading of the ground taken byhim in his last antecedent pleading, and the adoption of another.Bouvier.
disincorporate: Separated from, or not included in, a corporation;disincorporated. Bacon.
diaheliotropism: A tendency of leaves or other organs of plants to have theirdorsal surface faced towards the rays of light.
desecrate: To divest of a sacred character or office; to divert from asacred purpose; to violate the sanctity of; to profane; to put to anunworthy use; -- the opposite of consecrate.The [Russian] clergy can not suffer corporal punishment without beingpreviously desecrated. W. Tooke.The founders of monasteries imprecated evil on those who shoulddesecrate their donations. Salmon.
dartars: A kind of scab or ulceration on the skin of lambs.
demiss: Cast down; humble; submissive. [Obs.]He down descended like a most demiss And abject thrall. Spenser.
daint: Something of exquisite taste; a dainty. [Obs.] -- a.
dropper: A branch vein which drops off from, or leaves, the main lode.
disprince: To make unlike a prince. [R.]For I was drench'd with ooze, and torn with briers, . . . And, allone rag, disprinced from head to heel. Tennyson.
discinct: Ungirded; loosely dressed. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
dyingness: The state of dying or the stimulation of such a state; extremelanguor; languishment. [R.]Tenderness becomes me best, a sort of dyingness; you see thatpicture, Foible, -- a swimmingness in the eyes; yes, I'll look so.Congreve.
diseasedness: The state of being diseased; a morbid state; sickness. [R.] T.Burnet.
dentiscalp: An instrument for scraping the teeth.
dactylozooid: A kind of zooid of Siphonophora which has an elongated or evenvermiform body, with one tentacle, but no mouth. See Siphonophora.
defilement: The protection of the interior walls of a fortification from anenfilading fire, as by covering them, or by a high parapet on theexposed side.
decoherer: A device for restoring a coherer to its normal condition afterit has been affected by an electric wave, a process usuallyaccomplished by some method of tapping or shaking, or by rotation ofthe coherer.
downstream: Down the stream; as, floating downstream.
diploe: The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the platesof the skull.
dorsiferous: Bearing, or producing, on the back; -- applied to ferns whichproduce seeds on the back of the leaf, and to certain Batrachia, theova of which become attached to the skin of the back of the parent,where they develop; dorsiparous.
double-lock: To lock with two bolts; to fasten with double security. Tatler.
diphyodont: Having two successive sets of teeth (deciduous and permanent),one succeeding the other; as, a diphyodont mammal; diphyodontdentition; -- opposed to monophyodont.-- n.
diathetic: Pertaining to, or dependent on, a diathesis or specialconstitution of the body; as, diathetic disease.
debacle: A breaking or bursting forth; a violent rush or flood of waterswhich breaks down opposing barriers, and hurls forward and dispersesblocks of stone and other débris.
dyaks: ; sing. Dyak. (Ethnol.) The aboriginal and most numerousinhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain manybarbarous practices.
debauchment: The act of corrupting; the act of seducing from virtue or duty.
dilaniation: A rending or tearing in pieces; dilaceration. [R.]
dehorter: A dissuader; an adviser to the contrary. [Obs.]
depatriate: To withdraw, or cause to withdraw, from one's country; tobanish. [Obs.]A subject born in any state May, if he please, depatriate. Mason.
disinterestedness: The state or quality of being disinterested; impartiality.That perfect disinterestedness and self-devotion of which man seemsto be incapable, but which is sometimes found in woman. Macaulay.
dimorphism: Difference of form between members of the same species, as whena plant has two kinds of flowers, both hermaphrodite (as in thepartridge berry), or when there are two forms of one or both sexes ofthe same species of butterfly.Dimorphism is the condition of the appearance of the same speciesunder two dissimilar forms. Darwin.
deliciate: To delight one's self; to indulge in feasting; to revel. [Obs.]
dys-: An inseparable prefix, fr. the Greek ill, bad, hard, difficult,and the like; cf. the prefixes, Skr. dus-, Goth. tuz-, OHG. zur-, G.zer-, AS. to-, Icel. tor-, Ir. do-.
deictic: Direct; proving directly; -- applied to reasoning, and opposedto elenchtic or refutative.
devulgarize: To free from what is vulgar, common, or narrow.Shakespeare and Plutarch's "Lives" are very devulgarizing books. E.A. Abbott.
developer: A reagent by the action of which the latent image upon aphotographic plate, after exposure in the camera, or otherwise, isdeveloped and visible.
dog fancier: One who has an unusual fancy for, or interest in, dogs; also,one who deals in dogs.
disable: Lacking ability; unable. [Obs.] "Our disable and unactiveforce." Daniel.
dichotomize: To exhibit as a half disk. See Dichotomy,
disparagingly: In a manner to disparage or dishonor; slightingly.
downpour: A pouring or streaming downwards; esp., a heavy or continuousshower.
dicyanide: A compound of a binary type containing two cyanogen groups orradicals; -- called also bicyanide.
depredatory: Tending or designed to depredate; characterized by depredation;plundering; as, a depredatory incursion.
disacknowledge: To refuse to acknowledge; to deny; to disown. [Obs.] South.
diplomatically: According to the rules of diplomacy; in the manner of adiplomatist; artfully.
demonstrableness: The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrability.
discompliance: Failure or refusal to comply; noncompliance.A compliance will discommend me to Mr. Coventry, and a discomplianceto my lord chancellor. Pepys.
drumfish: any fish of the family Sciænidæ, which makes a loud noise bymeans of its air bladder; -- called also drum.
ditheism: The doctrine of those who maintain the existence of two gods orof two original principles (as in Manicheism), one good and one evil;dualism.
deesis: An invocation of, or address to, the Supreme Being.
depauperate: To make poor; to impoverish.Liming does not depauperate; the ground will last long, and bearlarge grain. Mortimer.Humility of mind which depauperates the spirit. Jer. Taylor.
dure: Hard; harsh; severe; rough; toilsome. [R.]The winter is severe, and life is dure and rude. W. H. Russell.
diaphonics: The doctrine of refracted sound; diacoustics.
dominative: Governing; ruling; imperious. Sir E. Sandys.
dissolvative: Having the power to dissolve anything; solvent. [Obs.]Frampton.
deaf-mute: A person who is deaf and dumb; one who, through deprivation ordefect of hearing, has either failed the acquire the power of speech,or has lost it. [See Illust. of Dactylology.]Deaf-mutes are still so called, even when, by artificial methods,they have been taught to speak imperfectly.
disclosed: Represented with wings expanded; -- applied to doves and otherbirds not of prey. Cussans.
discommission: To deprive of a commission or trust. [R.] Laud.
dropworm: The larva of any geometrid moth, which drops from trees bymeans of a thread of silk, as the cankerworm.
dakotas: An extensive race or stock of Indians, including many tribes,mostly dwelling west of the Mississippi River; -- also, in part,called Sioux. [Written also Dacotahs.]
dredger: A box with holes in its lid; -- used for sprinkling flour, ason meat or a breadboard; -- called also dredging box, drudger, anddrudging box.
dogbolt: The bolt of the cap-square over the trunnion of a cannon.Knight.
deliquium: A melting or dissolution in the air, or in a moist place; aliquid condition; as, a salt falls into a deliquium. [R.]
displayed: With wings expanded; -- said of a bird of pray, esp. an eagle.
disburse: To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund ortreasury.The duty of collecting and disbursing his revenues. Macaulay.Disbursing officer, an officer in any department of the publicservice who is charged with the duty of paying out public money.
disorganize: To destroy the organic structure or regular system of (agovernment, a society, a party, etc.); to break up (what isorganized); to throw into utter disorder; to disarrange.Lyford . . . attempted to disorganize the church. Eliot (1809).
domicile: A residence at a particular place accompanied with an intentionto remain there for an unlimited time; a residence accepted as afinal abode. Wharton.
dasymeter: An instrument for testing the density of gases, consisting of athin glass globe, which is weighed in the gas or gases, and then inan atmosphere of known density.
dumpy level: A level having a short telescope (hence its name) rigidly fixedto a table capable only of rotatory movement in a horizontal plane.The telescope is usually an inverting one. It is sometimes called theTroughton level, from the name of the inventor, and a varietyimproved by one Gavatt is known as the Gavatt level.
day-coal: The upper stratum of coal, as nearest the light or surface.
drain: The grain from the mashing tub; as, brewers' drains. [Eng.]Halliwell. Box drain, Counter drain. See under Box, Counter.-- Right of drain (Law), an easement or servitude by which one manhas a right to convey water in pipes through or over the estate ofanother. Kent.
decretist: One who studies, or professes the knowledge of, the decretals.
diffusivity: Tendency to become diffused; tendency, as of heat, to becomeequalized by spreading through a conducting medium.
droop: To let droop or sink. [R.] M. Arnold.Like to a withered vine That droops his sapless branches to theground. Shak.
despondent: Marked by despondence; given to despondence; low-spirited; as,a despondent manner; a despondent prisoner.-- De*spond"ent*ly, adv.
declaratively: By distinct assertion; not impliedly; in the form of adeclaration.The priest shall expiate it, that is, declaratively. Bates.
daman: A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The speciesfound in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of NorthernAfrica is H. Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit.See Cony, and Hyrax.
dogal: Of or pertaining to a doge.[R.]
detersion: The act of deterging or cleansing, as a sore.
detruncation: The act of lopping or cutting off, as the head from the body.
downthrow: The sudden drop or depression of the strata of rocks on oneside of a fault. See Throw, n.
duotone: Any picture printed in two shades of the same color, asduotypes and duographs are usually printed.
dibranchiata: An order of cephalopods which includes those with two gills, anapparatus for emitting an inky fluid, and either eight or tencephalic arms bearing suckers or hooks, as the octopi and squids. SeeCephalopoda.
dufrenite: A mineral of a blackish green color, commonly massive or innodules. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
dove plant: A Central American orchid (Peristeria elata), having a flowerstem five or six feet high, with numerous globose white fragrantflowers. The column in the center of the flower resembles a dove; --called also Holy Spirit plant.
disclusion: A shutting off; exclusion. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
dry nurse: A nurse who attends and feeds a child by hand; -- indistinction from a wet nurse, who suckles it.
dianoialogy: The science of the dianoetic faculties, and their operations.Sir W. Hamilton.
dowlas: A coarse linen cloth made in the north of England and inScotland, now nearly replaced by calico. Shak.
devoutless: Destitute of devotion.-- De*vout"less*ly, adv.-- De*vout"less*ness, n.
destinist: A believer in destiny; a fatalist. [R.]
dirtily: In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.
dynamization: The act of setting free the dynamic powers of a medicine, as byshaking the bottle containing it.
dulcorate: To sweeten; to make less acrimonious. [R.] Bacon.
dietary: Pertaining to diet, or to the rules of diet.
dramatist: The author of a dramatic composition; a writer of plays.
disafforest: To reduce from the privileges of a forest to the state ofcommon ground; to exempt from forest laws.By charter 9 Henry III. many forests were disafforested. Blackstone.
defecator: That which cleanses or purifies; esp., an apparatus forremoving the feculencies of juices and sirups. Knight.
dispondee: A double spondee; a foot consisting of four long syllables.
distracted: Mentally disordered; unsettled; mad.My distracted mind. Pope.
dog-rose: A common European wild rose, with single pink or white flowers.
domiculture: The art of house-keeping, cookery, etc. [R.] R. Park.
dapifer: One who brings meat to the table; hence, in some countries, theofficial title of the grand master or steward of the king's or anobleman's household.
denutrition: The opposition of nutrition; the failure of nutrition causingthe breaking down of tissue.
dunnock: The hedge sparrow or hedge accentor. [Local, Eng.]
dewretting: Dewrotting; the process of decomposing the gummy matter of flaxand hemp and setting the fibrous part, by exposure on a sward to dew,rain, and sunshine.
dispreader: One who spreads abroad.Dispreaders both of vice and error. Milton.
diametral: Pertaining to a diameter; diametrical. Diametral curve,Diametral surface (Geom.), any line or surface which bisects a systemof parallel chords drawn in a curve or surface.-- Diametral planes (Crystal.), planes in which two of the axes lie.
delibrate: To strip off the bark; to peel. [Obs.] Ash.
declarable: Capable of being declared. Sir T. Browne.
disworship: To refuse to worship; to treat as unworthy. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
disproportion: To make unsuitable in quantity, form, or fitness to an end; toviolate symmetry in; to mismatch; to join unfitly.To shape my legs of an unequal size; To disproportion me in everypart. Shak.A degree of strength altogether disproportioned to the extent of itsterritory. Prescott.
doulocracy: A government by slaves. [Written also dulocracy.] Hare.
detrect: To refuse; to decline. [Obs.] "To detrect the battle."Holinshed.
depilatory: Having the quality or power of removing hair.-- n.
drum winding: A method of armature winding in which the wire is wound uponthe outer surface of a cylinder or drum from end to end of thecylinder; -- distinguished from ring winding, etc.
diagnostic: Pertaining to, or furnishing, a diagnosis; indicating thenature of a disease.
diplomate: To invest with a title o [R.] Wood.
decurt: To cut short; to curtail. [Obs.] Bale.
dispossession: The putting out of possession, wrongfully or otherwise, of onewho is in possession of a freehold, no matter in what title; --called also ouster.
definitive: A word used to define or limit the extent of the significationof a common noun, such as the definite article, and some pronouns.
debouch: To march out from a wood, defile, or other confined spot, intoopen ground; to issue.Battalions debouching on the plain. Prescott.
droit: A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also,in old law, the writ of right. Abbott. Droit d'aubaine. See underAubaine.-- Droits of the Admiralty (Eng. Law), rights or perquisites of theAdmiralty, arising from seizure of an enemy's ships in port on thebreaking out of war, or those coming into port in ignorance ofhostilities existing, or from such ships as are taken bynoncommissioned captors; also, the proceeds of wrecks, and derelictproperty at sea. The droits of admiralty are now paid into theExchequer for the public benefit.
dodecatemory: A tern applied to the twelve houses, or parts, of the zodiac ofthe primum mobile, to distinguish them from the twelve signs; also,any one of the twelve signs of the zodiac.
dispand: To spread out; to expand. [Obs.] Bailey.
disembrangle: To free from wrangling or litigation. [Obs.] Berkeley.
disintegrate: To separate into integrant parts; to reduce to fragments or topowder; to break up, or cause to fall to pieces, as a rock, by blowsof a hammer, frost, rain, and other mechanical or atmosphericinfluences.Marlites are not disintegrated by exposure to the atmosphere, atleast in six years. Kirwan.
damnableness: The state or quality of deserving damnation; execrableness.The damnableness of this most execrable impiety. Prynne.
drivebolt: A drift; a tool for setting bolts home.
dollardee: A species of sunfish (Lepomis pallidus), common in the UnitedStates; -- called also blue sunfish, and copper-nosed bream.
doab: A tongue or tract of land included between two rivers; as, thedoab between the Ganges and the Jumna. [India] Am. Cyc.
decussative: Intersecting at acute angles. Sir T. Browne.
discontinue: To interrupt the continuance of; to intermit, as a practice orhabit; to put an end to; to cause to cease; to cease using, to stop;to leave off.Set up their conventicles again, which had been discontinued. Bp.Burnet.I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth. Shak.Taught the Greek tongue, discontinued before in these parts the spaceof seven hundred years. Daniel.They modify and discriminate the voice, without appearing todiscontinue it. Holder.
demulcent: Softening; mollifying; soothing; assuasive; as, oil isdemulcent.
despeed: To send hastily. [Obs.]Despeeded certain of their crew. Speed.
direptitiously: With plundering violence; by violent injustice. [R.] Strype.
diminish: To make smaller by a half step; to make (an interval) less thanminor; as, a diminished seventh.
disjoin: To part; to disunite; to separate; to sunder.That marriage, therefore, God himself disjoins. Milton.Never let us lay down our arms against France, till we have utterlydisjoined her from the Spanish monarchy. Addison.Windmill Street consisted of disjoined houses. Pennant.
dethrone: To remove or drive from a throne; to depose; to divest ofsupreme authority and dignity. "The Protector was dethroned." Hume.
drillstock: A contrivance for holding and turning a drill. Knight.
demonstrative: A demonstrative pronoun; as, "this" and "that" aredemonstratives.
depredation: The act of depredating, or the state of being depredated; theact of despoiling or making inroads; as, the sea often makesdepredation on the land.
delapsion: A falling down, or out of place; prolapsion.
dernful: Secret; hence, lonely; sad; mournful. [Obs.] "Dernful noise."Spenser.
despondency: The state of desponding; loss of hope and cessation of effort;discouragement; depression or dejection of the mind.The unhappy prince seemed, during some days, to be sunk indespondency. Macaulay.
dramatis personae: The actors in a drama or play.
dissyllabify: To form into two syllables. Ogilvie.
diorthotic: Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something;corrective.
desynonymize: To deprive of synonymous character; to discriminate in use; --applied to words which have been employed as synonyms. Coleridge.Trench.
duoliteral: Consisting of two letters only; biliteral. Stuart.
dispirited: Depressed in spirits; disheartened; daunted.-- Dis*pir"it*ed*ly, adv.-- Dis*pir"it*ed, n.
dog-headed: Having a head shaped like that of a dog; -- said of certainbaboons.
duodenum: The part of the small intestines between the stomach and thejejunum. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, under Digestive.
doll: A child's puppet; a toy baby for a little girl.
deficit: Deficiency in amount or quality; a falling short; lack; as, adeficit in taxes, revenue, etc. Addison.
dipleidoscope: An instrument for determining the time of apparent noon. Itconsists of two mirrors and a plane glass disposed in the form of aprism, so that, by the reflections of the sun's rays from theirsurfaces, two images are presented to the eye, moving in oppositedirections, and coinciding at the instant the sun's center is on themeridian.
dianoetic: Pertaining to the discursive faculty, its acts or products.I would employ . . . dianoetic to denote the operation of thediscursive, elaborative, or comparative faculty. Sir W. Hamilton.
disorb: To throw out of the proper orbit; to unsphere. Shak.
demesmerize: To relieve from mesmeric influence. See Mesmerize.
deep-read: Profoundly book-learned. "Great writers and deep-read men."L'Estrange.
dynactinometer: An instrument for measuring the intensity of the photogenic(light-producing) rays, and computing the power of object glasses.
dementate: Deprived of reason.Arise, thou dementate sinner! Hammond.
disunionist: An advocate of disunion, specifically, of disunion of theUnited States.
debatable: Liable to be debated; disputable; subject to controversy orcontention; open to question or dispute; as, a debatable question.The Debatable Land or Ground, a tract of land between the Esk and theSark, claimed by both England and Scotland; the Batable Ground.
dynamics: That department of musical science which relates to, or treatsof, the power of tones.
disseminative: Tending to disseminate, or to become disseminated.The effect of heresy is, like the plague, infectious anddisseminative. Jer. Taylor.
dittied: Set, sung, or composed as a ditty; -- usually in composition.Who, with his soft pipe, and smooth-dittied song. Milton.
domineer: To rule with insolence or arbitrary sway; to play the master;to be overbearing; to tyrannize; to bluster; to swell with conscioussuperiority or haughtiness; -- often with over; as, to domineer overdependents.Go to the feast, revel and domineer. Shak.His wishes tend abroad to roam, And hers to domineer at home. Prior.
delta connection: One of the usual forms or methods for connecting apparatus to athree-phase circuit, the three corners of the delta or triangle, asdiagrammatically represented, being connected to the three wires ofthe supply circuit.
disassenter: One who disassents; a dissenter. [Obs.] State Trials (1634).
damningness: Tendency to bring damnation. "The damningness of them [sins]."Hammond.
diploid: A solid bounded by twenty-four similar quadrilateral faces. Itis a hemihedral form of the hexoctahedron.
douanier: An officer of the French customs. [Anglicized form douaneer.]
deadish: Somewhat dead, dull, or lifeless; deathlike.The lips put on a deadish paleness. A. Stafford.
doffer: A revolving cylinder, or a vibrating bar with teeth, in acarding machine, which doffs, or strips off, the cotton from thecards. Ure.
dickens: The devil. [A vulgar euphemism.]I can not tell what the dickens his name is. Shak.
desideratum: Anything desired; that of which the lack is felt; a wantgenerally felt and acknowledge.
demonship: The state of a demon. Mede.
dissentiate: To throw into a state of dissent. [R.] Feltham.
dunted: Beaten; hence, blunted. [Obs.]Fencer's swords . . . having the edge dunted. Fuller.
diplopoda: An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment;the Chilognatha.
dermatopathic: Of or pertaining to skin diseases, or their cure.
dyeing: The process or art of fixing coloring matters permanently anduniformly in the fibers of wool, cotton, etc.
debut: A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance beforethe public, as of an actor or public speaker.
domina: Lady; a lady; -- a title formerly given to noble ladies whoheld a barony in their own right. Burrill.
dimeter: Having two poetical measures or meters.-- n.
dairymaid: A female servant whose business is the care of the dairy.
double-dye: To dye again or twice over.To double-dye their robes in scarlet. J. Webster.
dehydration: The act or process of freeing from water; also, the conditionof a body from which the water has been removed.
delilah: The mistress of Samson, who betrayed him (Judges xvi.); hence,a harlot; a temptress.Other Delilahs on a smaller scale Burns met with during his Dumfriessojourn. J. C. Shairp.
dementia: Insanity; madness; esp. that form which consists in weakness ortotal loss of thought and reason; mental imbecility; idiocy.
dishonorary: Bringing dishonor on; tending to disgrace; lesseningreputation. Holmes.
dramshop: A shop or barroom where spirits are sold by the dram.
deckle edge: The rough, untrimmed edge of paper left by the deckle; also, arough edge in imitation of this.
deaconhood: The state of being a deacon; office of a deacon; deaconship.
discutient: Serving to disperse morbid matter; discussive; as, a discutientapplication.-- n.
depone: To testify under oath; to depose; to bear witness. [AScotticism]The fairy Glorians, whose credibility on this point can not be calledin question, depones to the confinement of Merlin in a tree. Dunlop.
dateless: Without date; having no fixed time.
digitate: To point out as with the finger. [R.] Robinson (Eudoxa).
divisibility: The quality of being divisible; the property of bodies by whichtheir parts are capable of separation.Divisibility . . . is a primary attribute of matter. Sir W. Hamilton.
derdoing: Doing daring or chivalrous deeds. [Obs.] "In derdoing arms."Spenser.
ducking: , from Duck, v. t. & i. Ducking stool, a stool or chair inwhich common scolds were formerly tied, and plunged into water, as apunishment. See Cucking stool. The practice of ducking began in thelatter part of the 15th century, and prevailed until the early partof the 18th, and occasionally as late as the 19th century.Blackstone. Chambers.
dulcify: To sweeten; to free from acidity, saltness, or acrimony.Wiseman.
diphthongalize: To make into a diphthong; to pronounce as a diphthong.
dephlegmation: The operation of separating water from spirits and acids, byevaporation or repeated distillation; -- called also concentration,especially when acids are the subject of it. [Obs.]
daphnetin: A colorless crystalline substance, C9H6O4, extracted fromdaphnin.
dehydrate: To deprive of water; to render free from water; as, todehydrate alcohol.
disrober: One who, or that which, disrobes.
defilade: To raise, as a rampart, so as to shelter interior workscommanded from some higher point.
denouncer: One who denounces, or declares, as a menace.Here comes the sad denouncer of my fate. Dryden.
dicarbonic: Containing two carbon residues, or two carboxyl or radicals;as, oxalic acid is a dicarbonic acid.
degerm: To extract the germs from, as from wheat grains.
delimitation: The act or process of fixing limits or boundaries; limitation.Gladstone.
disobey: Not to obey; to neglect or refuse to obey (a superior or hiscommands, the laws, etc.); to transgress the commands of (one inauthority); to violate, as an order; as, refractory children disobeytheir parents; men disobey their Maker and the laws.Not to disobey her lord's behest. Tennyson.
destructionist: One who believes in the final destruction or completeannihilation of the wicked; -- called also annihilationist. Shipley.
diandria: A Linnæan class of plants having two stamens.
durometer: An instrument for measuring the degree of hardness; especially,an instrument for testing the relative hardness of steel rails andthe like.
diffraction: The deflection and decomposition of light in passing by theedges of opaque bodies or through narrow slits, causing theappearance of parallel bands or fringes of prismatic colors, as bythe action of a grating of fine lines or bars.Remarked by Grimaldi (1665), and referred by him to a property oflight which he called diffraction. Whewell.Diffraction grating. (Optics) See under Grating.-- Diffraction spectrum. (Optics) See under Spectrum.
discal: Pertaining to, or resembling, a disk; as, discal cells.
doitkin: A very small coin; a doit.
discommode: To put inconvenience; to incommode; to trouble. [R.]
decalogist: One who explains the decalogue. J. Gregory.
drevil: A fool; a drudge. See Drivel.
dibs: A sweet preparation or treacle of grape juice, much used in theEast. Johnston.
dovelet: A young or small dove. Booth.
disregard: Not to regard; to pay no heed to; to omit to take notice of; toneglect to observe; to slight as unworthy of regard or notice; as, todisregard the admonitions of conscience.Studious of good, man disregarded fame. Blackmore.
dunce: One backward in book learning; a child or other person dull orweak in intellect; a dullard; a dolt.I never knew this town without dunces of figure. Swift.
demency: Dementia; loss of mental powers. See Insanity.
down-share: A breastplow used in paring off turf on downs. [Eng.] Knight.
disseize: To deprive of seizin or possession; to dispossess or oustwrongfully (one in freehold possession of land); -- followed by of;as, to disseize a tenant of his freehold. [Written also disseise.]Which savage beasts strive as eagerly to keep and hold those goldenmines, as the Arimaspians to disseize them thereof. Holland.
demonologist: One who writes on, or is versed in, demonology.
disinvolve: To uncover; to unfold or unroll; to disentangle. [R.] Dr. H.More.
datary: An officer in the pope's court, having charge of the Dataria.
destructibility: The quality of being capable of destruction; destructibleness.
decarbonize: To deprive of carbon; as, to decarbonize steel; to decarbonizethe blood. Decarbonized iron. See Malleable iron.-- Decarbonized steel, homogenous wrought iron made by a steelprocess, as that of Bessemer; ingot iron.
damn: To doom to punishment in the future world; to consign toperdition; to curse.
delaware: An American grape, with compact bunches of small, amber-coloredberries, sweet and of a good flavor.
deperditely: , adv. Hopelessly; despairingly; in the manner of one ruined;as, deperditely wicked. [Archaic]
dolphin: A mass of iron or lead hung from the yardarm, in readiness tobe dropped on the deck of an enemy's vessel.
depreciative: Tending, or intended, to depreciate; expressing depreciation;undervaluing.-- De*pre"ci*a`tive*ly, adv.
demonstratively: In a manner fitted to demonstrate; clearly; convincingly;forcibly.
decimalism: The system of a decimal currency, decimal weights, measures,etc.
dipolar: Having two poles, as a magnetic bar.
davy jones: The spirit of the sea; sea devil; -- a term used by sailors.This same Davy Jones, according to the mythology of sailors, is thefiend that presides over all the evil spirits of the deep, and isseen in various shapes warning the devoted wretch of death and woe.Smollett.Davy Jones's Locker, the ocean, or bottom of the ocean.-- Gone to Davy Jones's Locker, dead, and buried in the sea; thrownoverboard.
deluder: One who deludes; a deceiver; an impostor.
dogvane: A small vane of bunting, feathers, or any other light material,carried at the masthead to indicate the direction of the wind.Totten.
dioptase: A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-greencrystals.
diphycercal: Having the tail fin divided into two equal parts by thenotochord, or end of the vertebral column; protocercal. SeeProtocercal.
defatigate: To weary or tire out; to fatigue. [R.] Sir T. Herbert.
deuteropathic: Pertaining to deuteropathy; of the nature of deuteropathy.
dilluing: A process of sorting ore by washing in a hand sieve. [Writtenalso deluing.]
della crusca: A shortened form of Academia della Crusca, an academy inFlorescence, Italy, founded in the 16th century, especially forconversing the purity of the Italian language.
dubber: One who, or that which, dubs.
digestive: Pertaining to digestion; having the power to cause or promotedigestion; as, the digestive ferments.Digestive cheese and fruit there sure will be. B. Jonson.Digestive apparatus, the organs of food digestion, esp. thealimentary canal and glands connected with it.-- Digestive salt, the chloride of potassium.
drabber: One who associates with drabs; a wencher. Massinger.
denature: To deprive of its natural qualities; change the nature of.
dicynodont: One of a group of extinct reptiles having the jaws armed with ahorny beak, as in turtles, and in the genus Dicynodon, supportingalso a pair of powerful tusks. Their remains are found in triassicstrata of South Africa and India.
decani: Used of the side of the choir on which the dean's stall isplaced; decanal; -- correlative to cantoris; as, the decanal, ordecani, side.
debarb: To deprive of the beard. [Obs.] Bailey.
dentary: Pertaining to, or bearing, teeth.-- n.
diiodide: A compound of a binary type containing two atoms of iodine; --called also biniodide.
disrepute: Loss or want of reputation; ill character; disesteem;discredit.At the beginning of the eighteenth century astrology fell intogeneral disrepute. Sir W. Scott.
dequantitate: To diminish the quantity of; to disquantity. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
divulge: To become publicly known. [R.] "To keep it from divulging."Shak.
dimorphous: Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinctforms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
detail: The selection for a particular service of a person or a body ofmen; hence, the person or the body of men so selected. Detaildrawing, a drawing of the full size, or on a large scale, of somepart of a building, machine, etc.-- In detail, in subdivisions; part by part; item; circumstantially;with particularity.
dak: Post; mail; also, the mail or postal arrangements; -- speltalso dawk, and dauk. [India] Dak boat, a mail boat. Percy Smith.-- Dak bungalow, a traveler's rest-house at the and of a dak stage.-- To travel by dak, to travel by relays of palanquines or othercarriage, as fast as the post along a road.
doxological: Pertaining to doxology; giving praise to God. Howell.
downsitting: The act of sitting down; repose; a resting.Thou knowest my downsitting and my uprising. Ps. cxxxix. 2.
disdainful: Full of disdain; expressing disdain; scornful; contemptuous;haughty.From these Turning disdainful to an equal good. Akenside.-- Dis*dain"ful*ly, adv.-- Dis*dain"ful*ness, n.
decastyle: Having ten columns in front; -- said of a portico, temple, etc.-- n.
danubian: Pertainingto, or bordering on, the river Danube.
drumbeat: The sound of a beaten drum; drum music.Whose morning drumbeat, following the sun, and keeping company withthe hours, circles the earth with one continuous and unbroken strainof the martial airs of England. D. Webster.
diplograph: An instrument used for double writing, as one for producingembossed writing for the blind and ordinary writing at the same time.-- Dip`lo*graph"ic*al (#), a. -- Dip*log"ra*phy (#), n.
dulcamara: A plant (Solanum Dulcamara). See Bittersweet, n.,
deliberative: Pertaining to deliberation; proceeding or acting bydeliberation, or by discussion and examination; deliberating; as, adeliberative body.A consummate work of deliberative wisdom. Bancroft.The court of jurisdiction is to be distinguished from thedeliberative body, the advisers of the crown. Hallam.
disinterestedly: In a disinterested manner; without bias or prejudice.
demisemiquaver: A short note, equal in time to the half of a semiquaver, or thethirty-second part of a whole note.
deliverly: Actively; quickly; nimbly. [Obs.]Swim with your bodies, And carry it sweetly and deliverly. Beau. &Fl.
discontentment: The state of being discontented; uneasiness; inquietude. Bacon.
disavaunce: To retard; to repel; to do damage to. [Obs.] Chaucer.
doomful: Full of condemnation or destructive power. [R.] "That doomfuldeluge." Drayton.
double: Having the petals in a flower considerably increased beyond thenatural number, usually as the result of cultivation and the expenseof the stamens, or stamens and pistils. The white water lily and someother plants have their blossoms naturally double.
diapnoic: Slightly increasing an insensible perspiration; mildlydiaphoretic.-- n.
disflesh: To reduce the flesh or obesity of. [Obs.] Shelton.
dulcite: A white, sugarlike substance, C6H8.(OH)2, occurring naturallyin a manna from Madagascar, and in certain plants, and producedartificially by the reduction of galactose and lactose or milk sugar.
degrease: To remove grease or fatty matter from, as wool or silk.
diana: The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess whopresided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with theGreek goddess Artemis.And chaste Diana haunts the forest shade. Pope.Diana monkey (Zoöl.), a handsome, white-bearded monkey of West Africa(Cercopithecus Diana).
druidism: The system of religion, philosophy, and instruction, receivedand taught by the Druids; the rites and ceremonies of the Druids.
dampen: To become damp; to deaden. Byron.
deserve: To be worthy of recompense; -- usually with ill or with well.One man may merit or deserve of another. South.
dragon: A fabulous animal, generally represented as a monstrous wingedserpent or lizard, with a crested head and enormous claws, andregarded as very powerful and ferocious.The dragons which appear in early paintings and sculptures areinvariably representations of a winged crocodile. Fairholt.
disgraduate: To degrade; to reduce in rank. [Obs.] Tyndale.
disenthrone: To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority. Milton.
disgregation: The process of separation, or the condition of being separate,as of the molecules of a body.
daubreelite: A sulphide of chromium observed in some meteoric irons.
dough-kneaded: Like dough; soft.He demeans himself . . . like a dough-kneaded thing. Milton.
decurrence: The act of running down; a lapse. [R.] Gauden.
dowral: Of or relating to a dower. [R.]
defective: Lacking some of the usual forms of declension or conjugation;as, a defective noun or verb.-- De*fect"ive*ly, adv.-- De*fect"ive*ness, n.
diegesis: A narrative or history; a recital or relation.
didactic: A treatise on teaching or education. [Obs.] Milton.
diastema: A vacant space, or gap, esp. between teeth in a jaw.
dacian: Of or pertaining to Dacia or the Dacians.-- n.
dactylitis: An inflammatory affection of the fingers. Gross.
depriver: One who, or that which, deprives.
dispersion: The separation of light into its different colored rays,arising from their different refrangibilities. Dispersion of theoptic axes (Crystallog.), the separation of the optic axes in biaxialcrystals, due to the fact that the axial angle has different valuesfor the different colors of the spectrum.
dressy: Showy in dress; attentive to dress.A dressy flaunting maidservant. T. Hook.A neat, dressy gentleman in black. W. Irving.
dispositioned: Having (such) a disposition; -- used in compounds; as, well-dispositioned.
disembellish: To deprive of embellishment; to disadorn. Carlyle.
determinability: The quality of being determinable; determinableness. Coleridge.
duffel bag: A sack to hold miscellaneous articles, as tools, supplies, orthe like.
