devotee: One who is wholly devoted; esp., one given wholly to religion;one who is superstitiously given to religious duties and ceremonies;a bigot.While Father Le Blanc was very devout he was not a devotee. A. S.Hardy.
dash: To rust with violence; to move impetuously; to strikeviolently; as, the waves dash upon rocks.[He] dashed through thick and thin. Dryden.On each hand the gushing waters play, And down the rough cascade alldashing fall. Thomson.
dinichthys: A genus of large extinct Devonian ganoid fishes. In some partsof Ohio remains of the Dinichthys are abundant, indicating animalstwenty feet in length.
duumvir: One of two Roman officers or magistrates united in the samepublic functions.
de facto: Actually; in fact; in reality; as, a king de facto, --distinguished from a king de jure, or by right.
dressmaking: The art, process, or occupation, of making dresses.
diverticulum: A blind tube branching out of a longer one.
decerp: To pluck off; to crop; to gather. [Obs.]
demountable: Capable of being dismounted; -- said of a form of rim, for anautomobile wheel, which can be removed with its tire from the wheel.
disorderly: Offensive to good morals and public decency; notoriouslyoffensive; as, a disorderly house.
damp off: To decay and perish through excessive moisture.
defiant: Full of defiance; bold; insolent; as, a defiant spirit or act.In attitude stern and defiant. Longfellow.-- De*fi"ant*ly, adv.-- De*fi"ant*ness, n.
dear: A dear one; lover; sweetheart.That kiss I carried from thee, dear. Shak.
discept: To debate; to discuss. [R.]One dissertates, he is candid; Two must discept, -- hasdistinguished. R. Browning.
darlingtonia: A genus of California pitcher plants consisting of a singlespecies. The long tubular leaves are hooded at the top, andfrequently contain many insects drowned in the secretion of theleaves.
despoliation: A stripping or plundering; spoliation. Bailey.
dignotion: Distinguishing mark; diagnostic. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
disinvigorate: To enervate; to weaken. [R.] Sydney Smith.
desmomyaria: The division of Tunicata which includes the Salpæ. See Salpa.
diplostemonous: Having twice as many stamens as petals, as the geranium. R.Brown.
deny: To answer inThen Sarah denied, saying, I laughed not; for she was afraid. Gen.xviii. 15.
disally: To part, as an alliance; to sunder. [R.] "Disallied theirnuptials." Milton.
drawling: The act of speaking with a drawl; a drawl.-- Drawl"ing*ly, adv. Bacon.
deft: Apt; fit; dexterous; clever; handy; spruce; neat. [Archaic orPoetic] "The deftest way." Shak. "Deftest feats." Gay.The limping god, do deft at his new ministry. Dryden.Let me be deft and debonair. Byron.
defeudalize: To deprive of the feudal character or form.
diphtheria: A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages,and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane,produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation. Cf.Group.
depravity: The stae of being depraved or corrupted; a vitiated state ofmoral character; general badness of character; wickedness of mind orheart; absence of religious feeling and principle. Total depravity.See Original sin, and Calvinism.
dilatoriness: The quality of being dilatory; lateness; slowness; tardiness;sluggishness.
devitrification: The act or process of devitrifying, or the state of beingdevitrified. Specifically, the conversion of molten glassy matterinto a stony mass by slow cooling, the result being the formation ofcrystallites, microbites, etc., in the glassy base, which are thencalled devitrification products.
determinator: One who determines. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
dequeen: To remove the queen from (a hive of bees).
drainpipe: A pipe used for carrying off surplus water.
dubitate: To doubt. [R.]If he . . . were to loiter dubitating, and not come. Carlyle.
describe: To use the faculty of describing; to give a description; as,Milton describes with uncommon force and beauty.
disceptator: One who arbitrates or decides. [R.] Cowley.
damnation: Condemnation to everlasting punishment in the future state, orthe punishment itself.How can ye escape the damnation of hell Matt. xxiii. 33.Wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation. Shak.
defilading: The art or act of determining the directions and heights of thelines of rampart with reference to the protection of the interiorfrom exposure to an enemy's fire from any point within range, or fromany works which may be erected. Farrow.
distrain: To levy a distress.Upon whom I can distrain for debt. Camden.
dynamometer: An apparatus for measuring force or power; especially, musculareffort of men or animals, or the power developed by a motor, or thatrequired to operate machinery.
delve: To dig or labor with a spade, or as with a spade; to labor as adrudge.Delve may I not: I shame to beg. Wyclif (Luke xvi. 3).
discloak: To take off a cloak from; to uncloak. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
decalcify: To deprive of calcareous matter; thus, to decalcify bones is toremove the stony part, and leave only the gelatin.
digestedly: In a digested or well-arranged manner; methodically.
denim: A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.
dumdum bullet: A kind of manstopping bullet; -- so named from Dumdum, inIndia, where bullets are manufactured for the Indian army.
distoma: A genus of parasitic, trematode worms, having two suckers forattaching themselves to the part they infest. See 1st Fluke,
draught: The act of selecting or detaching soldiers; a draft (see Draft,n., 2)(g) The act of drawing up, marking out, or delineating;representation. Dryden.
diligently: In a diligent manner; not carelessly; not negligently; withindustry or assiduity.Ye diligently keep commandments of the Lord your God. Deut. vi. 17.
displat: To untwist; to uncurl; to unplat. [Obs.] Hakewill.
doorstep: The stone or plank forming a step before an outer door.
drawboy: A boy who operates the harness cords of a hand loom; also, apart of power loom that performs the same office.
dasyure: A carnivorous marsupial quadruped of Australia, belonging tothe genus Dasyurus. There are several species.
denotation: The marking off or separation of anything. Hammond.
diamondize: To set with diamonds; to adorn; to enrich. [R.]Diamondizing of your subject. B. Jonson.
discordant: Dissonant; not in harmony or musical concord; harsh; jarring;as, discordant notes or sounds.For still their music seemed to start Discordant echoes in eachheart. Longfellow.
ditolyl: A white, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C14H14, consistingof two radicals or residues of toluene.
defoliation: The separation of ripened leaves from a branch or stem; thefalling or shedding of the leaves.
disallow: To refuse to allow; to deny the force or validity of; to disownand reject; as, the judge disallowed the executor's charge.To whom coming, as unto a living stone, disallowed indeed of men, butchosen of God. 1 Pet. ii. 4.That the edicts of Cæsar we may at all times disallow, but thestatutes of God for no reason we may reject. Milton.
debentured: Entitled to drawback or debenture; as, debentured goods.
dayspring: The beginning of the day, or first appearance of light; thedawn; hence, the beginning. Milton.The tender mercy of our God; whereby the dayspring from on high hathvisited us. Luke i. 78.
driveway: A passage or way along or through which a carriage may bedriven.
debase: To reduce from a higher to a lower state or grade of worth,dignity, purity, station, etc.; to degrade; to lower; to deteriorate;to abase; as, to debase the character by crime; to debase the mind byfrivolity; to debase style by vulgar words.The coin which was adulterated and debased. Hale.It is a kind of taking God's name in vain to debase religion withsuch frivolous disputes. Hooker.And to debase the sons, exalts the sires. Pope.
depositure: The act of depositing; deposition. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
dipterygian: Having two dorsal fins; -- said of certain fishes.
dunderhead: A dunce; a numskull; a blockhead. Beau. & Fl.
disclaimer: A denial, disavowal, or renunciation, as of a title, claim,interest, estate, or trust; relinquishment or waiver of an interestor estate. Burrill.
dad: Father; -- a word sometimes used by children.I was never so bethumped withwords, Since I first called my brother'sfather dad. Shak.
diverting: Amusing; entertaining.-- Di*vert"ing*ly, adv.-- Di*vert"ing*ness, n.
diver: Any bird of certain genera, as Urinator (formerly Colymbus), orthe allied genus Colymbus, or Podiceps, remarkable for their agilityin diving.
dilacerate: To rend asunder; to tear to pieces. Sir T. Browne.
devisee: One to whom a devise is made, or real estate given by will.
decipiency: State of being deceived; hallucination. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
demonomy: The dominion of demons. [R.] Sir T. Herbert.
dochmiac: Pertaining to, or containing, the dochmius.
depuratory: Depurating; tending to depurate or cleanse; depurative.
dyspnoic: Affected with shortness of breath; relating to dyspn
dimit: To dismiss, let go, or release. [Obs.]
defend: To deny the right of the plaintiff in regard to (the suit, orthe wrong charged); to oppose or resist, as a claim at law; tocontest, as a suit. Burrill.
despair: To be hopeless; to have no hope; to give up all hope orexpectation; -- often with of.We despaired even of life. 2 Cor. i. 8.Never despair of God's blessings here. Wake.
driftwind: A driving wind; a wind that drives snow, sand, etc., intoheaps. Beau. & Fl.
dermopterygii: A group of fishlike animals including the Marsipobranchiata andLeptocardia.
deiparous: Bearing or bringing forth a god; -- said of the Virgin Mary.[Obs.] Bailey.
deflective: Causing deflection. Deflective forces, forces that cause a bodyto deviate from its course.
diocese: The circuit or extent of a bishop's jurisdiction; the districtin which a bishop exercises his ecclesiastical authority.[Frequently, but improperly, spelt diocess.]
digenea: A division of Trematoda in which alternate generations occur,the immediate young not resembling their parents.
diplomatics: The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancientwritings, and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.
doubler: An instrument for augmenting a very small quantity ofelectricity, so as to render it manifest by sparks or theelectroscope.
decyl: A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21, never existing alone, butregarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compoundsof the paraffin series.
daddy longlegs: An arachnidan of the genus Phalangium, and allied genera,having a small body and four pairs of long legs; -- called alsoharvestman, carter, and grandfather longlegs.
disleave: To deprive of leaves. [R.]The cankerworms that annually that disleaved the elms. Lowell.
disruption: The act or rending asunder, or the state of being rent asunderor broken in pieces; breach; rent; dilaceration; rupture; as, thedisruption of rocks in an earthquake; disruption of a state.
diastasis: A forcible of bones without fracture.
disquiettude: Want of peace or tranquility; uneasiness; disturbance;agitation; anxiety.Fears and disquietude, and unavoidable anxieties of mind. Abp. Sharp.
drear: Dismal; gloomy with solitude. "A drear and dying sound."Milton.
disalliege: To alienate from allegiance. [Obs. & R.] Milton.
disbranch: To divest of a branch or branches; to tear off. Shak.
deflagrability: The state or quality of being deflagrable.The ready deflagrability . . . of saltpeter. Boyle.
dissymmetry: Absence or defect of symmetry; asymmetry.
disarticulator: One who disarticulates and prepares skeletons.
delta: A tract of land shaped like the letter delta (as, the delta ofthe Ganges, of the Nile, or of the Mississippi.
disband: To become separated, broken up, dissolved, or scattered;especially, to quit military service by breaking up organization.
delightful: Highly pleasing; affording great pleasure and satisfaction."Delightful bowers." Spenser. "Delightful fruit." Milton.
delusional: Of or pertaining to delusions; as, delusional monomania.
diatryma: An extinct eocene bird from New Mexico, larger than theostrich.
durio: A fruit tree (D. zibethinus, the only species known) of theIndian Archipelago. It bears the durian.
deforest: To clear of forests; to dis U. S. Agric. Reports.
deprecate: To pray against, as an evil; to seek to avert by player; todesire the removal of; to seek deliverance from; to express deepregret for; to disapprove of strongly.His purpose was deprecated by all round him, and he was withdifficulty induced to adandon it. Sir W. Scott.
disheritor: One who puts another out of his inheritance.
deliverable: Capable of being, or about to be, delivered; necessary to bedelivered. Hale.
demonstrate: To exhibit and explain (a dissection or other anatomicalpreparation).
disquiet: Deprived of quiet; impatient; restless; uneasy. [R.] Shak.
drawplate: A hardened steel plate having a hole, or a gradation of conicalholes, through which wires are drawn to be reduced and elongated.
decime: A French coin, the tenth part of a franc, equal to about twocents.
diadelphia: A Linnæan class of plants whose stamens are united into twobodies or bundles by their filaments.
dor: A large European scaraboid beetle (Geotrupes stercorarius),which makes a droning noise while flying. The name is also applied toallied American species, as the June bug. Called also dorr,dorbeetle, or dorrbeetle, dorbug, dorrfly, and buzzard clock.
dipteral: Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
defraudation: The act of defrauding; a taking by fraud. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
duke: To play the duke. [Poetic]Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence. Shak.
denudation: The laying bare of rocks by the washing away of the overlyingearth, etc.; or the excavation and removal of them by the action ofrunning water.
disproperty: To cause to be no longer property; to dispossess of. [R.] Shak.
doom palm: A species of palm tree (Hyphæne Thebaica), highly valued forthe fibrous pulp of its fruit, which has the flavor of gingerbread,and is largely eaten in Egypt and Abyssinia. [Written also doumpalm.]
diamond-back: The salt-marsh terrapin of the Atlantic coast (Malacoclemmyspalustris).
diastase: A soluble, nitrogenous ferment, capable of converting starchand dextrin into sugar.
demiquaver: A note of half the length of the quaver; a semiquaver. [R.]
deceptivity: Deceptiveness; a deception; a sham. [R.] Carlyle.
diallel: Meeting and intersecting, as lines; not parallel; -- opposed toparallel. [Obs.] Ash.
doxy: A loose wench; a disreputable sweetheart. Shak.
describable: That can be described; capable of description.
descending: Of or pertaining to descent; moving downwards. Descendingconstellations or signs (Astron.), those through which the planetsdescent toward the south.-- Descending node (Astron.), that point in a planet's orbit whereit intersects the ecliptic in passing southward.-- Descending series (Math.), a series in which each term isnumerically smaller than the preceding one; also, a series arrangedaccording to descending powers of a quantity.
distinguishing: Constituting difference, or distinction from everything else;distinctive; peculiar; characteristic.The distinguishing doctrines of our holy religion. Locke.Distinguishing pennant (Naut.), a special pennant by which anyparticular vessel in a fleet is recognized and signaled. Simmonds.
dacoit: One of a class of robbers, in India, who act in gangs.
dyingly: In a dying manner; as if at the point of death. Beau. & Fl.
diaper: Surface decoration of any sort which consists of the constantrepetition of one or more simple figures or units of design evenlyspaced.
diaphote: An instrument designed for transmitting pictures by telegraph.Fallows.
docimastic: Proving by experiments or tests. Docimastic art, metallurgy, orthe art of assaying metals; the art of separating metals from foreignmatters, and determining the nature and quantity of metallicsubstances contained in any ore or mineral.
denarius: A Roman silver coin of the value of about fourteen cents; the"penny" of the New Testament; -- so called from being worthoriginally ten of the pieces called as.
dichroic: Having the property of dichroism; as, a dichroic crystal.
dent: To make a dent upon; to indent.The houses dented with bullets. Macaulay.
denier: One who denies; as, a denier of a fact, or of the faith, or ofChrist.
damewort: A cruciferrous plant (Hesperis matronalis), remarkable for itsfragrance, especially toward the close of the day; -- called alsorocket and dame's violet. Loudon.
depositor: One who makes a deposit, especially of money in bank; -- thecorrelative of depository.
ditty-bag: A sailor's small bag to hold thread, needles, tape, etc.; --also called sailor's housewife.
dogwatch: A half watch; a watch of two hours, of which there are two, thefirst dogwatch from 4 to 6 o'clock, p.m., and the second dogwatchfrom 6 to 8 o'clock, P. M. Totten.
diageotropism: The tendency of organs (as roots) of plants to assume aposition oblique or transverse to a direction towards the center ofthe earth.
dismask: To divest of a mask. Shak.
dulia: An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angelsand saints as the servants of God.
delphinine: A poisonous alkaloid extracted from the stavesacre (Delphiniumstaphisagria), as a colorless amorphous powder.
dolus: Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.Wharton.
dissentaneous: Disagreeing; contrary; differing; -- opposed to consentaneous.[R.] Barrow.
double-bank: To row by rowers sitting side by side in twos on a bank orthwart. To double-bank an oar, to set two men to pulling one oar.
deceased: Passed away; dead; gone. The deceased, the dead person.
demulce: To soothe; to mollify; to pacify; to soften. [R.] Sir T. Elyot.
decurion: A head or chief over ten; especially, an officer who commandeda division of ten soldiers.
davyne: A variety of nephelite from Vesuvius.
delta current: The current flowing through a delta connection.
dungy: Full of dung; filthy; vile; low. Shak.
deobstruent: Removing obstructions; having power to clear or open thenatural ducts of the fluids and secretions of the body; aperient.-- n.
diminution: Omission, inaccuracy, or defect in a record.
d: The nominal of the second tone in the model major scale (thatin C), or of the fourth tone in the relative minor scale of C (thatin A minor), or of the key tone in the relative minor of F.
daw: A European bird of the Crow family (Corvus monedula), oftennesting in church towers and ruins; a jackdaw.The loud daw, his throat displaying, draw The whole assembly of hisfellow daws. Waller.
deutoplasm: The lifeless food matter in the cytoplasm of an ovum or a cell,as distinguished from the active or true protoplasm; yolk substance;yolk.
dactylotheca: The scaly covering of the toes, as in birds.
duad: A union of two; duality. [R.] Harris.
densimeter: An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity or densityof a substance.
disenchained: Freed from restraint; unrestrained. [Archaic] E. A. Poe.
dicotyledonous: Having two cotyledons or seed lobes; as, a dicotyledonousplant.
disillusionize: To disenchant; to free from illusion. "The bitterdisillusionizing experience of postnuptial life." W. Black.
discommon: To deprive of commonable quality, as lands, by inclosing orappropriating. Burrill.
duplex: Double; twofold. Duplex escapement, a peculiar kind of watchescapement, in which the scape-wheel has two sets of teeth. SeeEscapement.-- Duplex lathe, one for turning off, screwing, and surfacing, bymeans of two cutting tools, on opposite sides of the piece operatedupon.-- Duplex pumping engine, a steam pump in which two steam cylindersare placed side by side, one operating the valves of the other.-- Duplex querela Etym: [L., double complaint] (Eccl. Law), acomplaint in the nature of an appeal from the ordinary to hisimmediate superior, as from a bishop to an archbishop. Mozley & W.-- Duplex telegraphy, a system of telegraphy for sending twomessages over the same wire simultaneously.-- Duplex watch, one with a duplex escapement.
delf: A mine; a quarry; a pit dug; a ditch. [Written also delft, anddelve.] [Obs.]The delfts would be so flown with waters, that no gins or machinescould . . . keep them dry. Ray.
drudgery: The act of drudging; disagreeable and wearisome labor; ignobleor slavish toil.The drudgery of penning definitions. Macaulay.Paradise was a place of bliss . . . without drudgery and with outsorrow. Locke.
defensive: That which defends; a safeguard.Wars preventive, upon just fears, are true defensive. Bacon.To be on the defensive, To stand on the defensive, to be or stand ina state or posture of defense or resistance, in opposition toaggression or attack.
deflow: To flow down. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
dotted: Marked with, or made of, dots or small spots; diversified withsmall, detached objects. Dotted note (Mus.), a note followed by a dotto indicate an increase of length equal to one half of its simplevalue; thus, a dotted semibreve is equal to three minims, and adotted quarter to three eighth notes.-- Dotted rest, a rest lengthened by a dot in the same manner as adotted note.
delver: One who digs, as with a spade.
dint: To make a mark or cavity on or in, by a blow or by pressure; todent. Donne. Tennyson.
drawnet: A net for catching the larger sorts of birds; also, a dragnet.Crabb.
disespouse: To release from espousal or plighted faith. [Poetic] Milton.
discriminateness: The state of being discriminated; distinctness.
deprovincialize: To divest of provincial quality or characteristics.
decumbiture: Aspect of the heavens at the time of taking to one's sick bed,by which the prognostics of recovery or death were made.
degu: A small South American rodent (Octodon Cumingii), of the familyOctodontidæ.
disheritance: The act of disinheriting or state of being disinherited;disinheritance. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
disuniter: One who, or that which, disjoins or causes disunion.
defense: To furnish with defenses; to fortify. [Obs.] [Written alsodefence.]Better manned and more strongly defensed. Hales.
dulcamarin: A glucoside extracted from the bittersweet (Solanum Dulcamara),as a yellow amorphous substance. It probably occasions the compoundtaste. See Bittersweet, 3(a).
driftpin: A smooth drift. See Drift, n., 9.
dividend: A number or quantity which is to be divided.
decreet: The final judgment of the Court of Session, or of an inferiorcourt, by which the question at issue is decided.
dalmatian: Of or pertaining to Dalmatia. Dalmatian dog (Zoöl.), a carriagedog, shaped like a pointer, and having black or bluish spots on awhite ground; the coach dog.
disconsolated: Disconsolate. [Obs.]A poor, disconsolated, drooping creature. Sterne.
dog: A quadruped of the genus Canis, esp. the domestic dog (C.familiaris).
demonial: Of or pertaining to a demon. [Obs.] Cudworth.
distyle: Having two columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, orthe like. Distyle in antis, having columns between two antæ. SeeAnta.
dissuasive: Tending to dissuade or divert from a measure or purpose;dehortatory; as, dissuasive advice.-- n.
dimorphic: Having the property of dimorphism; dimorphous.
dime: A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents;the tenth of a dollar. Dime novel, a novel, commonly sensational andtrashy, which is sold for a dime, or ten cents.
disintegrator: A machine for grinding or pulverizing by percussion.
diffusiveness: The quality or state of being diffusive or diffuse;extensiveness; expansion; dispersion. Especially of style:Diffuseness; want of conciseness; prolixity.The fault that I find with a modern legend, it its diffusiveness.Addison.
disembowelment: The act of disemboweling, or state of being disemboweled;evisceration.
double-ender: A locomotive with pilot at each end. Knight.
dualism: State of being dual or twofold; a twofold division; any systemwhich is founded on a double principle, or a twofold distinction; as:(a) (Philos.) A view of man as constituted of two original andindependent elements, as matter and spirit. (Theol.)(b) A system which accepts two gods, or two original principles, onegood and the other evil.(c) The doctrine that all mankind are divided by the arbitrary decreeof God, and in his eternal foreknowledge, into two classes, the electand the reprobate.(d) (Physiol.) The theory that each cerebral hemisphere actsindependently of the other.An inevitable dualism bisects nature, so that each thing is a half,and suggests another thing to make it whole. Emerson.
dispair: To separate (a pair). [R.]I have . . . dispaired two doves. Beau. & Fl.
discover: To discover or show one's self. [Obs.]This done, they discover. DeckeNor was this the first time that they discovered to be followers ofthis world. Milton.
detonation: An explosion or sudden report made by the instantaneousdecomposition or combustion of unstable substances' as, thedetonation of gun cotton.
decipherable: Capable of being deciphered; as, old writings not decipherable.
dilapidated: Decayed; fallen into partial ruin; injured by bad usage orneglect.A deserted and dilapidated buildings. Cooper.
downstroke: A stroke made with a downward motion of the pen or pencil.
dyehouse: A building in which dyeing is carried on.
doggedly: In a dogged manner; sullenly; with obstinate resolution.
daff: To cast aside; to put off; to doff. [Obs.]Canst thou so daff me Thou hast killed my child. Shak.
dotish: Foolish; weak; imbecile. Sir W. Scott.
dry goods: A commercial name for textile fabrics, cottons, woolens, linen,silks, laces, etc., -- in distinction from groceries. [U.S.]
dingdong: An attachment to a clock by which the quarter hours are struckupon bells of different tones.
disgarland: To strip of a garland. [Poetic] "Thy locks disgarland."Drummond.
drawl: To utter in a slow, lengthened tone.
decretive: Having the force of a decree; determining.The will of God is either decretive or perceptive. Bates.
debted: Indebted; obliged to. [R.]I stand debted to this gentleman. Shak.
domestication: The act of domesticating, or accustoming to home; the action oftaming wild animals.
decagon: A plane figure having ten sides and ten angles; any figurehaving ten angles. A regular decagon is one that has all its sidesand angles equal.
drawgloves: An old game, played by holding up the fingers. Herrick.
discoast: To depart; to quit the coast (that is, the side or border) ofanything; to be separated. [Obs.]As far as heaven and earth discoasted lie. G. Fletcher.To discoast from the plain and simple way of speech. Barrow.
dragonnade: The severe persecution of French Protestants under Louis XIV.,by an armed force, usually of dragoons; hence, a rapid anddevastating incursion; dragoonade.He learnt it as he watched the dragonnades, the tortures, themassacres of the Netherlands. C. Kingsley.
depth: The number of simple elements which an abstract conception ornotion includes; the comprehension or content.
disaggregation: The separation of an aggregate body into its component parts.
dilute: To become attenuated, thin, or weak; as, it dilutes easily.
disdiapason: An interval of two octaves, or a fifteenth; -- called alsobisdiapason.
delight: To give delight to; to affect with great pleasure; to pleasehighly; as, a beautiful landscape delights the eye; harmony delightsthe ear.Inventions to delight the taste. Shak.Delight our souls with talk of knightly deeds. Tennyson.
detrusion: The act of thrusting or driving down or outward; outwardthrust.-- De*tru"sive, a.
disturber: One who interrupts or incommodes another in the peaceableenjoyment of his right.
dilly: A kind of stagecoach. "The Derby dilly." J. H. Frere.
depurate: Depurated; cleansed; freed from impurities. Boyle.
debarkation: Disembarkation.The debarkation, therefore, had to take place by small steamers. U.S. Grant.
danite: One of a secret association of Mormons, bound by an oath toobey the heads of the church in all things. [U. S.]
disculpate: To free from blame or the imputation of a fault; to exculpate.I almost fear you think I begged it, but I can disculpate myself.Walpole.
diffusion: The act of passing by osmosis through animal membranes, as inthe distribution of poisons, gases, etc., through the body. Unlikeabsorption, diffusion may go on after death, that is, after the bloodceases to circulate.
drivepipe: A pipe for forcing into the earth.
demy: Pertaining to, or made of, the size of paper called demy; as, ademy book.
disarrangement: The act of disarranging, or the state of being disarranged;confusion; disorder. Cowper.
direful: Dire; dreadful; terrible; calamitous; woeful; as, a direfulfiend; a direful day.-- Dire"ful*ly, adv.-- Dire"ful*ness, n.
doorcheek: The jamb or sidepiece of a door. Ex. xii. 22 (Douay version).
decrepitude: The broken state produced by decay and the infirmities of age;infirm old age.
devilship: The character or person of a devil or the devil. Cowley.
delightable: Capable of delighting; delightful. [Obs.]Many a spice delightable. Rom. of R.
delibration: The act of stripping off the bark. [Obs.] Ash.
deflectionize: To free from inflections.Deflectionized languages are said to be analytic. Earle.
divinatory: Professing, or relating to, divination. "A natural divinatoryinstinct." Cowley.
debilitate: To impair the strength of; to weaken; to enfeeble; as, todebilitate the body by intemperance.Various ails debilitate the mind. Jenyns.The debilitated frame of Mr. Bertram was exhausted by this lasteffort. Sir W. Scott.
doublet: A word or words unintentionally doubled or set up a secondtime.
diamagnetically: In the manner of, or according to, diamagnetism.
disincorporation: Deprivation of the rights and privileges of a corporation. T.Warton.
discordable: That may produce discord; disagreeing; discordant. [R.]Halliwell.
dehiscence: A gaping or bursting open along a definite line of attachmentor suture, without tearing, as in the opening of pods, or thebursting of capsules at maturity so as to emit seeds, etc.; also, thebursting open of follicles, as in the ovaries of animals, for theexpulsion of their contents.
double-hung: Having both sashes hung with weights and cords; -- said of awindow.
drainage: The system of drains and their operation, by which superfluouswater is removed from towns, railway beds, mines, and other works.
demiwolf: A half wolf; a mongrel dog, between a dog and a wolf.
disgarnish: To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle. Bp. Hall.
drimys: A genus of magnoliaceous trees. Drimys aromatica furnishesWinter's bark.
decrescendo: With decreasing volume of sound; -- a direction to performers,either written upon the staff (abbreviated Dec., or Decresc.), orindicated by the sign.
dizziness: Giddiness; a whirling sensation in the head; vertigo.
doctor: The friar skate. [Prov. Eng.] Doctors' Commons. See underCommons.-- Doctor's stuff, physic, medicine. G. Eliot.-- Doctor fish (Zoöl.), any fish of the genus Acanthurus; thesurgeon fish; -- so called from a sharp lancetlike spine on each sideof the tail. Also called barber fish. See Surgeon fish.
dallier: One Who fondles; a trifler; as, dalliers with pleasant words.Asham.
derogative: Derogatory.-- De*rog"a*tive*ly, adv. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
dobby: An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures(usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
diversifiability: The quality or capacity of being diversifiable. Earle.
demibastion: A half bastion, or that part of a bastion consisting of oneface and one flank.
discuss: To examine or search thoroughly; to exhaust a remedy against,as against a principal debtor before proceeding against the surety.Burrill.
damiana: A Mexican drug, used as an aphrodisiac.
desirableness: The quality of being desirable.The desirableness of the Austrian alliance. Froude.
deliver: Free; nimble; sprightly; active. [Obs.]Wonderly deliver and great of strength. Chaucer.
drawfiling: The process of smooth filing by working the file sidewiseinstead of lengthwise.
dissemble: To conceal the real fact, motives,He that hateth dissembleth with his lips. Prov. xxvi. 24.He [an enemy] dissembles when he assumes an air of friendship. C. J.Smith.
deplorable: Worthy of being deplored or lamented; lamentable; causinggrief; hence, sad; calamitous; grievous; wretched; as, life's evilsare deplorable.Individual sufferers are in a much more deplorable conditious thanany others. Burke.
diclinic: Having two of the intersections between the three axes oblique.See Crystallization.
daisied: Full of daisies; adorned with daisies. "The daisied green."Langhorne.The grass all deep and daisied. G. Eliot.
distributively: By distribution; singly; not collectively; in a distributivemanner.
deodate: A gift or offering to God. [Obs.]Wherein that blessed widow's deodate was laid up. Hooker.
disserviceable: Calculated to do disservice or harm; not serviceable;injurious; harmful; unserviceable. Shaftesbury.-- Dis*serv"ice*a*ble*ness, n. Norris.-- Dis*serv"ice*a*bly, adv.
decretal: Appertaining to a decree; containing a decree; as, a decretalepistle. Ayliffe.
drumly: Turbid; muddy. [Scot. & Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Wodroephe (1623).Burns.
digitalis: A genus of plants including the foxglove.
definable: Capable of being defined, limited, or explained; determinable;describable by definition; ascertainable; as, definable limits;definable distinctions or regulations; definable words.-- De*fin"a*bly, adv.
despume: To free from spume or scum. [Obs.]If honey be despumed. Holland.
dogskin: The skin of a dog, or leather made of the skin. Also usedadjectively.
dowle: Feathery or wool-like down; filament of a feather. Shak.No feather, or dowle of a feather. De Quincey.
diffused: Spread abroad; dispersed; loose; flowing; diffuse.It grew to be a widely diffused opinion. Hawthorne.-- Dif*fus"ed*ly, adv.-- Dif*fus"ed*ness, n.
distrust: To feel absence of trust in; not to confide in or rely upon; todeem of questionable sufficiency or reality; to doubt; to besuspicious of; to mistrust.Not distrusting my health. 2 Mac. ix. 22.To distrust the justice of your cause. Dryden.He that requireth the oath doth distrust that other. Udall.Of all afraid, Distrusting all, a wise, suspicious maid. Collins.
dinoceras: A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- calledalso Uintatherium. See Illustration in Appendix.
dead-pay: Pay drawn for soldiers, or others, really dead, whose names arekept on the rolls.O you commanders, That, like me, have no dead-pays. Massinger.
deliration: Aberration of mind; delirium. J. Motley.Deliration or alienation of the understanding. Mede.
dermoptera: The division of insects which includes the earwigs(Forticulidæ).
donax: A canelike grass of southern Europe (Arundo Donax), used forfishing rods, etc.
dildo: A burden in popular songs. [Obs.]Delicate burthens of dildos and fadings. Shak.
duramen: The heartwood of an exogenous tree.
depredable: Liable to depredation. [Obs.] "Made less depredable." Bacon.
dissertator: One who writers a dissertation; one who discourses. Boyle.
disendowment: The act of depriving of an endowment or endowments.[The] disendowment of the Irish Church. G. B. Smith.
deflect: To cause to turn aside; to bend; as, rays of light are oftendeflected.Sitting with their knees deflected under them. Lord (1630).
dropsy: An unnatural collection of serous fluid in any serous cavity ofthe body, or in the subcutaneous cellular tissue. Dunglison.
defluxion: A discharge or flowing of humors or fluid matter, as from thenose in catarrh; -- sometimes used synonymously with inflammation.Dunglison.
discorporate: Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate. [Obs.]Jas. II.
depasture: To pasture; to feed; to graze; also, to use for pasture. [R.]Cattle, to graze and departure in his grounds. Blackstone.A right to cut wood upon or departure land. Washburn.
dactylar: Of or pertaining to a finger or toe, or to the claw of aninsect crustacean.
disciple: One who receives instruction from another; a scholar; alearner; especially, a follower who has learned to believe in thetruth of the doctrine of his teacher; an adherent in doctrine; as,the disciples of Plato; the disciples of our Savior. The disciples,or The twelve disciples, the twelve selected companions of Jesus; --also called the apostles.-- Disciples of Christ. See Christian, n., 3, and Campbellite.
demandable: That may be demanded or claimed. "All sums demandable." Bacon.
domine: A West Indian fish (Epinula magistralis), of the familyTrichiuridæ. It is a long-bodied, voracious fish.
direct-coupled: Coupled without intermediate connections, as an engine and adynamo.
domiciliar: A member of a household; a domestic.
decantation: The act of pouring off a clear liquor gently from its lees orsediment, or from one vessel into another.
defect: To fail; to become deficient. [Obs.] "Defected honor." Warner.
difficult: To render difficult; to impede; to perplex. [R.] Sir W. Temple.
digraphic: Of or pertaining to a digraph. H. Sweet.
doucepere: One of the twelve peers of France, companions of Charlemagne inwar. [Written also douzepere.] [Obs.]Big-looking like a doughty doucepere. Spenser.
ding: A thump or stroke, especially of a bell.
dialectic: Same as Dialectics.Plato placed his dialectic above all sciences. Liddell & Scott.
devilism: The state of the devil or of devils; doctrine of the devil orof devils. Bp. Hall.
diminisher: One who, or that which, diminishes anything. Clerke (1637).
dragbolt: A coupling pin. See under Coupling. [U. S.]
dyadic: Pertaining to the number two; of two parts or elements. Dyadicarithmetic, the same as binary arithmetic.
dancer: One who dances or who practices dancing. The merry dancers,beams of the northern lights when they rise and fall alternatelywithout any considerable change of length. See Aurora borealis, underAurora.
dissoluteness: State or quality of being dissolute; looseness of morals andmanners; addictedness to sinful pleasures; debauchery; dissipation.Chivalry had the vices of dissoluteness. Bancroft.
doncella: A handsome fish of Florida and the West Indies (Platyglossusradiatus). The name is applied also to the ladyfish (Harpe rufa) ofthe same region.
descry: , Discovery or view, as of an army seen at a distance. [Obs.]Near, and on speedy foot; the main descry Stands on the hourlythought. Shak.
diuretic: Tending to increase the secretion and discharge of urine.-- n.
doyen: Lit., a dean; the senior member of a body or group; as, thedoyen of French physicians. "This doyen of newspapers."  A. R.Colquhoun.
dislive: To deprive of life. [Obs.]Telemachus dislived Amphimedon. Chapman.
district: Rigorous; stringent; harsh. [Obs.]Punishing with the rod of district severity. Foxe.
disoccupation: The state of being unemployed; want of occupation. [R.]
duplicate: Double; twofold. Duplicate proportion or ratio (Math.), theproportion or ratio of squares. Thus, in geometrical proportion, thefirst term to the third is said to be in a duplicate ratio of thefirst to the second, or as its square is to the square of the second.Thus, in 2, 4, 8, 16, the ratio of 2 to 8 is a duplicate of that of 2to 4, or as the square of 2 is to the square of 4.
decoy: To lead into danger by artifice; to lure into a net or snare;to entrap; to insnare; to allure; to entice; as, to decoy troops intoan ambush; to decoy ducks into a net.Did to a lonely cot his steps decoy. Thomson.E'en while fashion's brightest arts decoy, The heart, distrusting,asks if this be joy. Goldsmith.
dismissal: Dismission; discharge.Officeholders were commanded faithfully to enforce it, upon pain ofimmediate dismissal. Motley.
double-tongued: Making contrary declarations on the same subject; deceitful.Likewise must the deacons be grave, not double-tongued. 1 Tim. iii.8.
donation: The act or contract by which a person voluntarily transfers thetitle to a thing of which be is the owner, from himself to another,without any consideration, as a free gift. Bouvier. Donation party, aparty assembled at the house of some one, as of a clergyman, each onebringing some present. [U.S.] Bartlett.
deplumate: Destitute or deprived of features; deplumed.
dipropyl: One of the hexane paraffins, found in petroleum, consisting oftwo propyl radicals. See Hexane.
divi-divi: A small tree of tropical America (Cæsalpinia coriaria), whoselegumes contain a large proportion of tannic and gallic acid, and areused by tanners and dyers.
dulciana: A sweet-toned stop of an organ.
disinthrall: To free from thralldom; to disenthrall. [Written alsodisinthral.]
daira: Any of several valuable estates of the Egyptian khedive or hisfamily. The most important are the Da"i*ra Sa"ni*eh, or Sa"ni*yeh,and the Da"i*ra Khas"sa, administered by the khedive's Europeanbondholders, and known collectively as the Daira, or the Dairaestates.
datolite: A borosilicate of lime commonly occuring in glassy,, greenishcrystals. [Written also datholite.]
dove: A pigeon of the genus Columba and various related genera. Thespecies are numerous.
dorsibranchiata: A division of chætopod annelids in which the branchiæ are alongthe back, on each side, or on the parapodia. [See Illusts. underAnnelida and Chætopoda.]
damaskin: A sword of Damask steel.No old Toledo blades or damaskins. Howell
drip: To let fall in drops.Which from the thatch drips fast a shower of rain. Swift.
demolition: The act of overthrowing, pulling down, or destroying a pile orstructure; destruction by violence; utter overthrow; -- opposed toconstruction; as, the demolition of a house, of military works, of atown, or of hopes.
dividing: That divides; separating; marking divisions; graduating.Dividing engine, a machine for graduating circles (as forastronomical instruments) or bars (as for scales); also, for spacingoff and cutting teeth in wheels.-- Dividing sinker. (Knitting Mach.). See under Sinker.
dendrolite: A petrified or fossil shrub, plant, or part of a plant.
disprejudice: To free from prejudice. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
double-entendre: A word or expression admitting of a double interpretation, oneof which is often obscure or indelicate.
delapse: To pass down by inheritance; to lapse. [Obs.]Which Anne derived alone the right, before all other, Of the delapsedcrown from Philip. Drayton.
disenroll: To erase from a roll or list. [Written also disenrol.] Donne.
deergrass: An American genus (Rhexia) of perennial herbs, with oppositeleaves, and showy flowers (usually bright purple), with four petalsand eight stamens, -- the only genus of the order Melastomaceæinhabiting a temperate clime.
duressor: One who subjects another to duress Bacon.
diesis: A small interval, less than any in actual practice, but used inthe mathematical calculation of intervals.
discophora: A division of acalephs or jellyfishes, including most of thelarge disklike species.-- Dis*coph"o*rous, a.
decemvirship: The office of a decemvir. Holland.
demogorgon: , A mysterious, terrible, and evil divinity, regarded by someas the author of creation, by others as a great magician who wassupposed to command the spirits of the lower world. See Gorgon.Orcus and Ades, and the dreaded name Of Demogorgon. Milton.
destitution: The state of being deprived of anything; the state or conditionof being destitute, needy, or without resources; deficiency; lack;extreme poverty; utter want; as, the inundation caused generaldestitution.
dowerless: Destitute of dower; having no marriage portion. Shak.
dissatisfactory: Causing dissatisfaction; unable to give content;unsatisfactory; displeasing.To have reduced the different qualifications in the different Statesto one uniform rule, would probably have been as dissatisfactory tosome of the States, as difficult for the Convention. A. Hamilton.-- Dis*sat`is*fac"to*ri*ness, n.
defectibility: Deficiency; imperfection. [R.] Ld. Digby. Jer. Taylor.
disciplinableness: The quality of being improvable by discipline. Sir M. Hale.
downstairs: Down the stairs; to a lower floor.-- a.
dasewe: To become dim-sighted; to become dazed or dazzled. [Obs.]Chauscer.
disgraceful: Bringing disgrace; causing shame; shameful; dishonorable;unbecoming; as, profaneness is disgraceful to a man.-- Dis*grace"ful*fy, adv.-- Dis*grace"ful*ness, n.The Senate have cast you forth disgracefully. B. Jonson.
dispositively: In a dispositive manner; by natural or moral disposition.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.Do dispositively what Moses is recorded to have done literally, . . .break all the ten commandments at once. Boyle.
discriminatively: With discrimination or distinction. J. Foster.
descendibility: The quality of being descendible; capability of beingtransmitted from ancestors; as, the descendibility of an estate.
detour: A turning; a circuitous route; a deviation from a directcourse; as, the detours of the Mississippi.
dory: A European fish. See Doree, and John Doree.
decistere: The tenth part of the stere or cubic meter, equal to 3.531cubic feet. See Stere.
dogsick: Sick as a dog sometimes is very sick. [Colloq.]
detract: To take away a part or something, especially from one's credit;to lessen reputation; to derogate; to defame; -- often with from.It has been the fashion to detract both from the moral and literarycharacter of Cicero. V. Knox.
dengue: A specific epidemic disease attended with high fever, cutaneouseruption, and severe pains in the head and limbs, resembling those ofrheumatism; -- called also breakbone fever. It occurs in India,Egypt, the West Indies, etc., is of short duration, and rarely fatal.
die: To disappear gradually in another surface, as where moldingsare lost in a sloped or curved face.
disputer: One who disputes, or who is given to disputes; a controvertist.Where is the disputer of this world 1 Cor. i. 20.
dispeopler: One who, or that which, dispeoples; a depopulator. Gay.
disyoke: To unyoke; to free from a yoke; to disjoin. [Poetic] R.Browning.
diseased: Afflicted with disease.It is my own diseased imagination that torments me. W. Irving.
dejecture: That which is voided; excrements. Arbuthnot.
dry-eyed: Not having tears in the eyes.
dissension: Disagreement in opinion, usually of a violent character,producing warm debates or angry words; contention in words; partisanand contentious divisions; breach of friendship and union; strife;discord; quarrel.Paul and Barnabas had no small dissension and disputation with them.Acts xv. 2.Debates, dissension, uproars are thy joy. Dryden.A seditious person and raiser-up of dissension among the people.Robynson (More's Utopia).
dyad: An element, atom, or radical having a valence or combiningpower of two.
doloroso: Plaintive; pathetic; -- used adverbially as a musicaldirection.
dentation: Formation of teeth; toothed form. [R.]How did it [a bill] get its barb, its dentation Paley.
dejeration: The act of swearing solemnly. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
divertissement: A short ballet, or other entertainment, between the acts of aplay. Smart.
dozy: Drowsy; inclined to doze; sleepy; sluggish; as, a dozy head.Dryden.
dreamily: As if in a dream; softly; slowly; languidly. Longfellow.
dauk: See Dawk, v. t., to cut or gush.
deafen: To render impervious to sound, as a partition or floor, byfilling the space within with mortar, by lining with paper, etc.
denticete: The division of Cetacea in which the teeth are developed,including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.
desecration: The act of desecrating; profanation; condition of anythingdesecrated.
dirgeful: Funereal; moaning.Soothed sadly by the dirgeful wind. Coleridge.
digging: Places where ore is dug; especially, certain localities inCalifornia, Australia, and elsewhere, at which gold is obtained.[Recent]
durukuli: A small, nocturnal, South American monkey (Nyctipthecustrivirgatus). [Written also douroucouli.]
dullish: Somewhat dull; uninteresting; tiresome. "A series of dullishverses." Prof. Wilson.
diswarn: To dissuade from by previous warning. [Obs.]
dewrot: To rot, as flax or hemp, by exposure to rain, dew, and sun. SeeDewretting.
dossil: A small ovoid or cylindrical roil or pledget of lint, forkeeping a sore, wound, etc., open; a tent.
diaphaneity: The quality of being diaphanous; transparency; pellucidness.
discard: To throw out of one's hand, as superfluous cards; to lay aside(a card or cards).
dodge: The act of evading by some skillful movement; a sudden startingaside; hence, an artful device to evade, deceive, or cheat; a cunningtrick; an artifice. [Colloq.]Some, who have a taste for good living, have many harmless arts, bywhich they improve their banquet, and innocent dodges, if we may bepermitted to use an excellent phrase that has become vernacular sincethe appearance of the last dictionaries. Thackeray.
delighting: Giving delight; gladdening.-- De*light"ing*ly, adv. Jer. Taylor.
dejected: Cast down; afflicted; low-spirited; sad; as, a dejected look orcountenance.-- De*ject"ed*ly, adv.-- De*ject"ed*ness, n.
decimal: Of or pertaining to decimals; numbered or proceeding by tens;having a tenfold increase or decrease, each unit being ten times theunit next smaller; as, decimal notation; a decimal coinage. Decimalarithmetic, the common arithmetic, in which numeration proceeds bytens.-- Decimal fraction, a fraction in which the denominator is somepower of 10, as -- Decimal point, a dot or full stop at the left of adecimal fraction. The figures at the left of the point representunits or whole numbers, as 1.05.
delineator: A perambulator which records distances and delineates aprofile, as of a road.
discoverable: Capable of being discovered, found out, or perceived; as, manyminute animals are discoverable only by the help of the microscope;truths discoverable by human industry.
dudeen: A short tobacco pipe. [Written also dudheen.] [Irish]
dandelion: A well-known plant of the genus Taraxacum (T. officinale,formerly called T. Dens-leonis and Leontodos Taraxacum) bearinglarge, yellow, compound flowers, and deeply notched leaves.
diureticalness: The quality of being diuretical; diuretic property.
demilance: A light lance; a short spear; a half pike; also, a demilancer.
dearborn: A four-wheeled carriage, with curtained sides.
disseizin: The act of disseizing; an unlawful dispossessing and ouster ofa person actually seized of the freehold. [Written also disseisin.]Blackstone.
diffarreation: A form of divorce, among the ancient Romans, in which a cakewas used. See Confarreation.
disulphide: A binary compound of sulphur containing two atoms of sulphur ineach molecule; -- formerly called disulphuret. Cf. Bisulphide.
disclame: To disclaim; to expel. [Obs.] "Money did love disclame."Spenser.
denotable: Capable of being denoted or marked. Sir T. Browne.
drupe: A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp,without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarpis succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry andsubcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
despite: To vex; to annoy; to offend contemptuously. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.
discontinuor: One who deprives another of the possession of an estate bydiscontinuance. See Discontinuance, 2.
dry-rub: To rub and cleanse without wetting. Dodsley.
drake: The drake fly.The drake will mount steeple height into the air. Walton.Drake fly, a kind of fly, sometimes used in angling.The dark drake fly, good in August. Walton.
diaconate: The office of a deacon; deaconship; also, a body or board ofdeacons.
detrimental: Causing detriment; injurious; hurtful.Neither dangerous nor detrimental to the donor. Addison.
deflectionization: The act of freeing from inflections. Earle.
degravation: The act of making heavy. [Obs.] Bailey.
diffract: To break or separate into parts; to deflect, or decompose bydeflection, a
doctorly: Like a doctor or learned man. [Obs.] "Doctorly prelates." Foxe.
deficient: Wanting, to make up completeness; wanting, as regards arequirement; not sufficient; inadequate; defective; imperfect;incomplete; lacking; as, deficient parts; deficient estate; deficientstrength; deficient in judgment.The style was indeed deficient in ease and variety. Macaulay.Deficient number. (Arith.) See under Abundant.-- De*fi"cient-ly, adv.
diplomatist: A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.In ability, Avaux had no superior among the numerous able diplomaticswhom his country then possessed. Macaulay.
decrepit: Broken down with age; wasted and enfeebled by the infirmitiesof old age; feeble; worn out. "Beggary or decrepit age." Milton.Already decrepit with premature old age. Motley.
darwinian: Pertaining to Darwin; as, the Darwinian theory, a theory of themanner and cause of the supposed development of living things fromcertain original forms or elements.
demonomagy: Magic in which the aid of demons is invoked; black or infernalmagic. Bp. Hurd.
drynurse: To feed, attend, and bring up without the breast. Hudibras.
damnific: Procuring or causing loss; mischievous; injurious.
dishful: As much as a dish holds when full.
devanagari: The character in which Sanskrit is written.
diapophysis: The dorsal transverse, or tubercular, process of a vertebra.See Vertebra.
disarrange: To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; tothrow out of order.
dissyllabize: To form into two syllables; to dyssyllabify.
division: The process of finding how many times one number or quantity iscontained in another; the reverse of multiplication; also, the ruleby which the operation is performed.
dustman: One whose employment is to remove dirt and defuse. Gay.
danewort: A fetid European species of elder (Sambucus Ebulus); dwarfelder; wallwort; elderwort; -- called also Daneweed, Dane's weed, andDane's-blood.
dernier: Last; final. Dernier ressort ( Etym: [F.], last resort orexpedient.
downlying: The time of retiring to rest; time of repose. Cavendish. At thedownlying, at the travail in childbirth. [Scot.]
demolish: To throw or pull down; to raze; to destroy the fabric of; topull to pieces; to ruin; as, to demolish an edifice, or a wall.I expected the fabric of my book would long since have beendemolished, and laid even with the ground. Tillotson.
dialogue: To take part in a dialogue; to dialogize. [R.] Shak.
dannebrog: The ancient battle standard of Denmark, bearing figures ofcross and crown. Order of Dannebrog, an ancient Danish order ofknighthood.
dephase: To put out of phase, as two parts of a single alternatingcurrent.
dimissory: Sending away; dismissing to another jurisdiction; grantingleave to depart. Letters dimissory (Eccl.), letters given by a bishopdismissing a person who is removing into another diocese, andrecommending him for reception there. Hook.
decreasing: Becoming less and less; diminishing.-- De*creas"ing*ly, adv. Decreasing series (Math.), a series inwhich each term is numerically smaller than the preceding term.
dermatophyte: A vegetable parasite, infesting the skin.
discord: Union of musical sounds which strikes the ear harshly ordisagreeably, owing to the incommensurability of the vibrations whichthey produce; want of musical concord or harmony; a chord demandingresolution into a concord.For a discord itself is but a harshness of divers sounds mBacon.Apple of discord. See under Apple.
drier: Drying oil; a substance mingled with the oil used in oilpainting to make it dry quickly.
dress goods: A term applied to fabrics for the gowns of women and girls; --most commonly to fabrics of mixed materials, but also applicable tosilks, printed linens, and calicoes.
drawee: The person on whom an order or bill of exchange is drawn; --the correlative of drawer.
diplocardiac: Having the heart completely divided or double, one sidesystemic, the other pulmonary.
disme: A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe. Ayliffe.
dexterousness: The quality of being dexterous; dexterity.
distrusting: That distrusts; suspicious; lacking confidence in.-- Dis*trust"ing*ly, adv.
defensor: A defender or an advocate in court; a guardian or protector.
deuterocanonical: Pertaining to a second canon, or ecclesiastical writing ofinferior authority; -- said of the Apocrypha, certain Epistles, etc.
disproportionality: The state of being disproportional. Dr. H. More.
decorticate: To divest of the bark, husk, or exterior coating; to husk; topeel; to hull. "Great barley dried and decorticated." Arbuthnot.
demonologer: One versed in demonology. R. North.
demilune: A work constructed beyond the main ditch of a fortress, and infront of the curtain between two bastions, intended to defend thecurtain; a ravelin. See Ravelin.
defiler: One who defiles; one who corrupts or violates; that whichpollutes.
dedition: The act of yielding; surrender. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
do-little: One who performs little though professing much. [Colloq.]Great talkers are commonly dolittles. Bp. Richardson.
disinterest: Disinterested. [Obs.]The measures they shall walk by shall be disinterest and even. Jer.Taylor.
defatigable: Capable of being wearied or tired out. [R.] Glanvill.
dovetail: A flaring tenon, or tongue (shaped like a bird's tail spread),and a mortise, or socket, into which it fits tightly, making aninterlocking joint between two pieces which resists pulling a part inall directions except one. Dovetail molding (Arch.), a molding of anyconvex section arranged in a sort of zigzag, like a series ofdovetails.-- Dovetail saw (Carp.), a saw used in dovetailing.
dogbane: A small genus of perennial herbaceous plants, with poisonousmilky juice, bearing slender pods pods in pairs.
decortication: The act of stripping off the bark, rind, hull, or outer coat.
disrealize: To divest of reality; to make uncertain. [Obs.] Udall.
destructible: Liable to destruction; capable of being destroyed.
dowable: Capable of being endowed; entitled to dower. Blackstone.
dismaw: To eject from the maw; to disgorge. [R.] Shelton.
dioeciously: In a dioecious manner. Dioeciously hermaphrodite (Bot.), havingflowers structurally perfect, but practically dioecious, -- those onone plant producing no pollen, and those on another no ovules.
dumple: To make dumpy; to fold, or bend, as one part over another. [R.]He was a little man, dumpled up together. Sir W. Scott.
distringas: A writ commanding the sheriff to distrain a person by his goodsor chattels, to compel a compliance with something required of him.
dendrocoela: A division of the Turbellaria in which the digestive cavitygives off lateral branches, which are often divided into smallerbranchlets.
dovelike: Mild as a dove; gentle; pure and lovable. Longfellow.
dashism: The character of making ostentatious or blustering parade orshow. [R. & Colloq.]He must fight a duel before his claim to . . . dashism can beuniversally allowed. V. Knox.
devexity: A bending downward; a sloping; incurvation downward; declivity.[R.] Davies (Wit's Pilgr.)
dungmeer: A pit where dung and weeds rot for manure.
declinometer: An instrument for measuring the declination of the magneticneedle.
deblai: The cavity from which the earth for parapets, etc. (remblai),is taken.
dress circle: A gallery or circle in a theater, generally the first above thefloor, in which originally dress clothes were customarily worn.
detach: To push asunder; to come off or separate from anything; todisengage.[A vapor] detaching, fold by fold, From those still heights.Tennyson.
dissenterism: The spirit or principles of dissenters. Ed. Rev.
dispensatorily: In the way of dispensation; dispensatively.
dissolubleness: The quality of being dissoluble; dissolubility. Boyle.
disparition: Act of disappearing; disappearance. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
discumbency: The act of reclining at table according to the manner of theancients at their meals. Sir T. Browne.
dismount: To take down, or apart, as a machine.
disgradation: Degradation; a stripping of titles and honors.
ducally: In the manner of a duke, or in a manner becoming the rank of aduke.
dhow: A coasting vessel of Arabia, East Africa, and the Indian Ocean.It has generally but one mast and a lateen sail. [Also written dow.]
dreg: Corrupt or defiling matter contained in a liquid, orprecipitated from it; refuse; feculence; lees; grounds; sediment;hence, the vilest and most worthless part of anything; as, the dregsof society.We, the dregs and rubbish of mankind. Dryden.
deprivable: Capable of being, or liable to be, deprived; liable to bedeposed.Kings of Spain . . . deprivable for their tyrannies. Prynne.
duomo: A cathedral. See Dome, 2.Of tower or duomo, sunny sweet. Tennyson.
doss: A place to sleep in; a bed; hence, sleep. [Slang]
draconian: Pertaining to Draco, a famous lawgiver of Athens, 621 b. c.Draconian code, or Draconian laws, a code of laws made by Draco.Their measures were so severe that they were said to be written inletters of blood; hence, any laws of excessive rigor.
dade: To hold up by leading strings or by the hand, as a child whilehe toddles. [Obs.]Little children when they learn to go By painful mothers daded to andfro. Drayton.
dermatologist: One who discourses on the skin and its diseases; one versed indermatology.
dramaturgy: The art of dramatic composition and representation.
difficile: Difficult; hard to manage; stubborn. [Obs.] --Dif"fi*cile*ness, n. [Obs.] Bacon.
durham: One or a breed of short-horned cattle, originating in thecounty of Durham, England. The Durham cattle are noted for theirbeef-producing quality.
distributary: Tending to distribute or be distributed; that distributes;distributive.
derogatory: Tending to derogate, or lessen in value; expressing derogation;detracting; injurious; -- with from to, or unto.Acts of Parliament derogatory from the power of subsequentParliaments bind not. Blackstone.His language was severely censured by some of his brother peers asderogatory to their other. Macaulay.Derogatory clause in a testament (Law), a sentence of secretcharacter inserted by the testator alone, of which he reserves theknowledge to himself, with a condition that no will he may makethereafter shall be valid, unless this clause is inserted word forword; -- a precaution to guard against later wills extorted byviolence, or obtained by suggestion.
dyas: A name applied in Germany to the Permian formation, thereconsisting of two principal groups.
diphenyl: A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leadingbenzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene orphenyl radicals united.
doubloon: A Spanish gold coin, no longer issued, varying in value atdifferent times from over fifteen dollars to about five. See Doblonin Sup.
decolor: To deprive of color; to bleach.
desiccate: To dry up; to deprive or exhaust of moisture; to preserve bydrying; as, to desiccate fish or fruit.Bodies desiccated by heat or age. Bacon.
disrobe: To divest of a robe; to undress; figuratively, to strip ofcovering; to divest of that which clothes or decorates; as, autumndisrobes the fields of verdure.Two great peers were disrobed of their glory. Sir H. Wotton.
duality: The quality or condition of being two or twofold; dualcharacter or usage.
dwang: A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffenand support them.
diestock: A stock to hold the dies used for cutting screws.
discrete: Separate; not coalescent; -- said of things usually coalescent.Discrete movement. See Concrete movement of the voice, underConcrete, a.-- Discrete proportion, proportion where the ratio of the means isdifferent from that of either couplet; as, 3:6::8:16, 3 bearing thesame proportion to 6 as 8 does to 16. But 3 is not to 6 as 6 to 8. Itis thus opposed to continued or continual proportion; as, 3:6::12:24.-- Discrete quantity, that which must be divided into units, asnumber, and is opposed to continued quantity, as duration, orextension.
detrimentalness: The quality of being detrimental; injuriousness.
deskwork: Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer. Tennyson.
demirep: A woman of doubtful reputation or suspected character; anadventuress. [Colloq.] De Quincey.
devisor: One who devises, or gives real estate by will; a testator; --correlative to devisee.
dreamy: Abounding in dreams or given to dreaming; appropriate to, orlike, dreams; visionary. "The dreamy dells." Tennyson.
dysteleology: The doctrine of purposelessness; a term applied by Haeckel tothat branch of physiology which treats of rudimentary organs, in viewof their being useless to the life of the organism.To the doctrine of dysteleology, or the denial of final causes, aproof of the real existence of such a thing as instinct mustnecessarily be fatal. Word (Dynamic Sociology).
deplete: To empty or unload, as the vessels of human system, bybloodletting or by medicine. Copland.
dimity: A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings,and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns,both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
detumescence: Diminution of swelling; subsidence of anything swollen. [R.]Cudworth.
dichotomous: Regularly dividing by pairs from bottom to top; as, adichotomous stem.-- Di*chot"o*mous*ly, adv.
diagnosis: The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from itssigns or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, thedecision arrived at.
dueling: e act or practice of fighting in single combat. Also adj.[Written also duelling.]
dizzily: In a dizzy manner or state.
desitive: Final; serving to complete; conclusive. [Obs.] "Desitivepropositions." I. Watts.
dogwood: The Cornus, a genus of large shrubs or small trees, the wood ofwhich is exceedingly hard, and serviceable for many purposes.
driftpiece: An upright or curved piece of timber connecting the plank sheerwith the gunwale; also, a scroll terminating a rail.
debenture stock: The debt or series of debts, collectively, represented by aseries of debentures; a debt secured by a trust deed of property forthe benefit of the holders of shares in the debt or of a series ofdebentures. By the terms of much debenture stock the holders are notentitled to demand payment until the winding up of the company ordefault in payment; in the winding up of the company or default inpayment; in the case of railway debentures, they cannot demandpayment of the principal, and the debtor company cannot redeem thestock, except by authority of an act of Parliament. [Eng.]
disboscation: Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal ofa forest. Sir W. Scott.
dribber: One who dribs; one who shoots weakly or badly. [Obs.] Ascham.
dormouse: A small European rodent of the genus Myoxus, of severalspecies. They live in trees and feed on nuts, acorns, etc.; -- socalled because they are usually torpid in winter.
dichromate: A salt of chromic acid containing two equivalents of the acidradical to one of the base; -- called also bichromate.
decennial: Consisting of ten years; happening every ten years; as, adecennial period; decennial games. Hallam.
dogsleep: The fitful naps taken when all hands are kept up by stress.
difform: Irregular in form; -- opposed to uniform; anomalous; hence,unlike; dissimilar; as, to difform corolla, the parts of which do notcorrespond in size or proportion; difform leaves.The unequal refractions of difform rays. Sir I. Newton.
deprehensible: That may be caught or discovered; apprehensible. [Obs.] Petty.-- Dep`re*hen"si*ble*ness, n. [Obs.]
dogger: A two-masted fishing vessel, used by the Dutch.
doughfaceism: The character of a doughface; truckling pliability.
diglyph: A projecting face like the triglyph, but having only twochannels or grooves sunk in it.
depopulation: The act of depopulating, or condition of being depopulated;destruction or explusion of inhabitants.The desolation and depopulation [of St.Quentin] were now complete.Motley.
dilater: One who, or that which, dilates, expands, o r enlarges.
disunity: A state of separation or disunion; want of unity. Dr. H. More.
dram: A Persian daric. Ezra ii. 69. Fluid dram, or Fluid drachm. Seeunder Fluid.
dicotyledon: A plant whose seeds divide into two seed lobes, or cotyledons,in germinating.
durably: In a lasting manner; with long continuance.
discontinuer: One who discontinues, or breaks off or away from; an absentee.He was no gadder abroad, not discontinuer from his convent for a longtime. Fuller.
diurnation: The condition of sleeping or becoming dormant by day, as is thecase of the bats.
degraded: Having the typical characters or organs in a partiallydeveloped condition, or lacking certain parts.Some families of plants are degraded dicotyledons. Dana.
dihedral: Having two plane faces; as, the dihedral summit of a crystal.Dihedral angle, the angular space contained between planes whichintersect. It is measured by the angle made by any two lines at rightangles to the two planes.
dedicator: One who dedicates; more especially, one who inscribes a book tothe favor of a patron, or to one whom he desires to compliment.
driveler: A slaverer; a slabberer; an idiot; a fool. [Written alsodriveller.]
diminutival: Indicating diminution; diminutive. "Diminutival forms" [ofwords]. Earle.-- n.
darbies: Manacles; handcuffs. [Cant]Jem Clink will fetch you the darbies. Sir W. Scott.
dele: Erase; remove; -- a direction to cancel something which hasbeen put in type; usually expressed by a peculiar form of d, thus: .
duffel: A kind of coarse woolen cloth, having a thick nap or frieze.[Written also duffle.]Good duffel gray and flannel fine. Wordsworth.
droughtiness: A state of dryness of the weather; want of rain.
dextrin: A translucent, gummy, amorphous substance, nearly tasteless andodorless, used as a substitute for gum, for sizing, etc., andobtained from starch by the action of heat, acids, or diastase. It isof somewhat variable composition, containing several carbohydrateswhich change easily to their respective varieties of sugar. It is sonamed from its rotating the plane of polarization to the right; --called also British gum, Alsace gum, gommelin, leiocome, etc. SeeAchroödextrin, and Erythrodextrin.
danaide: A water wheel having a vertical axis, and an inner and outertapering shell, between which are vanes or floats attached usually toboth shells, but sometimes only to one.
deportation: The act of deporting or exiling, or the state of beingdeported; banishment; transportation.In their deportations, they had often the favor of their conquerors.Atterbury.
demurely: In a demure manner; soberly; gravely; -- now, commonly, with amere show of gravity or modesty.They . . . looked as demurely as they could; for 't was a hangingmatter to laugh unseasonably. Dryden.
dinnerly: Of or pertaining to dinner. [R.]The dinnerly officer. Copley.
diduction: The act of drawing apart; separation.
dagswain: Acoarse woolen fabric made of daglocks, or the refuse of wool."Under coverlets made of dagswain." Holinshed.
daboia: A large and highly venomous Asiatic viper (Daboia xanthica).
disreputation: Loss or want of reputation or good name; dishonor; disrepute;disesteem. "A disreputation of piety." Jer. Taylor.
driftweed: Seaweed drifted to the shore by the wind. Darwin.
de bene esse: Of well being; of formal sufficiency for the time;conditionally; provisionally. Abbott.
defacer: One who, or that which, defaces or disfigures.
domestic: Articles of home manufacture, especially cotton goods. [U. S.]
divorcement: Dissolution of the marriage tie; divorce; separation.Let him write her a divorcement. Deut. xxiv. 1.The divorcement of our written from our spoken language. R. Morris.
dysluite: A variety of the zinc spinel or gahnite.
delinquent: Failing in duty; offending by neglect of duty.
divertive: Tending to divert; diverting; amusing; interesting.Things of a pleasant and divertive nature. Rogers.
dilapidation: The pulling down of a building, or suffering it to fall or bein a state of decay. Burrill.
derogatorily: In a derogatory manner; disparagingly. Aubrey.
declarator: A form of action by which some right or interest is sought tobe judicially declared.
disintegrable: Capable of being disintegrated, or reduced to fragments orpowder.Argillo-calcite is readily disintegrable by exposure. Kirwan.
discrepant: Discordant; at variance; disagreeing; contrary; different.The Egyptians were . . . the most oddly discrepant from the rest intheir manner of worship. Cudworth.
doldrums: A part of the ocean near the equator, abounding in calms,squalls, and light, baffling winds, which sometimes prevent allprogress for weeks; -- so called by sailors. To be in the doldrums,to be in a state of listlessness ennui, or tedium.
damage feasant: Doing injury; trespassing, as cattle. Blackstone.
dihedron: A figure with two sides or surfaces. Buchanan.
deputize: To appoint as one's deputy; to empower to act in one's stead;to depute.
disprovable: Capable of being disproved or refuted. Boyle.
duration: The state or quality of lasting; continuance in time; theportion of time during which anything exists.It was proposed that the duration of Parliament should be limited.Macaulay.Soon shall have passed our own human duration. D. Webster.
deceitful: Full of, or characterized by, deceit; serving to mislead orinsnare; trickish; fraudulent; cheating; insincere.Harboring foul deceitful thoughts. Shak.
dentiphone: An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound tothe auditory nerve; an audiphone. Knight.
disseizee: A person disseized, or put out of possession of an estateunlawfully; -- correlative to disseizor. [Written also disseisee.]
desman: An amphibious, insectivorous mammal found in Russia (Myogalemoschata). It is allied to the moles, but is called muscrat by someEnglish writers. [Written also dæsman.]
decivilize: To reduce from civilization to a savage state. [R.] Blackwood'sMag.
disadvantage: To injure the interest of; to be detrimental to.
dentil: A small square block or projection in cornices, a number ofwhich are ranged in an ornamental band; -- used particularly in theIonic, Corinthian, and Composite orders.
docetae: Ancient heretics who held that Christ's body was merely aphantom or appearance.
disembroil: To disentangle; to free from perplexity; to extricate fromconfusion.Vaillant has disembroiled a history that was lost to the world beforehis time. Addison.
dinornis: A genus of extinct, ostrichlike birds of gigantic size, whichformerly inhabited New Zealand. See Moa. [Written also Deinornis.]
danseuse: a professional female dancer; a woman who dances at a publicexhibition as in a ballet.
ditty-box: A small box to hold a sailor's thread, needless, comb, etc.
delamination: Formation and separation of laminæ or layers; one of themethods by which the various blastodermic layers of the ovum aredifferentiated.
demur: To interpose a demurrer. See Demurrer, 2.
defeasanced: Liable to defeasance; capable of being made void or forfeited.
digital: Of or performance to the fingers, or to digits; done with thefingers; as, digital compression; digital examination.
doxology: In Christian worship: A hymn expressing praise and honor toGod; a form of praise to God designed to be sung or chanted by thechoir or the congregation.David breaks forth into these triumphant praises and doxologies.South.
develop: To change the form of, as of an algebraic expression, byexecuting certain indicated operations without changing the value.
desiccation: The act of desiccating, or the state of being desiccated.
drubber: One who drubs. Sir W. Scott.
denominate: To give a name to; to characterize by an epithet; to entitle;to name; to designate.Passions commonly denominating selfish. Hume.
decayed: Fallen, as to physical or social condition; affected withdecay; rotten; as, decayed vegetation or vegetables; a decayedfortune or gentleman.-- De*cay"ed*ness, n.
deodorizer: He who, or that which, deodorizes; esp., an agent that destroysoffensive odors.
daglock: A dirty or clotted lock of wool on a sheep; a taglock.
davidic: Of or pertaining to David, the king and psalmist of Israel, orto his family.
dysuric: Pertaining to, or afflicted with, dysury.
dirigible: Capable of being directed; steerable; as, a dirigible balloon.
decitizenize: To deprive of the rights of citizenship. [R.]We have no law -- as the French have -- to decitizenize a citizen.Edw. Bates.
dioxindol: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance obtained by thereduction of isatin. It is a member of the indol series; -- hence itsname.
diverging: Tending in different directions from a common center; spreadingapart; divergent. Diverging series (Math.), a series whose terms arelarger as the series is extended; a series the sum of whose termsdoes not approach a finite limit when the series is extendedindefinitely; -- opposed to a converging series.
disruptive: Causing, or tending to cause, disruption; caused by disruption;breaking through; bursting; as, the disruptive discharge of anelectrical battery. Nichol.
dyewood: Any wood from which coloring matter is extracted for dyeing.
dentiloquy: The habit or practice of speaking through the teeth, or withthem closed.
descent: Transmission of an estate by inheritance, usually, but notnecessarily, in the descending line; title to inherit an estate byreason of consanguinity. Abbott.
double-eyed: Having a deceitful look. [R.] "Deceitful meanings is double-eyed." Spenser.
ditch: To dig a ditch or ditches. Swift.
dow: A kind of vessel. See Dhow.
delawares: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the valley of theDelaware River, but now mostly located in the Indian Territory.
daintily: In a dainty manner; nicely; scrupulously; fastidiously;deliciously; prettily.
dishevele: Disheveled. [Obs.]Dishevele, save his cap, he rode all bare. Chaucer.
donator: One who makes a gift; a donor; a giver.
distantial: Distant. [Obs.]More distantial from the eye. W. Montagu.
domical: Relating to, or shaped like, a dome.
daphnomancy: Divination by means of the laurel.
denture: An artificial tooth, block, or set of teeth.
dwale: The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefyingqualities.
ductible: Capable of being drawn out [R.] Feltham.
diffusate: Material which, in the process of catalysis, has diffused orpassed through the separating membrane.
doubtless: Free from fear or suspicion. [Obs.]Pretty child, sleep doubtless and secure. Shak.
devocalize: To make toneless; to deprive of vowel quality.-- De*vo`cal*i*za"tion, n.If we take a high vowel, such as (i) [= nearly i of bit], anddevocalize it, we obtain a hiss which is quite distinct enough tostand for a weak (jh). H. Sweet.
distend: To become expanded or inflated; to swell. "His heart distendswith pride." Milton.
decease: Departure, especially departure from this life; death.His decease, which he should accomplish at Jerusalem. Luke ix. 31.And I, the whilst you mourn for his decease, Will with my mourningplaints your plaint increase. Spenser.
dunfish: Codfish cured in a particular manner, so as to be of a superiorquality.
drib: To do by little and little; as:(a) To cut off by a little at a time; to crop.(b) To appropriate unlawfully; to filch; to defalcate.He who drives their bargain dribs a part. Dryden.
dodecahedral: Pertaining to, or like, a dodecahedion; consisting of twelveequal sides. Dodecahedral cleavage. See under Cleavage.
dibble: A pointed implement used to make holes in the ground in whichno set out plants or to plant seeds.
durbar: An audience hall; the court of a native prince; a state levee;a formal reception of native princes, given by the governor generalof India. [India] [Written also darbar.]
doggerel: Low in style, and irregular in measure; as, doggerel rhymes.This may well be rhyme doggerel, quod he. Chaucer.
dry-boned: Having dry bones, or bones without flesh.
dictatress: A woman who dictates or commands.Earth's chief dictatress, ocean's mighty queen. Byron.
dialogical: Relating to a dialogue; dialogistical. Burton.
dynamometry: The art or process of measuring forces doing work.
defeatured: Changed in features; deformed. [R.]Features when defeatured in the . . . way I have described. DeQuincey.
despairing: Feeling or expressing despair; hopeless.-- De*spair"ing*ly, adv.-- De*spair"ing*ness, n.
derivable: That can be derived; obtainable by transmission; capable ofbeing known by inference, as from premises or data; capable of beingtraced, as from a radical; as, income is derivable from varioussources.All honor derivable upon me.
