South.The exquisite pleasure derivable from the true and beautifulrelations of domestic life. H. G. Bell.The argument derivable from the doxologies. J. H. Newman.
dravida: A race Hindostan, believed to be the original people whooccupied the land before the Hindoo or Aryan invasion.
differentia: The formal or distinguishing part of the essence of a species;the characteristic attribute of a species; specific difference.
degradation: A gradual wearing down or wasting, as of rocks and banks, bythe action of water, fro
detortion: The act of detorting, or the state of being detorted; atwisting or warping.
drench: A drink; a draught; specifically, a potion of medicine pouredor forced down the throat; also, a potion that causes purging. "Adrench of wine." Dryden.Give my roan horse a drench. Shak.
dysgenesis: A condition of not generating or breeding freely; infertility;a form homogenesis in which the hybrids are sterile among themselves,but are fertile with members of either parent race.
downhill: Towards the bottom of a hill; as, water runs downhill.
distraint: The act or proceeding of seizing personal property by distress.Abbott.
downcast: Cast downward; directed to the ground, from bashfulness,modesty, dejection, or guilt.'T is love, said she; and then my downcast eyes, And guilty dumbness,witnessed my surprise. Dryden.- Down"cast`ly, adv.-- Down"cast`ness, n.
diagraph: A drawing instrument, combining a protractor and scale.
diesinker: An engraver of dies for stamping coins, medals, etc.
duck-legged: Having short legs, like a waddling duck; short-legged. Dryden.
disparage: Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior. [Obs.]Chaucer.Dissuaded her from such a disparage. Spenser.
dooryard: A yard in front of a house or around the door of a house.
depredate: To subject to plunder and pillage; to despoil; to lay waste; toprey upon.It makes the substance of the body . . . less apt to be consumed anddepredated by the spirits. Bacon.
delenda: Things to be erased or blotted out.
decollated: Decapitated; worn or cast off in the process of growth, as theapex of certain univalve shells.
demonianism: The state of being possessed by a demon or by demons.
delacrymation: An involuntary discharge of watery humors from the eyes;wateriness of the eyes. [Obs.] Bailey.
dumbness: The quality or state of being dumb; muteness; silence;inability to speak.
ditto: The aforesaid thing; the same (as before). Often contracted todo., or to two "turned commas" ("), or small marks. Used in bills,books of account, tables of names, etc., to save repetition.A spacious table in the center, and a variety of smaller dittos inthe corners. Dickens.
despicably: In a despicable or mean manner; contemptibly; as, despicablystingy.
demi-tasse: A small cup for, or of, black coffee.
degenerationist: A believer in the theory of degeneration, or hereditarydegradation of type; as, the degenerationists hold that savagery isthe result of degeneration from a superior state.
diagrammatic: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a diagram; showing bydiagram.-- Di`a*gram*mat"ic*ly, adv.
disembossom: To separate from the bosom. [R.] Young.
dowdy: Showing a vulgar taste in dress; awkward and slovenly in dress;vulgar-looking.-- Dow"di*ly, adv.-- Dow"di*ness, n.
dolabriform: Shaped like the head of an ax or hatchet, as some leaves, andalso certain organs of some shellfish.
dullness: The state of being dull; slowness; stupidity; heaviness;drowsiness; bluntness; obtuseness; dimness; want of luster; want ofvividness, or of brightness. [Written also dulness.]And gentle dullness ever loves a joke. Pope.
diamine: A compound containing two amido groups united with one or morebasic or positive radicals, -- as contrasted with a diamide.
disoxygenate: To deprive of oxygen; to deoxidize. [R.]
defender: One who defends; one who maintains, supports, protects, orvindicates; a champion; an advocate; a vindicator.Provinces . . . left without their ancient and puissant defenders.Motley.
dieter: One who diets; one who prescribes, or who partakes of, food,according to hygienic rules.
dithyrambic: Pertaining to, or resembling, a dithyramb; wild and boisterous."Dithyrambic sallies." Longfellow.-- n.
duel: A combat between two persons, fought with deadly weapons, byagreement. It usually arises from an injury done or an affront givenby one to the other. Trial by duel (Old Law), a combat between twopersons for proving a cause; trial by battel.
dolerite: A dark-colored, basic, igneous rock, composed essentially ofpyroxene and a triclinic feldspar with magnetic iron. By many authorsit is considered equivalent to a coarse-grained basalt.
disobedience: Neglect or refusal to obey; violation of a command orprohibition.He is undutiful to him other actions, and lives in open disobedience.Tillotson.
dominate: To predominate over; to rule; to govern. "A city dominated bythe ax." Dickens.We everywhere meet with Slavonian nations either dominant ordominated. W. Tooke.
deteriority: Worse state or quality; inferiority. "The deteriority of thediet." [R.] Ray.
durability: The state or quality of being durable; the power ofuninterrupted or long continuance in any condition; the power ofresisting agents or influences which tend to cause changes, decay, ordissolution; lastingness.A Gothic cathedral raises ideas of grandeur in our minds by the size,its height, . . . its antiquity, and its durability. Blair.
devotional: Pertaining to, suited to, or used in, devotion; as, adevotional posture; devotional exercises; a devotional frame of mind.
dress coat: A coat with skirts behind only, as distinct from the frockcoat, of which the skirts surround the body. It is worn on occasionsof ceremony. The dress coat of officers of the United States army isa full-skirted frock coat.
deoppilation: Removal of whatever stops up the passages. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
defectious: Having defects; imperfect. [Obs.] "Some one defectious piece."Sir P. Sidney.
dubiety: Doubtfulness; uncertainty; doubt. [R.] Lamb. "The dubiety ofhis fate." Sir W. Scott.
disk clutch: A friction clutch in which the gripping surfaces are disks ormore or less resemble disks.
disembarrass: To free from embarrassment, or perplexity; to clear; toextricate.To disembarrass himself of his companion. Sir W. Scott.
dialogist: Pertaining to a dialogue; having the form or nature of adialogue.-- Di*al`o*gis"tic*al*ly, adv.
deterrence: That which deters; a deterrent; a hindrance. [R.]
disconvenient: Not convenient or congruous; unsuitable; ill-adapted. [Obs.]Bp. Reynolds.
dyke: See Dike. The spelling dyke is restricted by some to thegeological meaning.
developable: Capable of being developed. J. Peile. Developable surface(Math.), a surface described by a moving right line, and such thatconsecutive positions of the generator intersect each other. Hence,the surface can be developed into a plane.
deciare: A measure of area, the tenth part of an are; ten square meters.
decad: A decade.Averill was a decad and a half his elder. Tennyson.
diathermanism: The doctrine or the phenomena of the transmission of radiantheat. Nichol.
dyer: One whose occupation is to dye cloth and the like. Dyer'sbroom, Dyer's rocket, Dyer's weed. See Dyer's broom, under Broom.
disjunctive: Pertaining to disjunct tetrachords. "Disjunctive notes." Moore(Encyc. of Music). Disjunctive conjunction (Gram.), one connectinggrammatically two words or clauses, expressing at the same time anopposition or separation inherent in the notions or thoughts; as,either, or, neither, nor, but, although, except, lest, etc.-- Disjunctive proposition, one in which the parts are connected bydisjunctive conjunctions; as it is either day or night.-- Disjunctive syllogism (Logic), one in which the major propositionis disjunctive; as, the earth moves in a circle or an ellipse; but indoes not move in a circle, therefore it moves in an ellipse.
derive: To obtain one substance from another by actual or theoreticalsubstitution; as, to derive an organic acid from its correspondinghydrocarbon.
deflorate: Past the flowering state; having shed its pollen. Gray.
depolarization: The act of depriving of polarity, or the result of such action;reduction to an unpolarized condition. Depolarization of light(Opt.), a change in the plane of polarization of rays, especially bya crystalline medium, such that the light which had been extinguishedby the analyzer reappears as if the polarization had been anulled.The word is inappropriate, as the ray does not return to theunpolarized condition.
damage: The estimated reparation in money for detriment or injurysustained; a compensation, recompense, or satisfaction to one party,for a wrong or injury actually done to him by another.
domeykite: A massive mineral of tin-white or steel-gray color, an arsenideof copper.
debouchure: The outward opening of a river, of a valley, or of a strait.
dynamiter: One who uses dynamite; esp., one who uses it for thedestruction of life and property.
deemster: A judge in the Isle of Man who decides controversies withoutprocess. Cowell.
discipline: The enforcement of methods of correction against one guilty ofecclesiastical offenses; reformatory or penal action toward a churchmember.
dualistic: Consisting of two; pertaining to dualism or duality. Dualisticsystem or theory (Chem.), the theory, originated by Lavoisier anddeveloped by Berzelius, that all definite compounds are binary intheir nature, and consist of two distinct constituents, themselvessimple or complex, and possessed of opposite chemical or electricalaffinities.
dreader: One who fears, or lives in fear.
dicoccous: Composed pf two coherent, one-seeded carpels; as, a dicoccouscapsule.
diactinic: Capable of transmitting the chemical or actinic rays of light;as, diactinic media.
dynastic: Of or relating to a dynasty or line of kings. Motley.
dartoic: Of or pertaining to the dartos.
destinal: Determined by destiny; fated. [Obs.] "The order destinal."Chaucer.
dandie: One of a breed of small terriers; -- called also DandieDinmont.
decussatively: Crosswise; in the form of an X. "Anointed decussatively." SirT. Browne.
devastavit: Waste or misapplication of the assets of a deceased person byan executor or an administrator. Bouvier.
diagnosticate: To make a diagnosis of; to recognize by its symptoms, as adisease.
dull: To become dull or stupid. Rom. of R.
distractedness: A state of being distracted; distraction. Bp. Hall.
diamido-: A prefix or combining form of Diamine.
deathbed: The bed in which a person dies; hence, the closing hours oflife of one who dies by sickness or the like; the last sickness.That often-quoted passage from Lord Hervey in which the Queen'sdeathbed is described. Thackeray.
degree: A certain distance or remove in the line of descent,determining the proximity of blood; one remove in the chain ofrelationship; as, a relation in the third or fourth degree.In the 11th century an opinion began to gain ground in Italy, thatthird cousins might marry, being in the seventh degree according tothe civil law. Hallam.
doornail: The nail or knob on which in ancient doors the knocker struck;-- hence the old saying, "As dead as a doornail."
dwindle: To diminish; to become less; to shrink; to waste or consumeaway; to become degenerate; to fall away.Weary sennights nine times nine Shall he dwindle, peak and pine.Shak.Religious societies, though begun with excellent intentions, are saidto have dwindled into factious clubs. Swift.
deuterogamy: A second marriage, after the death of the first husband ofwife; -- in distinction from bigamy, as defined in the old canon law.See Bigamy. Goldsmith.
dripstone: A drip, when made of stone. See Drip, 2.
drum: An instrument of percussion, consisting either of a hollowcylinder, over each end of which is stretched a piece of skin orvellum, to be beaten with a stick; or of a metallic hemisphere(kettledrum) with a single piece of skin to be so beaten; the commoninstrument for marking time in martial music; one of the pair oftympani in an orchestra, or cavalry band.The drums cry bud-a-dub. Gascoigne.
dodo: A large, extinct bird (Didus ineptus), formerly inhabiting theIsland of Mauritius. It had short, half-fledged wings, like those ofthe ostrich, and a short neck and legs; -- called also dronte. It wasrelated to the pigeons.
despumate: To throw off impurities in spume; to work off in foam or scum;to foam.
disengaging: Loosing; setting free; detaching. Disengaging machinery. Seeunder Engaging.
demarcate: To mark by bounds; to set the limits of; to separate; todiscriminate. Wilkinson.
deadhead: A buoy. See under Dead, a.
disquisitory: Of or pertaining to disquisition; disquisitive. Ed. Rev.
demivill: A half-vill, consisting of five freemen or frankpledges.Blackstone.
disoccident: To turn away from the west; to throw out of reckoning as tolongitude. [Obs.] Marvell.
directorship: The condition or office of a director; directorate.
diathesis: Bodily condition or constitution, esp. a morbid habit whichpredisposes to a particular disease, or class of diseases.
draining: The art of carrying off surplus water, as from land. Drainingtile. Same as Draintile.
discommunity: A lack of common possessions, properties, or relationship.Community of embryonic structure reveals community of descent; butdissimilarity of embryonic development does not prove discommunity ofdescent. Darwin.
designator: An officer who assigned to each his rank and place in publicshows and ceremonies.
disembowered: Deprived of, or removed from, a bower. [Poetic] Bryant.
deliquiate: To melt and become liquid by absorbing water from the air; todeliquesce. Fourcroy.
deludable: Capable of being deluded; liable to be imposed on gullible. SirT. Browne.
depravation: Change for the worse; deterioration; morbid perversion.
dermatography: An anatomical description of, or treatise on, the skin.
decemviral: Pertaining to the decemvirs in Rome.
dead: Cut off from the rights of a citizen; deprived of the power ofenjoying the rights of property; as, one banished or becoming a monkis civilly dead.
dipyridyl: A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by thereduction of pyridine.
denitration: A disengaging, or removal, of nitric acid.
degustation: Tasting; the appreciation of sapid qualities by the tasteorgans. Bp. Hall.
debeige: A kind of woolen or mixed dress goods. [Written also debage.]
durableness: Power of lasting, enduring, or resisting; durability.The durableness of the metal that supports it. Addison.
deputator: One who deputes, or makes a deputation. [R.] Locke.
disburden: To rid of a burden; to free from a load borne or from somethingoppressive; to unload; to disencumber; to relieve.He did it to disburden a conscience. Feltham.My mediations . . . will, I hope, be more calm, being thusdisburdened. Hammond.
disposable: Subject to disposal; free to be used or employed as occasionmay require; not assigned to any service or use.The great of this kingdom . . . has easily afforded a disposablesurplus. Burke.
dichogamy: The condition of certain species of plants, in which thestamens and pistil do not mature simultaneously, so that these plantscan never fertilize themselves.
dactylopterous: Having the inferior rays of the pectoral fins partially orentirely free, as in the gurnards.
deranged: Disordered; especially, disordered in mind; crazy; insane.The story of a poor deranged parish lad. Lamb.
desecrater: One who desecrates; a profaner. Harper's Mag.
difflation: A blowing apart or away. [Obs.] Bailey.
decorative: Suited to decorate or embellish; adorning.-- Dec"o*ra*tive*ness, n. Decorative art, fine art which has for itsend ornamentation, rather than the representation of objects orevents.
disacquaint: To render unacquainted; to make unfamiliar. [Obs.]While my sick heart With dismal smart Is disacquainted never.Herrick.
dasypaedes: Those birds whose young are covered with down when hatched.
distensible: Capable of being distended or dilated.
deaf-mutism: The condition of being a deaf-mute.
dermopteran: An insect which has the anterior pair of wings coriaceous, anddoes not use them in flight, as the earwig.
damara: A native of Damaraland, German Southwest Africa. The Damarasinclude an important and warlike Bantu tribe, and the Hill Damaras,who are Hottentots and mixed breeds hostile to the Bantus.
deftly: Aptly; fitly; dexterously; neatly. "Deftly dancing." Drayton.Thyself and office deftly show. Shak.
dermoneural: Pertaining to, or in relation with, both dermal and neuralstructures; as, the dermoneural spines or dorsal fin rays of fishes.Owen.
discina: A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached byone valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.
dilettanteism: The state or quality of being a dilettante; the desultorypursuit of art, science, or literature.
disputative: Disposed to dispute; inclined to cavil or to reason inopposition; as, a disputative temper. I. Watts.
dunnish: Inclined to a dun color. Ray.
defenseless: Destitute of defense; unprepared to resist attack; unable tooppose; unprotected.-- De*fense"less*ly, adv.-- De*fense"less*ness, n.
disinfection: The act of disinfecting; purification from infecting matter.
disshadow: To free from shadow or shade. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
disobligatory: Releasing from obligation. "Disobligatory power." Charles I.
decomposed: Separated or broken up; -- said of the crest of birds when thefeathers are divergent.
dug: A teat, pap, or nipple; -- formerly that of a human mother, nowthat of a cow or other beast.With mother's dug between its lips. Shak.
disemboguement: The act of disemboguing; discharge. Mease.
domesticant: Forming part of the same family. [Obs.] Sir E. Dering.
disworth: To deprive of worth; to degrade. [Obs.] Feltham.
dewret: To ret or rot by the process called dewretting.
dialyze: To separate, prepare, or obtain, by dialysis or osmose; to passthrough an animal membrane; to subject to dialysis. [Written alsodialyse.]
decathlon: In the modern Olympic Games, a composite contest consisting ofa 100-meter run, a broad jump, putting the shot, a running high-jump,a 400-meter run, throwing the discus, a 100-meter hurdle race, polevaulting, throwing the javelin, and a 1500-meter run.
disloign: To put at a distance; to remove. [Obs.]Low-looking dales, disloigned from common gaze. Spenser.
decimosexto: A book consisting of sheets, each of which is folded intosixteen leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size ofbook; -- usually written 16mo or 16º.
dilatator: A muscle which dilates any part; a dilator.
divaricate: To divide into two branches; to cause to branch apart.
distensive: Distending, or capable of being distended.
dialogism: An imaginary speech or discussion between two or more;dialogue. Fulke.
dispel: To drive away by scattering, or so to cause to vanish; to clearaway; to banish; to dissipate; as, to dispel a cloud, vapors, cares,doubts, illusions.[Satan] gently raised their fainting courage, and dispelled theirfears. Milton.I saw myself the lambent easy light Gild the brown horror, and dispelthe night. Dryden.
decrown: To deprive of a crown; to discrown. [R.] Hakewill.
deploredness: The state of being deplored or deplorable. [R.] Bp. Hail.
didelphia: The subclass of Mammalia which includes the marsupials. SeeMarsupialia.
despicableness: The quality of being despicable; meanness; vileness;worthlessness.
disagreeableness: The state or quality of being; disagreeable; unpleasantness.
damnability: The quality of being damnable; damnableness. Sir T. More.
duncedom: The realm or domain of dunces. [Jocose] Carlyle.
downlooked: Having a downcast countenance; dejected; gloomy; sullen. [R.]Dryden.
dissected: Cut deeply into many lobes or divisions; as, a dissected leaf.
demonism: The belief in demons or false gods.The established theology of the heathen world . . . rested upon thebasis of demonism. Farmer.
discapacitate: To deprive of capacity; to incapacitate. [R.]
deerskin: The skin of a deer, or the leather which is made from it.Hakluyt. Longfellow.
disconnection: The act of disconnecting, or state of being disconnected;separation; want of union.Nothing was therefore to be left in all the subordinate members butweakness, disconnection, and confusion. Burke.
deoxidizer: That which removes oxygen; hence, a reducing agent; as, nascenthydrogen is a deoxidizer.
dustbrush: A brush of feathers, bristles, or hair, for removing dust fromfurniture.
durative: Continuing; not completed; implying duration.Its durative tense, which expresses the thought of it as going on. J.Byrne.
dissociate: To separate from fellowship or union; to disunite; to disjoin;as, to dissociate the particles of a concrete substance.Before Wyclif's death in 1384, John of Gaunt had openly dissociatedhimself from the reformer. A. W. Ward.
dialectics: That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes ofreasoning; the application of logical principles to discursivereasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error;logical discussion.
dehydrogenation: The act or process or freeing from hydrogen; also, thecondition resulting from the removal of hydrogen.
discontinuation: Breach or interruption of continuity; separation of parts in aconnected series; discontinuance.Upon any discontinuation of parts, made either by bubbles or byshaking the glass, the whole mercury falls. Sir I. Newton.
dockage: A charge for the use of a dock.
draper: One who sells cloths; a dealer in cloths; as, a draper andtailor.
dextrose: A sirupy, or white crystalline, variety of sugar, C6H12O6 (socalled from turning the plane of polarization to the right),occurring in many ripe fruits. Dextrose and levulose are obtained bythe inversion of cane sugar or sucrose, and hence called invertsugar. Dextrose is chiefly obtained by the action of heat and acidson starch, and hence called also starch sugar. It is also formed fromstarchy food by the action of the amylolytic ferments of saliva andpancreatic juice.
dejecter: One who casts down, or dejects.
dispeed: To send off with speed; to dispatch. [Obs.] Knolles.Then they dispeeded themselves of the Cid and of their mother-in-law,DoSouthey.
disimprovement: Reduction from a better to a worse state; as, disimprovement ofthe earth.
deictically: In a manner to show or point out; directly; absolutely;definitely.When Christ spake it deictically. Hammond.
draughty: Pertaining to a draught, or current of air; as, a draughtly,comfortless room.
despend: To spend; to squander. See Dispend. [Obs.]Some noble men in Spain can despend Howell.
discomfiture: The act of discomfiting, or the state of being discomfited;rout; overthrow; defeat; frustration; confusion and dejection.Every man's sword was against his fellow, and there was a very greatdiscomfiture. 1 Sam. xiv. 20.A hope destined to end . . . in discomfiture and disgrace. Macaulay.
disreverence: To treat irreverently or with disrespect. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
decomposable: Capable of being resolved into constituent elements.
do: A syllable attached to the first tone of the major diatonicscale for the purpose of solmization, or solfeggio. It is the firstof the seven syllables used by the Italians as manes of musicaltones, and replaced, for the sake of euphony, the syllable Ut,applied to the note C. In England and America the same syllables areused by mane as a scale pattern, while the tones in respect toabsolute pitch are named from the first seven letters of thealphabet.
dite: To prepare for action or use; to make ready; to dight. [Obs.]His hideous club aloft he dites. Spenser.
disprison: To let loose from prison, to set all liberty. [R.] Bulwer.
diphygenic: Having two modes of embryonic development.
dolioform: Barrel-shaped, or like a cask in form.
demerge: To plunge down into; to sink; to immerse. [Obs.]The water in which it was demerged. Boyle.
development: The series of changes which animal and vegetable organismsundergo in their passage from the embryonic state to maturity, from alower to a higher state of organization.
dezincify: To deprive of, or free from, zinc.
doorcase: The surrounding frame into which a door shuts.
dairying: The business of conducting a dairy.
dunny: Deaf; stupid.[Prov. Eng.]My old dame Joan is something dunny, and will scarce know how tomanage. Sir W. Scott.
deanship: The office of a dean.I dont't value your deanship a straw. Swift.
dying: The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
diagnostics: That part of medicine which has to do with ascertaining thenature of diseases by means of their symptoms or signs.His rare skill in diagnostics. Macaulay.
dramseller: One who sells distilled liquors by the dram or glass.
destructor: A destroyer. [R.]Fire, the destructive and the artificial death of things. Boyle.
depolishing: The process of removing the vitreous glaze from porcelain,leaving the dull luster of the surface of ivory porcelian. Knight.
defile: To march off in a line, file by file; to file off.
dactylonomy: The art of numbering or counting by the fingers.
diaphoretic: A medicine or agent which promotes perspiration.
discharge: To throw off or deliver a load, charge, or burden; to unload;to emit or give vent to fluid or other contents; as, the water pipedischarges freely.The cloud, if it were oily or fatty, would not discharge. Bacon.
disrespect: Want of respect or reverence; disesteem; incivility;discourtesy.Impatience of bearing the least affront or disrespect. Pope.
diluter: One who, or that which, dilutes or makes thin, more liquid, orweaker.
dauphin: The title of the eldest son of the king of France, and heir tothe crown. Since the revolution of 1830, the title has beendiscontinued.
draintile: A hollow tile used in making drains; -- called also drainingtile.
disburthen: To disburden; to relieve of a load. [Archaic]
depucelate: To deflour; to deprive of virginity. [Obs.] Bailey.
dister: To banish or drive from a country. [Obs.] Howell.
disreputable: Not reputable; of bad repute; not in esteem; dishonorable;disgracing the reputation; tending to bring into disesteem; as, it isdisreputable to associate familiarly with the mean, the lewd, and theprofane.Why should you think that conduct disreputable in priests which youprobably consider as laudable in yourself Bp. Watson.
drawbench: A machine in which strips of metal are drawn through adrawplate; especially, one in which wire is thus made; -- also calleddrawing bench.
duncical: Like a dunce; duncish.The most dull and duncical commissioner. Fuller.
disconsecrate: To deprive of consecration or sacredness. [R.]
dephlegm: To rid of phlegm or water; to dephlegmate. [Obs.] Boyle.
deminatured: Having half the nature of another. [R.] Shak.
dancette: Deeply indented; having large teeth; thus, a fess dancetté hasonly three teeth in the whole width of the escutcheon.
divagation: A wandering about or going astray; digression.Let us be set down at Queen's Crawley without further divagation.Thackeray.
diffame: Evil name; bad reputation; defamation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
determinist: One who believes in determinism. Also adj.; as, deterministtheories.
detrain: To alight, or to cause to alight, from a railway train. [Eng.]London Graphic.
detonate: To explode with a sudden report; as, niter detonates withsulphur.
dominator: A ruler or ruling power. "Sole dominator of Navarre." Shak.Jupiter and Mars are dominators for this northwest part of the world.Camden.
decillion: According to the English notation, a million involved to thetenth power, or a unit with sixty ciphers annexed; according to theFrench and American notation, a thousand involved to the eleventhpower, or a unit with thirty-three ciphers annexed. [See the Noteunder Numeration.]
dog star: Sirius, a star of the constellation Canis Major, or the GreaterDog, and the brightest star in the heavens; -- called also Canicula,and, in astronomical charts, a Canis Majoris. See Dog days.
dishevel: To be spread in disorder or hang negligently, as the hair. [R.]Sir T. Herbert.
demisable: Capable of being leased; as, a demisable estate.
denigrator: One who, or that which, blackens.
deafening: The act or process of rendering impervious to sound, as a flooror wall; also, the material with which the spaces are filled in thisprocess; pugging.
dilated: Widening into a lamina or into lateral winglike appendages.
disparates: Things so unequal or unlike that they can not be compared witheach other.
diverberate: To strike or sound through. [R.] Davies (Holy Roode).
diagometer: A sort of electroscope, invented by Rousseau, in which the drypile is employed to measure the amount of electricity transmitted bydifferent bodies, or to determine their conducting power. Nichol.
double-ripper: A kind of coasting sled, made of two sleds fastened togetherwith a board, one before the other. [Local, U. S.]
deutoplastic: Pertaining to, or composed of, deutoplasm.
detector bar: A bar, connected with a switch, longer than the distancebetween any two consecutive wheels of a train (45 to 50 feet), laidinside a rail and operated by the wheels so that the switch cannot bethrown until all the train is past the switch.
defeasance: A condition, relating to a deed, which being performed, thedeed is defeated or rendered void; or a collateral deed, made at thesame time with a feoffment, or other conveyance, containingconditions, on the performance of which the estate then created maybe defeated.
dentately: In a dentate or toothed manner; as, dentately ciliated, etc.
degrade: To reduce in altitude or magnitude, as hills and mountains; towear down.
donzel: A young squire, or knight's attendant; a page. [Obs.] Beau. &Fl.
derivation: The operation of deducing one function from another accordingto some fixed law, called the law of derivation, as the ofdifferentiation or of integration.
decarburization: The act, process, or result of decarburizing.
doughiness: The quality or state of being doughy.
debilitation: The act or process of debilitating, or the condition of one whois debilitated; weakness.
discoblastic: Applied to a form of egg cleavage seen in osseous fishes, whichoccurs only in a small disk that separates from the rest of the egg.
dispiritment: Depression of spirits; discouragement. [R.]Procter, in evident distress and dispiritment, was waiting the slowconclusion of this. Carlyle.
disenamor: To free from the captivity of love. Shelton.
disdeify: To divest or deprive of deity or of a deific rank or condition.Feltham.
dowress: A woman entitled to dower. Bouvier.
digynia: A Linnæan order of plants having two styles.
dumpling: A roundish mass of dough boiled in soup, or as a sort ofpudding; often, a cover of paste inclosing an apple or other fruit,and boiled or baked; as, an apple dumpling.
d valve: A kind of slide valve. See Slide valve, under Slide.
deductive: Of or pertaining to deduction; capable of being deduced frompremises; deducible.All knowledge of causes is deductive. Glanvill.Notions and ideas . . . used in a deductive process. Whewell.
dole: grief; sorrow; lamentation. [Archaic]And she died. So that day there was dole in Astolat. Tennyson.
desponsory: A written pledge of marriage. Clarendon.
dogmatist: One who dogmatizes; one who speaks dogmatically; a bold andarrogant advancer of principles.I expect but little success of all this upon the dogmatist; hisopinioned assurance is paramount to argument. Glanvill.
dewfall: The falling of dew; the time when dew begins to fall.
donative: A benefice conferred on a person by the founder or patron,without either presentation or institution by the ordinary, orinduction by his orders. See the Note under Benefice, n.,
divisionor: One who divides or makes division. [Obs.] Sheldon.
denotative: Having power to denote; designating or marking off.Proper names are preëminently denotative; telling us that such asobject has such a term to denote it, but telling us nothing as to anysingle attribute. Latham.
dishearten: To discourage; to deprive of courage and hope; to depress thespirits of; to deject.Regiments . . . utterly disorganized and disheartened. Macaulay.
disgustful: Provoking disgust; offensive to the taste; exciting aversion;disgusting.That horrible and disgustful situation. Burke.
deceptiveness: The power or habit of deceiving; tendency or aptness todeceive.
digladiate: To fight like gladiators; to contend fiercely; to disputeviolently. [Obs.]Digladiating like Æschines and Demosthenes. Hales.
distress: To seize for debt; to distrain.
demise: The conveyance or transfer of an estate, either in fee for lifeor for years, most commonly the latter. Bouvier.
designedly: By design; purposely; intentionally; -- opposed toaccidentally, ignorantly, or inadvertently.
dephosphorization: The act of freeing from phosphorous.
disaffirmance: Overthrow or annulment by the decision of a superior tribunal;as, disaffirmance of judgment.
doretree: A doorpost. [Obs.] "As dead as a doretree." Piers Plowman.
demurral: Demur; delay in acting or deciding.The same causes of demurral existed which prevented British troopsfrom assisting in the expulsion of the French from Rome. Southey.
dischurch: To deprive of status as a church, or of membership in a church.Bp. Hall.
dosage: The administration of medicine in doses; specif., a scheme orsystem of grading doses of medicine according to age, etc.
disfigure: To mar the figure of; to render less complete, perfect, orbeautiful in appearance; to deface; to deform.Disfiguring not God's likeness, but their own. Milton.
disabuse: To set free from mistakes; to undeceive; to disengage fromfallacy or deception; to set right.To undeceive and disabuse the people. South.If men are now sufficiently enlightened to disabuse themselves orartifice, hypocrisy, and superstition, they will consider this eventas an era in their history. J. Adams.
disadvance: To draw back, or cause to draw back. [Obs.] Spenser.
disproportionate: Not proportioned; unsymmetrical; unsuitable to something elsein bulk, form, value, or extent; out of proportion; inadequate; as,in a perfect body none of the limbs are disproportionate; it iswisdom not to undertake a work disproportionate means.-- Dis`pro*por"tion*ate*ly, adv.-- Dis`pro*por"tion*ate*ness, n.
dilemma: An argument which presents an antagonist with two or morealternatives, but is equally conclusive against him, whicheveralternative he chooses.
deligation: A binding up; a bandaging. Wiseman.
desirable: Worthy of desire or longing; fitted to excite desire or a wishto possess; pleasing; agreeable.All of them desirable young men. Ezek. xxiii. 12.As things desirable excite Desire, and objects move the appetite.Blackmore.
derbyshire spar: A massive variety of fluor spar, found in Derbyshire, England,and wrought into vases and other ornamental work.
destemper: A kind of painting. See Distemper.
digraph: Two signs or characters combined to express a singlearticulated sound; as ea in head, or th in bath.
disfranchise: To deprive of a franchise or chartered right; to dispossess ofthe rights of a citizen, or of a particular privilege, as of voting,holding office, etc.Sir William Fitzwilliam was disfranchised. Fabyan (1509).He was partially disfranchised so as to be made incapable of takingpart in public affairs. Thirlwall.
diorite: An igneous, crystalline in structure, consisting essentially ofa triclinic feldspar and hornblende. It includes part of what wascalled greenstone.
dabb: A large, spine-tailed lizard (Uromastix spinipes), found inEgypt, Arabia, and Palestine; -- called also dhobb, and dhabb.
diathermic: Affording a free passage to heat; as, diathermic substances.Melloni.
dice: Small cubes used in gaming or in determining by chance; also,the game played with dice. See Die, n. Dice coal, a kind of coaleasily splitting into cubical fragments. Brande & C.
diaphanoscope: A dark box constructed for viewing transparent pictures, withor without a lens.
dislimn: To efface, as a picture. [Obs.] Shak.
disestablish: To unsettle; to break up (anything established); to deprive, asa church, of its connection with the state. M. Arnold.
dissheathe: To become unsheathed. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
despicable: Fit or deserving to be despised; contemptible; mean; vile;worthless; as, a despicable man; despicable company; a despicablegift.
docetic: Pertaining to, held by, or like, the Docetæ. "DoceticGnosticism." Plumptre.
disserve: To fail to serve; to do injury or mischief to; to damage; tohurt; to harm.Have neither served nor disserved the interests of any party. Jer.Taylor.
diamond state: Delaware; -- a nickname alluding to its small size.
distressful: Full of distress; causing, indicating, or attended with,distress; as, a distressful situation. "Some distressful stroke."Shak. "Distressful cries." Pope.-- Dis*tress"ful*ly, adv.
discandy: To melt; to dissolve; to thaw. [Obs.]
direction: The pointing of a piece with reference to an imaginary verticalaxis; -- distinguished from elevation. The direction is given whenthe plane of sight passes through the object. Wilhelm.
delirious: Having a delirium; wandering in mind; light-headed; insane;raving; wild; as, a delirious patient; delirious fancies.-- De*lir"i*ous*ly, adv.-- De*lir"i*ous*ness, n.
distributing: That distributes; dealing out. Distributing past office, anoffice where the mails for a large district are collected to beassorted according to their destination and forwarded.
disgusting: That causes disgust; sickening; offensive; revolting.-- Dis*gust"ing*ly, adv.
dissolver: One who, or that which, has power to dissolve or dissipate.Thou kind dissolver of encroaching care. Otway.
dugway: A way or road dug through a hill, or sunk below the surface ofthe land. [U.S.]
docible: Easily taught or managed; teachable. Milton.
disencharm: To free from the influence of a charm or spell; to disenchant.[R.] Jer. Taylor.
desmodont: A member of a group of South American blood-sucking bats, ofthe genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.
dux: The scholastic name for the theme or subject of a fugue, theanswer being called the comes, or companion.
disentrance: To awaken from a trance or an enchantment. Hudibras.
disusage: Gradual cessation of use or custom; neglect of use; disuse.[R.] Hooker.
dominant: Ruling; governing; prevailing; controlling; predominant; as,the dominant party, church, spirit, power.The member of a dominant race is, in his dealings with the subjectrace, seldom indeed fraudulent, . . . but imperious, insolent, andcruel. Macaulay.Dominant estate or tenement (Law), the estate to which a servitude oreasement is due from another estate, the estate over which theservitude extends being called the servient estate or tenement.Bouvier. Wharton's Law Dict.-- Dominant owner (Law), one who owns lands on which there is aneasement owned by another.
dogtooth: An ornament common in Gothic architecture, consisting ofpointed projections resembling teeth; -- also called tooth ornament.Dogtooth spar (Min.), a variety of calcite, in acute crystals,resembling the tooth of a dog. See Calcite.-- Dogtooth violet (Bot.), a small, bulbous herb of the Lily family(genus Erythronium). It has two shining flat leaves and commonly onelarge flower. [Written also dog's-tooth violet.]
depopulate: To deprive of inhabitants, whether by death or by expulsion; toreduce greatly the populousness of; to dispeople; to unpeople.Where is this viper, That would depopulate the city Shak.
deoxygenation: The act or operation of depriving of oxygen.
disconsent: To differ; to disagree; to dissent. [Obs.] Milton.
diaphysis: An abnormal prolongation of the axis of inflorescence.
dejecta: Excrements; as, the dejecta of the sick.
dura mater: The tough, fibrous membrane, which lines the cavity of theskull and spinal column, and surrounds the brain and spinal cord; --frequently abbreviated to dura.
daguerreotypy: The art or process of producing pictures by method of Daguerre.
deterioration: The process of growing worse, or the state of having grownworse.
disappendent: Freed from a former connection or dependence; disconnected.[R.]
diriment: Absolute. Diriment impediment (R. C. Ch.), an impediment thatnullifies marriage.
diota: A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.
drub: To beat with a stick; to thrash; to cudgel.Soundly Drubbed with a good honest cudgel. L'Estrange.
discodactylous: Having sucking disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
dung: The excrement of an animal. Bacon.
durylic: Pertaining to, allied to, or derived from, durene; as, durylicacid.
diswont: To deprive of wonted usage; to disaccustom. [R.] Bp. Hall.
dorian: Same as Doric, 3. "Dorian mood." Milton. Dorian mode (Mus.),the first of the authentic church modes or tones, from D to D,resembling our D minor scale, but with the B natural. Grove.
denominationalist: One imbued with a denominational spirit. The Century.
dismay: To take dismay or fright; to be filled with dismay. [Obs.]Shak.
descensive: Tending to descend; tending downwards; descending. Smart.
drabbet: A coarse linen fabric, or duck.
demurrable: That may be demurred to. Stormonth.
decolling: Beheading. [R.]By a speedy dethroning and decolling of the king. ParliamentaryHistory (1648).
divinator: One who practices or pretends to divination; a diviner. [R.]Burton.
dentine: The dense calcified substance of which teeth are largelycomposed. It contains less animal matter than bone, and in the teethof man is situated beneath the enamel.
drysaltery: The articles kept by a drysalter; also, the business of adrysalter.
dermis: The deep sensitive layer of the skin beneath the scarfskin orepidermis; -- called also true skin, derm, derma, corium, cutis, andenderon. See Skin, and Illust. in Appendix.
dislink: To unlink; to disunite; to separate. [R.] Tennyson.
dentition: The system of teeth peculiar to an animal.
dowitcher: The red-breasted or gray snipe (Macrorhamphus griseus); --called also brownback, and grayback.
denizenize: To constitute (one) a denizen; to denizen. Abbott.
designful: Full of design; scheming. [R.] -- De*sign"ful*ness, n. [R.]Barrow.
disceptation: Controversy; disputation; discussion. [Archaic]Verbose janglings and endless disceptations. Strype.
dere: To hurt; to harm; to injure. [Obs.] Chaucer.
delundung: An East Indian carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis),resembling the civets, but without scent pouches. It is handsomelyspotted.
deliquesce: To dissolve gradually and become liquid by attracting andabsorbing moisture from the air, as certain salts, acids, andalkalies.In very moist air crystals of strontites deliquesce. Black.
deracinate: To pluck up by the roots; to extirpate. [R.]While that the colter rusts That should deracinate such savagery.Shak.
dander: To wander about; to saunter; to talk incoherently. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
dub: To make a noise by brisk drumbeats. "Now the drum dubs." Beau.& Fl.
delicatessen: Relishes for the table; dainties; delicacies. "A dealer indelicatessen".  G. H. Putnam.
diversiform: Of a different form; of varied forms.
discalceated: Deprived off shoes or sandals; unshod; discalced.
derider: One who derides, or laughs at, another in contempt; a mocker; ascoffer.
demarcation: The act of marking, or of ascertaining and setting a limit;separation; distinction.The speculative line of demarcation, where obedience ought to end andresistance must begin, is faint, obscure, and not easily definable.Burke.
deliquate: To melt or be dissolved; to deliquesce. [Obs.] Boyle.
deposit: A natural occurrence of a useful mineral under the conditionsto invite exploitation. Raymond.
daytime: The time during which there is daylight, as distinguished fromthe night.
diphthongize: To change into a diphthong, as by affixing another vowel to asimple vowel. "The diphthongized long vowels." H. Sweet.
distrainable: Capable of being, or liable to be, distrained. Blackstone.
disorientate: To turn away from the east, or (figuratively) from the right orthe truth. [R.]
disinfectant: That which disinfects; an agent for removing the causes ofinfection, as chlorine.
deceptive: Tending to deceive; having power to mislead, or impress withfalse opinions; as, a deceptive countenance or appearance.Language altogether deceptive, and hiding the deeper reality from oureyes. Trench.Deceptive cadence (Mus.), a cadence on the subdominant, or in someforeign key, postponing the final close.
disconnect: To dissolve the union or connection of; to disunite; to sever;to separate; to disperse.The commonwealth itself would . . . be disconnected into the dust andpowder of individuality. Burke.This restriction disconnects bank paper and the precious metals.Walsh.
dizz: To make dizzy; to astonish; to puzzle. [Obs.] Gayton.
deathliness: The quality of being deathly; deadliness. Southey.
discruciate: To torture; to excruciate. [Obs.]Discruciate a man in deep distress. Herrick.
diaphanic: Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.
drizzle: To rain slightly in very small drops; to fall, as water fromthe clouds, slowly and in fine particles; as, it drizzles; drizzlingdrops or rain. "Drizzling tears." Spenser.
declination: The angular distance of any object from the celestial equator,either northward or southward.
debatement: Controversy; deliberation; debate. [R.]A serious question and debatement with myself. Milton.
doughtiness: The quality of being doughty; valor; bravery.
decant: To pour off gently, as liquor, so as not to disturb thesediment; or to pour from one vessel into another; as, to decantwine.
dal segno: A direction to go back to the sign Segno.
demonology: A treatise on demons; a supposititious science which treats ofdemons and their manifestations. Sir W. Scott.
doge: The chief magistrate in the republics of Venice and Genoa.
disembogue: To become discharged; to flow put; to find vent; to pour outcontents.Volcanos bellow ere they disembogue. Young.
disgarrison: To deprive of a garrison. Hewyt.
dragantine: A mucilage obtained from, or containing, gun tragacanth.
double-quick: Of, or performed in, the fastest time or step in marching, nextto the run; as, a double-quick step or march.
dressmaker: A maker of gowns, or similar garments; a mantuamaker.
disputatious: Inclined to dispute; apt to civil or controvert; characterizedby dispute; as, a disputatious person or temper.The Christian doctrine of a future life was no recommendation of thenew religion to the wits and philosophers of that disputationsperiod. Buckminster.-- Dis`pu*ta"tious*ly, adv.-- Dis`pu*ta"tious*ness, n.
decompound: Several times compounded or divided, as a leaf or stem;decomposite.
disposedness: The state of being disposed or inclined; inclination;propensity. [R.]
diaphemetric: Relating to the measurement of the tactile sensibility ofparts; as, diaphemetric compasses. Dunglison.
disexercise: To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained. [Obs.]By disexercising and blunting our abilities. Milton.
detestable: Worthy of being detested; abominable; extremely hateful; veryodious; deserving abhorrence; as, detestable vices.Thou hast defiled my sanctuary will all thy detestable things, andwith all thine abominations. Ezek. v. 11.
digamy: Act, or state, of being twice married; deuterogamy. [R.]
dessert: A service of pastry, fruits, or sweetmeats, at the close of afeast or entertainment; pastry, fruits, etc., forming the last courseat dinner."An 't please your honor," quoth the peasant, "This same dessert isnot so pleasant." Pope.Dessert spoon, a spoon used in eating dessert; a spoon intermediatein size between a teaspoon and a tablespoon.-- Dessert-spoonful, n., pl. Dessert-spoonfuls, as much as a dessertspoon will hold, usually reckoned at about two and a half fluiddrams.
devolve: To pass by transmission or succession; to be handed over ordown; -- generally with on or upon, sometimes with to or into; as,after the general fell, the command devolved upon (or on) the nextofficer in rank.His estate . . . devolved to Lord Somerville. Johnson.
deadlight: A strong shutter, made to fit open ports and keep out water ina storm.
digamous: Pertaining to a second marriage, that is, one after the deathof the first wife or the first husband.
desirability: The state or quality of being desirable; desirableness.
dubiosity: The state of being doubtful; a doubtful statement or thing.[R.]Men often swallow falsities for truths, dubiosities for certainties,possibilities for feasibilities. Sir T. Browne.
dukeling: A little or insignificant duke. Ford.
dentirostral: Having a toothed bill; -- applied to a group of passerinebirds, having the bill notched, and feeding chiefly on insects, asthe shrikes and vireos. See Illust. (N) under Beak.
dooly: A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carryingpersons or things; a palanquin. [Written also doolee and doolie.][East Indies]Having provided doolies, or little bamboo chairs slung on four men'sshoulders, in which I put my papers and boxes, we next morningcommenced the ascent. J. D. Hooker.
declinate: Bent downward or aside; (Bot.) bending downward in a curve;declined.
deletitious: Of such a nature that anything may be erased from it; -- saidof paper.
diapedesis: The passage of the corpuscular elements of the blood from theblood vessels into the surrounding tissues, without rupture of thewalls of the blood vessels.
disencumbrance: Freedom or deliverance from encumbrance, or anything burdensomeor troublesome. Spectator.
didactics: The art or science of teaching.
dockyard: A yard or storage place for all sorts of naval stores andtimber for shipbuilding.
defendress: A female defender. [R.]Defendress of the faith. Stow.
disopinion: Want or difference of belief; disbelief. [Obs.] Bp. Reynolds.
disgruntle: To dissatisfy; to disaffect; to anger. [Colloq.]
decorum: Propriety of manner or conduct; grace arising from suitablenessof speech and behavior to one's own character, or to the place andoccasion; decency of conduct; seemliness; that which is seemly orsuitable.Negligent of the duties and decorums of his station. Hallam.If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, Thatmajesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom. Shak.
dialectal: Relating to a dialect; dialectical; as, a dialectical variant.
dreamful: Full of dreams. " Dreamful ease." Tennyson.-- Dream"ful*ly, adv.
duplicature: A doubling; a fold, as of a membrane.
disuse: Cessation of use, practice, or exercise; inusitation;desuetude; as, the limbs lose their strength by disuse.The disuse of the tongue in the only . . . remedy. Addison.Church discipline then fell into disuse. Southey.
drunkard: One who habitually drinks strong liquors immoderately; onewhose habit it is to get drunk; a toper; a sot.The drunkard and glutton shall come to poverty. Prov. xxiii. 21.
drazel: A slut; a vagabond wench. Same as Drossel. [Obs.] Hudibras.
dispender: One who dispends or expends; a steward. [Obs.] Wyclif (1 Cor.iv. 1).
diacaustic: Pertaining to, or possessing the properties of, a species ofcaustic curves formed by refraction. See Caustic surface, underCaustic.
dactyl: A poetical foot of three sylables (-- ~ ~), one long followedby two short, or one accented followed by two unaccented; as, L.tëgmînê, E. mer"ciful; -- so called from the similarity of itsarrangement to that of the joints of a finger. [Written alsodactyle.]
dianthus: A genus of plants containing some of the most popular ofcultivated flowers, including the pink, carnation, and Sweet William.
decorticator: A machine for decorticating wood, hulling grain, etc.; also, aninstrument for removing surplus bark or moss from fruit trees.
detruncate: To shorten by cutting; to cut off; to lop off.
denominator: That number placed below the line in vulgar fractions whichshows into how many parts the integer or unit is divided.
deil: Devil; -- spelt also deel. [Scot.] Deil's buckie. See underBuckie.
dantean: Relatingto, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or hiswritings.
diapasm: Powdered aromatic herbs, sometimes made into little balls andstrung together. [Obs.]
delirate: To madden; to rave. [Obs.]An infatuating and delirating spirit in it. Holland.
dambose: A crystalline vari ety of fruit sugar obtained from dambonite.
decreaseless: Suffering no decrease. [R.]It [the river] flows and flows, and yet will flow, Volumedecreaseless to the final hour. A. Seward.
dust: Coined money; cash. Down with the dust, deposit the cash; paydown the money. [Slang] "My lord, quoth the king, presently deposityour hundred pounds in gold, or else no going hence all the days ofyour life. . . . The Abbot down with his dust, and glad he escapedso, returned to Reading." Fuller.-- Dust brand (Bot.), a fungous plant (Ustilago Carbo); -- calledalso smut.-- Gold dust, fine particles of gold, such as are obtained in placermining; -- often used as money, being transferred by weight.-- In dust and ashes. See under Ashes.-- To bite the dust. See under Bite, v. t.-- To raise, or kick up, dust, to make a commotion. [Colloq.] -- Tothrow dust in one's eyes, to mislead; to deceive. [Colloq.]
dispathy: Lack of sympathy; want of passion; apathy. [R.]Many discrepancies and some dispathies between us. Southey.
dissociation: The process by which a compound body breaks up into simplerconstituents; -- said particularly of the action of heat on gaseousor volatile substances; as, the dissociation of the sulphurmolecules; the dissociation of ammonium chloride into hydrochloricacid and ammonia.
dormy: Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said ofa player or side.
depauperize: To free from paupers; to rescue from poverty. [R.]
disjointed: Separated at the joints; disconnected; incoherent.-- Dis*joint"ed*ly, adv.-- Dis*joint"ed*ness, n.
dominion day: In Canada, a legal holiday, July lst, being the anniversary ofthe proclamation of the formation of the Dominion in 1867.
dialyzed: Prepared by diffusion through an animal membrane; as, dialyzediron.
defensative: That which serves to protect or defend.
ductless: Having to duct or outlet; as, a ductless gland.
diabolo: An old game or sport (revived under this name) consisting inwhirling on a string, fastened to two sticks, a small somewhat spool-shaped object (called the diabolo) so as to balance it on a string,toss it in the air and catch it, etc.
disacryl: A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymericmodification of acrolein.
duettino: A duet of short extent and concise form.
derecho: A straight wind without apparent cyclonic tendency, usuallyaccompanied with rain and often destructive, common in the prairieregions of the United States.
delirifacient: Producing, or tending to produce, delirium.-- n.
dresden ware: A superior kind of decorated porcelain made near Dresden inSaxony.
dentate-sinuate: Having a form intermediate between dentate and sinuate.
dustpan: A shovel-like utensil for conveying away dust brushed from thefloor.
deviate: To go out of the way; to turn aside from a course or a method;to stray or go astray; to err; to digress; to diverge; to vary.Thus Pegasus, a nearer way to take, May boldly deviate from thecommon track. Pope.
discourager: One who discourages.The promoter of truth and the discourager of error. Sir G. C. Lewis.
discrown: To deprive of a crown.The end had crowned the work; it not unreasonably discrowned theworkman. Motley.
discerningly: In a discerning manner; with judgment; judiciously; acutely.Garth.
dichromic: Furnishing or giving two colors; -- said of defective vision,in which all the compound colors are resolvable into two elementsinstead of three. Sir J. Herschel.
dicalcic: Having two atoms or equivalents of calcium to the molecule.
duumvirate: The union of two men in the same office; or the office,dignity, or government of two men thus associated, as in ancientRome.
digamist: One who marries a second time; a deuterogamist. Hammond.
desoxalic: Made or derived from oxalic acid; as, desoxalic acid.
dealing: The act of one who deals; distribution of anything, as of cardsto the players; method of business; traffic; intercourse;transaction; as, to have dealings with a person. Double dealing,insincere, treacherous dealing; duplicity.-- Plain dealing, fair, sincere, honorable dealing; honest,outspoken expression of opinion.
defier: One who dares and defies; a contemner; as, a defier of thelaws.
deterration: The uncovering of anything buried or covered with earth; ataking out of the earth or ground. Woodward.
dissectible: Capable of being dissected, or separated by dissection. Paley.
diphthongic: Of the nature of diphthong; diphthongal. H. Sweet.
deedless: Not performing, or not having performed, deeds or exploits;inactive.Deedless in his tongue. Shak.
dogtrick: A gentle trot, like that of a dog.
drawer: An under-garment worn on the lower limbs. Chest of drawers. Seeunder Chest.
desume: To select; to borrow. [Obs.] Sir. M. Hale.
dunlin: A species of sandpiper (Tringa alpina); -- called also churr,dorbie, grass bird, and red-backed sandpiper. It is found both inEurope and America.
determine: To define or limit by adding a differentia.
dracontic: Belonging to that space of time in which the moon performs onerevolution, from ascending node to ascending node. See Dragon's head,under Dragon. [Obs.] "Dracontic month." Crabb.
deepen: To become deeper; as, the water deepens at every cast of thelead; the plot deepens.His blood-red tresses deepening in the sun. Byron.
dietarian: One who lives in accordance with prescribed rules for diet; adieter.
diminishable: Capable of being diminished or lessened.
donna: A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
draw: To have efficiency as an epispastic; to act as a sinapism; --said of a blister, poultice, etc.
dermobranchiate: Having the skin modified to serve as a gill.
deviation: The voluntary and unnecessary departure of a ship from, ordelay in, the regular and usual course of the specific voyageinsured, thus releasing the underwriters from their responsibility.Deviation of a falling body (Physics), that deviation from a strictlyvertical line of descent which occurs in a body falling freely, inconsequence of the rotation of the earth.-- Deviation of the compass, the angle which the needle of a ship'scompass makes with the magnetic meridian by reason of the magnetismof the iron parts of the ship.-- Deviation of the line of the vertical, the difference between theactual direction of a plumb line and the direction it would have ifthe earth were a perfect ellipsoid and homogeneous, -- caused by theattraction of a mountain, or irregularities in the earth's density.
demurity: Demureness; also, one who is demure. Sir T. Browne.
dagoba: A dome-shaped structure built over relics of Buddha or someBuddhist saint. [East Indies]
deep-laid: Laid deeply; formed with cunning and sagacity; as, deep-laidplans.
discountable: Capable of being, or suitable to be, discounted; as, certainforms are necessary to render notes discountable at a bank.
decapod: A crustacean with ten feet or legs, as a crab; one of theDecapoda. Also used adjectively.
distaste: To be distasteful; to taste ill or disagreeable. [Obs.]Dangerous conceits are, in their natures, poisons, Which at the arescarce found to distaste. Shak.
doe: A female deer or antelope; specifically, the female of thefallow deer, of which the male is called a buck. Also applied to thefemale of other animals, as the rabbit. See the Note under Buck.
duodenal: Of or pertaining to the duodenum; as, duodenal digestion.
disenchant: To free from enchantment; to deliver from the power of charmsor spells; to free from fascination or delusion.Haste to thy work; a noble stroke or two Ends all the charms, anddisenchants the grove. Dryden.
direption: The act of plundering, despoiling, or snatching away. [R.]Speed.
derail: To cause to run off from the rails of a railroad, as alocomotive. Lardner.
deambulatory: Going about from place to place; wandering; of or pertaining toa deambulatory. [Obs.] "Deambulatory actors." Bp. Morton.
doghole: A place fit only for dogs; a vile, mean habitation orapartment. Dryden.
diopside: A crystallized variety of pyroxene, of a clear, grayish greencolor; mussite.
depletive: Able or fitted to deplete.-- n.
dwarfish: Like a dwarf; below the common stature or size; very small;petty; as, a dwarfish animal, shrub.-- Dwarf"ish*ly, adv.-- Dwarf"ish*ness, n.
diatonic: Pertaining to the scale of eight tones, the eighth of which isthe octave of the first. Diatonic scale (Mus.), a scale consisting ofeight sounds with seven intervals, of which two are semitones andfive are whole tones; a modern major or minor scale, as distinguishedfrom the chromatic scale.
dual: Expressing, or consisting of, the number two; belonging to two;as, the dual number of nouns, etc. , in Greek.Here you have one half of our dual truth. Tyndall.
diffusible: Capable of passing through animal membranes by osmosis.
ducat: A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries inEurope; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
donary: A thing given to a sacred use. [R.] Burton.
domino: A game played by two or more persons, with twenty-eight piecesof wood, bone, or ivory, of a flat, oblong shape, plain at the back,but on the face divided by a line in the middle, and either leftblank or variously dotted after the manner of dice. The game isplayed by matching the spots or the blank of an unmatched half of adomino already played Hoyle.
driftbolt: A bolt for driving out other bolts.
deuterogamist: One who marries the second time.
dissolvable: Capable of being dissolved, or separated into component parts;capable of being liquefied; soluble.-- Dis*solv"a*ble*ness, n.Though everything which is compacted be in its own naturedissolvable. Cudworth.Such things as are not dissolvable by the moisture of the tongue. SirI. Newton.
duster: A blowing machine for separating the flour from the bran.
dreggy: Containing dregs or lees; muddy; foul; feculent. Boyle.
distracter: One who, or that which, distracts away.
decisory: Able to decide or determine; having a tendency to decide. [R.]
decrial: A crying down; a clamorous censure; condemnation by censure.
dextral: Right, as opposed to sinistral, or left. Dextral shell (Zoöl.),a spiral shell the whorls of which turn from left right, or like thehands of a watch when the apex of the spire is toward the eye of theobserver.
devonian: Of or pertaining to Devon or Devonshire in England; as, theDevonian rocks, period, or system. Devonian age (Geol.), the age nextolder than the Carboniferous and later than the Silurian; -- calledalso the Age of fishes. The various strata of this age compose theDevonian formation or system, and include the old red sandstone ofGreat Britain. They contain, besides plants and numerousinvertebrates, the bony portions of many large and remarkable fishesof extinct groups. See the Diagram under Geology.
deliverance: Any fact or truth which is decisively attested or intuitivelyknown as a psychological or philosophical datum; as, the deliveranceof consciousness.
derogation: An alteration of, or subtraction from, a contract for a sale ofstocks.
dolor: Pain; grief; distress; anguish. [Written also dolour.] [Poetic]Of death and dolor telling sad tidings. Spenser.
debauch: To lead away from purity or excellence; to corrupt in characteror principles; to mar; to vitiate; to pollute; to seduce; as, todebauch one's self by intemperance; to debauch a woman; to debauch anarmy.Learning not debauched by ambition. Burke.A man must have got his conscience thoroughly debauched and hardenedbefore he can arrive to the height of sin. South.Her pride debauched her judgment and her eyes. Cowley.
destituent: Deficient; wanting; as, a destituent condition. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
defrayal: The act of defraying; payment; as, the defrayal of necessarycosts.
disglory: Dishonor. [Obs.]To the disglory of God's name. Northbrooke.
disseminated: Occurring in small portions scattered through some othersubstance.
deca-: A prefix, from Gr. de`ka, signifying ten; specifically (MetricSystem), a prefix signifying the weight or measure that is ten timesthe principal unit.
delaine: A kind of fabric for women's dresses.
downhaul: A rope to haul down, or to assist in hauling down, a sail; as,a staysail downhaul; a trysail downhaul.
deodorize: To deprive of odor, especially of such as results fromimpurities.
divisible: Capable of being divided or separated.Extended substance . . . is divisible into parts. Sir W. Hamilton.Divisible contract (Law), a contract containing agreements one ofwhich can be separated from the other.-- Divisible offense (Law), an offense containing a lesser offensein one of a greater grade, so that on the latter there can be anacquittal, while on the former there can be a conviction.-- Di*vis"i*ble*ness, n.-- Di*vis"i*bly, adv.
dextrally: (adv. Towards the right; as, the hands of a watch rotatedextrally.
domanial: Of or relating to a domain or to domains.
deperdit: That which is lost or destroyed. [R.] Paley.
decade: A group or division of ten; esp., a period of ten years; adecennium; as, a decade of years or days; a decade of soldiers; thesecond decade of Livy. [Written also decad.]During this notable decade of years. Gladstone.
diphthong: To form or pronounce as a diphthong; diphthongize. [R.]
directress: A woman who directs. Bp. Hurd.
doctrinal: A matter of doctrine; also, a system of doctrines. T. Goodwin.Sir T. Elyot.
dissunder: To separate; to sunder; to destroy. [R.] Chapman.
dog-eared: Having the corners of the leaves turned down and soiled bycareless or long-continued usage; -- said of a book.Statute books before unopened, not dog-eared. Ld. Mansfield.
decameron: A celebrated collection of tales, supposed to be related in tendays; -- written in the 14th century, by Boccaccio, an Italian.
disproportionally: In a disproportional manner; unsuitably in form, quantity, orvalue; unequally.
damper: That which damps or checks; as: (a) A valve or movable plate inthe flue or other part of a stove, furnace, etc., used to check orregulate the draught of air. (b) A contrivance, as in a pianoforte,to deaden vibrations; or, as in other pieces of mechanism, to checksome action at a particular time.Nor did Sabrina's presence seem to act as any damper at the modestlittle festivities. W. Black.
denunciator: One who denounces, publishes, or proclaims, especially intendedor coming evil; one who threatens or accuses.
dishonorer: One who dishonors or disgraces; one who treats anotherindignity. Milton.
dialectology: That branch of philology which is devoted to the considerationof dialects. Beck.
double-shade: To double the natural darkness of (a place). Milton.
delighted: Endowed with delight.If virtue no delighted beauty lack. Shak.
disbud: To deprive of buds or shoots, as for training, or economizingthe vital strength of a tree.
dimplement: The state of being dimpled, or marked with gentle depressions.[R.]The ground's most gentle dimplement. Mrs. Browning.
deflower: Same as Deflour.An earthquake . . . deflowering the gardens. W. Montagu.If a man had deflowered a virgin. Milton.
dull-eyed: Having eyes wanting brightness, liveliness, or vivacity. Shak.
dago: A nickname given to a person of Spanish (or, by extension,Portuguese or Italian) descent. [U. S.]
diselenide: A selenide containing two atoms of selenium in each molecule.
dimerous: Composed of, or having, two parts of each kind.
debit: A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; --mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account.
deflagration: The act or process of deflagrating.
drawing: The process of pulling out and elongating the sliver from thecarding machine, by revolving rollers, to prepare it for spinning.
deter: To prevent by fear; hence, to hinder or prevent from action byfear of consequences, or difficulty, risk, etc. Addison.Potent enemies tempt and deter us from our duty. Tillotson.My own face deters me from my glass. Prior.
debtee: One to whom a debt is due; creditor; -- correlative to debtor.Blackstone.
dewclaw: In any animal, esp. of the Herbivora, a rudimentary claw orsmall hoof not reaching the ground.Some cut off the dewclaws [of greyhounds]. J. H. Walsh.
demonomist: One in subjection to a demon, or to demons. [R.] Sir T.Herbert.
doorga: A Hindoo divinity, the consort of Siva, represented with tenarms. [Written also Durga.] Malcom.
democratical: Democratic.The democratical was democratically received. Algernon Sidney.
despotat: The station or government of a despot; also, the domain of adespot. Freeman.
debased: Turned upside down from its proper position; inverted;reversed.
draughtsmanship: The office, art, or work of a draughtsman.
dare: To have adequate or sufficient courage for any purpose; to bebold or venturesome; not to be afraid; to venture.I dare do all that may become a man; Who dares do more is none. Shak.Why then did not the ministers use their new law Bacause they durstnot, because they could not. Macaulay.Who dared to sully her sweet love with suspicion. Thackeray.The tie of party was stronger than the tie of blood, because apartisan was more ready to dare without asking why. Jowett (Thu
driller: One who, or that which, drills.
diarthrosis: A form of articulation which admits of considerable motion; acomplete joint; abarticulation. See Articulation.
dualin: An explosive substance consisting essentially of sawdust orwood pulp, saturated with nitroglycerin and other similar nitrocompounds. It is inferior to dynamite, and is more liable toexplosion.
disentanglement: The act of disentangling or clearing from difficulties. Warton.
draughtboard: A checkered board on which draughts are played. SeeCheckerboard.
delirament: A wandering of the mind; a crazy fancy. [Obs.] Heywood.
disfurnishment: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.Daniel.
dissembling: That dissembles; hypocritical; false.-- Dis*sem"bling*ly, adv.
deposable: Capable of being deposed or deprived of office. Howell.
debateful: Full of contention; contentious; quarrelsome. [Obs.] Spenser.
dishouse: To deprive of house or home. "Dishoused villagers." JamesWhite.
dilucid: Clear; lucid. [Obs.] Bacon.-- Di*lu"cid*ly, adv. [Obs.] -- Di`lu*cid"i*ty, n. [Obs.]
dakota group: A subdivision at the base of the cretaceous formation inWestern North America; -- so named from the region where the stratawere first studied.
dispute: To contend in argument; to argue against something maintained,upheld, or claimed, by another; to discuss; to reason; to debate; toaltercate; to wrangle.Therefore disputed [reasoned, Rev. Ver.] he in synagogue with the Jews. Acts xvii. 17.
day-laborer: One who works by the day; -- usually applied to a farm laborer,or to a workman who does not work at any particular trade. Goldsmith.
denary: Containing ten; tenfold; proceeding by tens; as, the denary, ordecimal, scale.
delthyris: A name formerly given to certain Silurian brachiopod shells ofthe genus Spirifer. Delthyris limestone (Geol.), one of the divisionsof the Upper Silurian rocks in New York.
determination: A flow, rush, or tendency to a particular part; as, adetermination of blood to the head.
dissentious: Marked by dissensions; apt to breed discord; quarrelsome;contentious; factious.-- Dis*sen"tious*ly, adv.
dirt: To make foul of filthy; to dirty. Swift.
dziggetai: The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Thibet (Asinushemionus).
dicyemid: Like or belonging to the Dicyemata.-- n.
doughface: A contemptuous nickname for a timid, yielding politician, orone who is easily molded. [Political cant, U. S.]
dissertation: A formal or elaborate argumentative discourse, oral or written;a disquisition; an essay; a discussion; as, Dissertations on theProphecies.
determinate: To bring to an end; to determine. See Determine. [Obs.]The sly, slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thydear exile. Shak.
dertrotheca: The horny covering of the end of the bill of birds.
doubletree: The bar, or crosspiece, of a carriage, to which the singletreesare attached.
digressive: Departing from the main subject; partaking of the nature ofdigression. Johnson.
derotremata: The tribe of aquatic Amphibia which includes Amphiuma,Menopoma, etc. They have permanent gill openings, but no externalgills; -- called also Cryptobranchiata. [Written also Derotrema.]
determiner: One who, or that which, determines or decides.
doff: To put off dress; to take off the hat.
duykerbok: A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- calledalso impoon, and deloo.
determinable: Capable of being determined, definitely ascertained, decidedupon, or brought to a conclusion.Not wholly determinable from the grammatical use of the words. South.
dizzy: To make dizzy or giddy; to give the vertigo to; to confuse.If the jangling of thy bells had not dizzied thy understanding. SirW. Scott.
desirefulness: The state of being desireful; eagerness to obtain and possess.[R.]The desirefulness of our minds much augmenteth and increaseth ourpleasure. Udall.
detector: One who, or that which, detects; a detecter. Shak.A deathbed's detector of the heart. Young.Bank-note detector, a publication containing a description of genuineand counterfeit bank notes, designed to enable persons todiscriminate between them.-- Detector l. See under Lock.
disliken: To make unlike; to disguise. [Obs.] Shak.
discontented: Dissatisfied; uneasy in mind; malcontent.And every one that was in distress, and every one that was in debt,and every one that was discontented, gathered themselves unto him. 1Sam. xxii. 2.-- Dis`con*tent"ed*ly, adv.-- Dis`con*tent"ed*ness, n.
disquietness: Disturbance of quiet in body or mind; restlessness; uneasiness.Hooker.
dude: A kind of dandy; especially, one characterized by anultrafashionable style of dress and other affectations. [Recent]The social dude who affects English dress and English drawl. TheAmerican.
deference: A yielding of judgment or preference from respect to the wishesor opinion of another; submission in opinion; regard; respect;complaisance.Deference to the authority of thoughtful and sagacious men. Whewell.Deference is the most complicate, the most indirect, and the mostelegant of all compliments. Shenstone.
deprostrate: Fully prostrate; humble; low; rude. [Obs.]How may weak mortal ever hope to file His unsmooth tongue, and hisdeprostrate style. G. Fletcher.
drug: To drudge; to toil laboriously. [Obs.] "To drugge and draw."Chaucer.
deliquescent: Branching so that the stem is lost in branches, as in mostdeciduous trees. Gray.
dolt: A heavy, stupid fellow; a blockhead; a numskull; an ignoramus;a dunce; a dullard.This Puck seems but a dreaming dolt. Drayton.
distributable: Capable of being distributed. Sir W. Jones.
divider: An instrument for dividing lines, describing circles, etc.,compasses. See Compasses.
dogshore: One of several shores used to hold a ship firmly and preventher moving while the blocks are knocked away before launching.
dilettant: Of or pertaining to dilettanteism; amateur; as, dilettantspeculation. Carlyle.
disemploy: To throw out of employment. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
drossy: Of, pertaining to, resembling, dross; full of dross; impure;worthless. " Drossy gold." Dryden. "Drossy rhymes." Donne.-- Dross"i*ness, n.
detractory: Defamatory by denial of desert; derogatory; calumnious. Sir T.Browne.
dungaree: A coarse kind of unbleached cotton stuff. [Written alsodungari.] [India]
dwindlement: The act or process of dwindling; a dwindling. [R.] Mrs.Oliphant.
disnaturalize: To make alien; to deprive of the privileges of birth. Locke.
dislikeful: Full of dislike; disaffected; malign; disagreeable. [Obs.]Spenser.
dryness: The state of being dry. See Dry.
director: A part of a machine or instrument which directs its motion oraction.
dribble: To let fall in drops.Let the cook . . . dribble it all the way upstairs. Swift.
directoire style: A style of dress prevalent at the time of the French Directory,characterized by great extravagance of design and imitating the Greekand Roman costumes.
deadlatch: A kind of latch whose bolt may be so locked by a detent that itcan not be opened from the inside by the handle, or from the outsideby the latch key. Knight.
diplex: Pertaining to the sending of two messages in the same directionat the same time. Diplex and contraplex are the two varieties ofduplex.
dizzard: A blockhead. [Obs.] [Written also dizard, and disard.] --Diz"zard*ly, adv. [Obs.]
decubation: Act of lying down; decumbence. [Obs.] Evelyn.
dropwise: After the manner of a drop; in the form of drops.Trickling dropwise from the cleft. Tennyson.
dwarf: An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of itsspecies or kind; especially, a diminutive human being.
dimethyl: Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consistingof two methyl radicals. See Ethane.
duet: A composition for two performers, whether vocal orinstrumental.
demonry: Demoniacal influence or possession. J. Baillie.
deviatory: Tending to deviate; devious; as, deviatory motion. [R.] Tully.
didactyl: An animal having only two digits.
demand: To call into court; to summon. Burrill.
delitescency: Concealment; seclusion.The mental organization of the novelist must be characterized, tospeak craniologically, by an extraordinary development of the passionfor delitescency. Sir W. Scott.
de-: A prefix from Latin de down, from, away; as in debark, decline,decease, deduct, decamp. In words from the French it is equivalent toLatin dis- apart, away; or sometimes to de. Cf. Dis-. It is negativeand opposite in derange, deform, destroy, etc. It is intensive indeprave, despoil, declare, desolate, etc.
desulphuration: The act or process of depriving of sulphur.
dvergr: A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillfulin working metals.
dermohaemal: Pertaining to, or in relation with, both dermal and hæmalstructures; as, the dermohæmal spines or ventral fin rays of fishes.
dactylioglyphy: The art or process of gem engraving.
diagonial: Diagonal; diametrical; hence; diametrically opposed. [Obs.]Sin can have no tenure by law at all, but is rather an eternaloutlaw, and in hostility with law past all atonement; both diagonalcontraries, as much allowing one another as day and night together inone hemisphere. Milton.
daphnia: A genus of the genus Daphnia.
disponee: The person to whom any property is legally conveyed.
diapason: The octave, or interval which includes all the tones of thediatonic scale.
disseminator: One who, or that which, disseminates, spreads, or propagates;as, disseminators of disease.
dust-point: An old rural game.With any boy at dust-point they shall play. Peacham (1620).
durable: Able to endure or continue in a particular condition; lasting;not perishable or changeable; not wearing out or decaying soon;enduring; as, durable cloth; durable happiness.Riches and honor are with me; yea, durable riches and righteousness.Prov. viii. 18.An interest which from its object and grounds must be so durable. DeQuincey.
dragbar: Same as Drawbar (b). Called also draglink, and drawlink. [U.S.]
dissembler: One who dissembles; one who conceals his opinions ordispositions under a false appearance; a hypocrite.It is the weakest sort of politicians that are the greatestdissemblers. Bacon.Priests, princes, women, no dissemblers here. Pope.
droplet: A little drop; a tear. Shak.
didonia: The curve which on a given surface and with a given perimetercontains the greatest area. Tait.
driftless: Having no drift or direction; without aim; purposeless.
defamatory: Containing defamation; injurious to reputation; calumnious;slanderous; as, defamatory words; defamatory writings.
divorcive: Having power to divorce; tending to divorce. "This divorcivelaw." Milton.
disanchor: To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor. [Obs.]Heywood.
dehisce: To gape; to open by dehiscence.
debark: To go ashore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to put ashore.
dumpish: Dull; stupid; sad; moping; melancholy. " A . . . dumpish andsour life." Lord Herbert.-- Dump"ish*ly, adv.-- Dump"ish*ness, n.
dissimilitude: A comparison by contrast; a dissimile.
diapase: Same as Diapason. [Obs.]A tuneful diapase of pleasures. Spenser.
