dike: A wall-like mass of mineral matter, usually an intrusion ofigneous rocks, filling up rents or fissures in the original strata.
desperado: A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions,and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.
disgage: To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage. [Obs.] Holland.
discreditable: Not creditable; injurious to reputation; disgraceful;disreputable.-- Dis*cred"it*a*bly, adv.
discursion: The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought tothought. Coleridge.
duchesse lace: A beautiful variety of Brussels pillow lace made originally inBelgium and resembling Honiton guipure. It is worked with fine threadin large sprays, usually of the primrose pattern, with much raisedwork.
debullition: A bubbling or boiling over. [Obs.] Bailey.
disconcert: Want of concert; disagreement. Sir W. Temple.
dopplerite: A brownish black native hydrocarbon occurring in elastic orjellylike masses.
disappropriate: Severed from the appropriation or possession of a spiritualcorporation.The appropriation may be severed, and the church becomedisappropriate, two ways. Blackstone.
diaphanous: Allowing light to pass through, as porcelain; translucent ortransparent; pellucid; clear.Another cloud in the region of them, light enough to be fantastic anddiaphanous. Landor.
debituminization: The act of depriving of bitumen.
diseasefulness: The quality of being diseaseful; trouble; trial. [R.] Sir P.Sidney.
dimple: To form dimples; to sink into depressions or littleinequalities.And smiling eddies dimpled on the main. Dryden.
dusken: To make dusk or obscure. [R.]Not utterly defaced, but only duskened. Nicolls.
detergency: A cleansing quality or power. De Foe.
decane: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H22, of the paraffin series, includingseveral isomeric modifications.
drabble: To draggle; to wet and befoul by draggling; as, to drabble agown or cloak. Halliwell.
dragoman: An interpreter; -- so called in the Levant and other parts ofthe East.
discoursive: The state or quality of being discoursive or able to reason.[R.] Feltham.
derivement: That which is derived; deduction; inference. [Obs.]I offer these derivements from these subjects. W. Montagu.
dinosauria: An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size(whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlikecharacters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Somewalked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large "birdtracks," so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed andquadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration ofDinosaur in Appendix.
dowel: To fasten together by dowels; to furnish with dowels; as, acooper dowels pieces for the head of a cask.
damourite: A kind of Muscovite, or potash mica, containing water.
discide: To divide; to cleave in two. [Obs.] Spenser.
deaconship: The office or ministry of a deacon or deaconess.
dicer: A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.As false as dicers' oaths. Shak.
dampish: Moderately damp or moist.-- Damp"ish*ly, adv.-- Damp"ish*ness, n.
duress: The state of compulsion or necessity in which a person isinfluenced, whether by the unlawful restrain of his liberty or byactual or threatened physical violence, to incur a civil liability orto commit an offense.
demonstrably: In a demonstrable manner; incontrovertibly; clearly.Cases that demonstrably concerned the public cause. Clarendon.
dialogically: In the manner or nature of a dialogue. Goldsmith.
disedge: To deprive of an edge; to blunt; to dull.Served a little to disedge The sharpness of that pain about herheart. Tennyson.
doughty: Able; strong; valiant; redoubtable; as, a doughty hero.Sir Thopas wex [grew] a doughty swain. Chaucer.Doughty families, hugging old musty quarrels to their hearts, buffeteach other from generation to generation. Motley.
debellation: The act of conquering or subduing. [Obs.]
diradiation: The emission and diffusion of rays of light.
declaratory: Making declaration, explanation, or exhibition; making clear ormanifest; affirmative; expressive; as, a clause declaratory of thewill of the legislature. Declaratory act (Law), an act or statutewhich sets forth more clearly, and declares what is, the existinglaw.
dahlia: A genus of plants native to Mexico and Central America, of theorder Compositæ; also, any plant or flower of the genus. The numerousvarieties of cultivated dahlias bear conspicuous flowers which differin color.
diarchy: A form of government in which the supreme power is vested intwo persons.
divorcer: The person or cause that produces or effects a divorce.Drummond.
duodenary: Containing twelve; twelvefold; increasing by twelves;duodecimal.
dimidiate: To represent the half of; to halve.
decorate: To deck with that which is becoming, ornamental, or honorary;to adorn; to beautify; to embellish; as, to decorate the person; todecorate an edifice; to decorate a lawn with flowers; to decorate themind with moral beauties; to decorate a hero with honors.Her fat neck was ornamented with jewels, rich bracelets decorated herarms. Thackeray.
deathbird: Tengmalm's or Richardson's owl (Nyctale Tengmalmi); -- socalled from a superstition of the North American Indians that itsnote presages death.
damp: A gaseous prodact, formed in coal mines, old wells, pints, etc.Choke damp, a damp consisting principally of carboniCarbonic acid,under Carbonic.-- Damp sheet, a curtain in a mine gallery to direct air currentsand prevent accumulation of gas.-- Fire damp, a damp consisting chiefly of light carburetedhydrogen; -- so called from its tendence to explode when mixed withatmospheric air and brought into contact with flame.
disbase: To debase or degrade. [Obs.]Nor you nor your house were so much as spoken of before I disbasedmyself. B. Jonson.
denize: To make a denizen; to confer the rights of citizenship upon; tonaturalize. [Obs.]There was a private act made for denizing the children of RichardHillStrype.
deipnosophist: One of an ancient sect of philosophers, who cultivated learnedconversation at meals.
doorpost: The jamb or sidepiece of a doorway.
dandyism: The manners and dress of a dandy; foppishness. Byron.
dishaunt: To leave; to quit; to cease to haunt. Halliwell.
disloyalty: Want of loyalty; lack of fidelity; violation of allegiance.
daun: A variant of Dan, a title of honor. [Obs.] Chaucer.
default: A neglect of, or failure to take, some step necessary to securethe benefit of law, as a failure to appear in court at a dayassigned, especially of the defendant in a suit when called to makeanswer; also of jurors, witnesses, etc. In default of, in case offailure or lack of.Cooks could make artificial birds and fishes in default of the realones. Arbuthnot.-- To suffer a default (Law), to permit an action to be calledwithout appearing to answer.
decay: To pass gradually from a sound, prosperous, or perfect state,to one of imperfection, adversity, or dissolution; to waste away; todecline; to fail; to become weak, corrupt, or disintegrated; to rot;to perish; as, a tree decays; fortunes decay; hopes decay.Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, Where wealthaccumulates and men decay. Goldsmith.
dispart: To part asunder; to divide; to separate; to sever; to rend; torive or split; as, disparted air; disparted towers. [Archaic]Them in twelve troops their captain did dispart. Spenser.The world will be whole, and refuses to be disparted. Emerson.
decarburize: To deprive of carbon; to remove the carbon from.
disenthrallment: Liberation from bondage; emancipation; disinthrallment.[Written also disenthralment.]
displenish: To deprive or strip, as a house of furniture, or a barn ofstock. [Scot.]
deletion: Act of deleting, blotting out, or erasing; destruction. [Obs.]Jer. Taylor.A total deletion of every person of the opposing party. Sir M. Hale.
desireful: Filled with desire; eager. [R.]The desireful troops. Godfrey (1594).
dorhawk: The European goatsucker; -- so called because it eats the dorbeetle. See Goatsucker. [Written also dorrhawk.] Booth.
dodecagon: A figure or polygon bounded by twelve sides and containingtwelve angles.
doubtance: State of being in doubt; uncertainty; doubt. [Obs.] Chaucer.
dastard: One who meanly shrinks from danger; an arrant coward; apoltroon.You are all recreants and dashtards, and delight to live in slaveryto the nobility. Shak.
den: A narrow glen; a ravine; a dell. [Old Eng. & Scotch] Shak.
deathblow: A mortal or crushing blow; a stroke or event which kills ordestroys.The deathblow of my hope. Byron.
depuration: The act or process of depurating or freeing from foreign orimpure matter, as a liquid or wound.
diptote: A noun which has only two cases. Andrews.
dishorn: To deprive of horns; as, to dishorn cattle. "Dishorn thespirit." Shak.
dataria: Formerly, a part of the Roman chancery; now, a separate officefrom which are sent graces or favors, cognizable in foro externo,such as appointments to benefices. The name is derived from the worddatum, given or dated (with the indications of the time and place ofgranting the gift or favor).
drogher: A small craft used in the West India Islands to take offsugars, rum, etc., to the merchantmen; also, a vessel fortransporting lumber, cotton, etc., coastwise; as, a lumber drogher.[Written also droger.] Ham. Nar. Encyc.
dragoon: Formerly, a soldier who was taught and armed to serve either onhorseback or on foot; now, a mounted soldier; a cavalry man.
dibutyl: A liquid hydrocarbon, C8H18, of the marsh-gas series, being oneof several octanes, and consisting of two butyl radicals. Cf. Octane.
diphthongal: Relating or belonging to a diphthong; having the nature of adiphthong.-- Diph*thon"gal*ly, adv.
determinant: Serving to determine or limit; determinative.
deletory: That which blots out. [Obs.] "A deletory of sin." Jer. Taylor.
differentiate: To obtain the differential, or differential coefficient, of;as, to differentiate an algebraic expression, or an equation.
discounter: One who discounts; a discount broker. Burke.
decidement: Means of forming a decision. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
delineatory: That delineates; descriptive; drawing the outline; delineating.
dispensatory: Granting, or authorized to grant, dispensations. "Dispensatorypower." Bp. Rainbow.
decarbonization: The action or process of depriving a substance of carbon.
dartrous: Relating to, or partaking of the nature of, the disease calledtetter; herpetic. Dartroud diathesis, A morbid condition of thesystem predisposing to the development of certain skin deseases, suchas eczema, psoriasis, and pityriasis. Also called rheumic diathesis,and hipretism. Piffard.
dissatisfaction: The state of being dissatisfied, unsatisfied, or discontented;uneasiness proceeding from the want of gratification, or fromdisappointed wishes and expectations.The ambitious man has little happiness, but is subject to muchuneasiness and dissatisfaction. Addison.
deltidium: The triangular space under the beak of many brachiopod shells.
diogenes: A Greek Cynic philosopher (412-323 B. C.) who lived much inAthens and was distinguished for contempt of the common aims andconditions of life, and for sharp, caustic sayings. Diogenes' crab(Zoöl.), a species of terrestrial hermit crabs (Cenobita Diogenes),abundant in the West Indies and often destructive to crops.-- Diogenes' tub, the tub which the philosopher Diogenes is said tohave carried about with him as his house, in which he lived.
divisor: The number by which the dividend is divided. Common divisor.(Math.) See under Common, a.
doorplane: A plane on a door, giving the name, and sometimes theemployment, of the occupant.
daybook: A journal of accounts; a primary record book in which arerecorded the debts and credits, or accounts of the day, in theirorder, and from which they are transferred to the journal.
decrepitate: To roast or calcine so as to cause a crackling noise; as, todecrepitate salt.
doubtfully: In a doubtful manner.Nor did the goddess doubtfully declare. Dryden.
dionysiac: Of or pertaining to Dionysus or to the Dionysia; Bacchic; as, aDionysiac festival; the Dionysiac theater at Athens.
din: Loud, confused, harsh noise; a loud, continuous, rattling orclanging sound; clamor; roar.Think you a little din can daunt mine ears Shak.He knew the battle's din afar. Sir W. Scott.The dust and din and steam of town. Tennyson.
dedentition: The shedding of teeth. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
dancing: from Dance. Dancing girl, one of the women in the East Indieswhose profession is to dance in the temples, or for the amusement ofspectators. There are various classes of dancing girls.-- Dancing master, a teacher of dancing.-- Dancing school, a school or place where dancing is taught.
desistance: The act or state of desisting; cessation. [R.] Boyle.If fatigue of body or brain were in every case followed by desistance. . . then would the system be but seldom out of working order. H.Spencer.
degloried: Deprived of glory; dishonored. [Obs.] "With thorns degloried."G. Fletcher.
divinize: To invest with a divine character; to deify. [R.] M. Arnold.Man had divinized all those objects of awe. Milman.
diocesener: One who belongs to a diocese. [Obs.] Bacon.
digitigrade: Walking on the toes; -- distinguished from plantigrade.
donjon: The chief tower, also called the keep; a massive tower inancient castles, forming the strongest part of the fortifications.See Illust. of Castle.
dope-book: A chart of previous performances, etc., of race horses. [Race-track Slang]
discourageable: Capable of being discouraged; easily disheartened. Bp. Hall.
disembarrassment: Freedom or relief from impediment or perplexity.
dankish: Somewhat dank.-- Dank"ish*ness, n.In a dark and dankish vault at home. Shak.
decompose: To separate the constituent parts of; to resolve into originalelements; to set free from previously existing forms of chemicalcombination; to bring to dissolution; to rot or decay.
dido: A shrewd trick; an antic; a caper. To cut a dido, to play atrick; to cut a caper; -- perhaps so called from the trick of Dido,who having bought so much land as a hide would cover, is said to havecut it into thin strips long enough to inclose a spot for a citadel.
decembrist: One of those who conspired for constitutional governmentagainst the Emperor Nicholas on his accession to the throne at thedeath of Alexander I., in December, 1825; -- called also Dekabrist.
decandria: A Linnæan class of plants characterized by having ten stamens.
desinential: Terminal.Furthermore, b, as a desinential element, has a dynamic function.Fitzed. Hall.
dodecasyllable: A word consisting of twelve syllables.
devastate: To lay waste; to ravage; to desolate.Whole countries . . . were devastated. Macaulay.
deordination: Disorder; dissoluteness. [Obs.]Excess of rideordination. Jer. Taylor.
derrick: A mast, spar, or tall frame, supported at the top by stays orguys, with suitable tackle for hoisting heavy weights, as stones inbuilding. Derrick crane, a combination of the derrick and the crane,having facility for hoisting and also for swinging the loadhorizontally.
deportment: Manner of deporting or demeaning one's self; manner of acting;conduct; carrige; especially, manner of acting with respect to thecourtesies and duties of life; behavior; demeanor; bearing.The gravity of his deportment carried him safe through manydifficulties. Swift.
deturpate: To defile; to disfigure. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
diluviate: To run as a flood. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.
dueness: Quality of being due; debt; what is due or becoming. T.Goodwin.
desinent: Ending; forming an end; lowermost. [Obs.] "Their desinentparts, fish." B. Jonson.
dugong: An aquatic herbivorous mammal (Halicore dugong), of the orderSirenia, allied to the manatee, but with a bilobed tail. It inhabitsthe Red Sea, Indian Ocean, East Indies, and Australia. [Written alsoduyong.]
dispatchful: Bent on haste; intent on speedy execution of business or anytask; indicating haste; quick; as, dispatchful looks. Milton.
depredator: One who plunders or pillages; a spoiler; a robber.
dinetical: Revolving on an axis. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
deform: Deformed; misshapen; shapeless; horrid. [Obs.]Sight so deform what heart of rock could long Dry-eyed behold Milton.
dismarry: To free from the bonds of marriage; to divorce. [Obs.] Ld.Berners.
dispassion: Freedom from passion; an undisturbed state; apathy. Sir W.Temple.
disauthorize: To deprive of credit or authority; to discredit. [R.] W.Wotton.
devoutness: Quality or state of being devout.
duan: A division of a poem corresponding to a canto; a poem or song.[R.]
doorsill: The sill or threshold of a door.
diplanar: Of or pertaining to two planes.
drill press: A machine for drilling holes in metal, the drill being pressedto the metal by the action of a screw.
dauber: A pad or ball of rags, covered over with canvas, for inkingplates; a dabber.
diverter: One who, or that which, diverts, turns off, or pleases.
deep-fet: Deeply fetched or drawn. [Obs.] "Deep-fet groans." Shak.
disfeature: To deprive of features; to mar the features of. [R.]
drooper: One who, or that which, droops.
dhole: A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountainsof India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger andother wild animals in packs.
dazzlement: Dazzling flash, glare, or burst of light. Donne.
danish: Belonging to the Danes, or to their language or country.-- n.
daybreak: The time of the first appearance of light in the morning.
demonic: Of or pertaining to a demon or to demons; demoniac. "Demonicambushes." Lowell.
dealfish: A long, thin fish of the arctic seas (Trachypterus arcticus).
douar: A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.
date: The fruit of the date palm; also, the date palm itself.
dowcet: One of the testicles of a hart or stag. [Spelt also doucet.] B.Jonson.
demesnial: Of or pertaining to a demesne; of the nature of a demesne.
dreibund: A triple alliance; specif., the alliance of Germany, Austria,and Italy, formed in 1882.
detonize: To explode, or cause to explode; to burn with an explosion; todetonate.
defalk: To lop off; to bate. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
dipnoi: A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodusand Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to theAmphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils openinside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.
daughterly: Becoming a daughter; filial.Sir Thomas liked her natural and dear daughterly affection towardshim. Cavendish.
devilry: A dragon fly. See Darning needle, under Darn, v. t.
desiderate: To desire; to feel the want of; to lack; to miss; to want.Pray have the goodness to point out one word missing that ought tohave been there -- please to insert a desiderated stanza. You cannot. Prof. Wilson.Men were beginning . . . to desiderate for them an actual abode offire. A. W. Ward.
difformity: Irregularity of form; diversity of form; want of uniformity.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
depurgatory: Serving to purge; tending to cleanse or purify. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
ductor: A contrivance for removing superfluous ink or coloring matterfrom a roller. See Doctor, 4. Knight. Ductor roller (Printing), theroller which conveys or supplies ink to another roller. Knight.
dormitive: Causing sleep; as, the dormitive properties of opium. Clarke.-- n. (Med.)
desidiousness: The state or quality of being desidiose, or indolent. [Obs.] N.Bacon.
dapper: Little and active; spruce; trim; smart; neat in dress orappearance; lively.He wondered how so many provinces could be held in subjection by sucha dapper little man. Milton.The dapper ditties that I wont devise. Spenser.Sharp-nosed, dapper steam yachts. Julian Hawthorne.
disprofess: To renounce the profession or pursuit of.His arms, which he had vowed to disprofess. Spenser.
dyscrasia: An ill habit or state of the constitution; -- formerly regardedas dependent on a morbid condition of the blood and humors.
disclamation: A disavowing or disowning. Bp. Hall.
dubitable: Liable to be doubted; uncertain. [R.] Dr. H. More.-- Du"bi*ta*bly, adv. [R.]
dictaphone: A form of phonographic recorder and reproducer adapted for usein dictation, as in business.
deceiver: One who deceives; one who leads into error; a cheat; animpostor.The deceived and the deceiver are his. Job xii. 16.
dependable: Worthy of being depended on; trustworthy. "Dependablefriendships." Pope.
deep-waisted: Having a deep waist, as when, in a ship, the poop andforecastle are much elevated above the deck.
displeasant: Unpleasing; offensive; unpleasant. [Obs.] Speed.-- Dis*pleas"ant*ly, adv. [Obs.] Strype.-- Dis*pleas"ant*ness, n. [Obs.]
dace: A small European cyprinoid fish (Squalius leuciscus orLeuciscus vulgaris); -- called also dare.
debater: One who debates; one given to argument; a disputant; acontrovertist.Debate where leisure serves with dull debaters. Shak.
dispoline: One of several isomeric organic bases of the quinoline seriesof alkaloids.
disquietous: Causing uneasiness. [R.]So distasteful and disquietous to a number of men. Milton.
dissociability: Want of sociability; unsociableness. Bp. Warburton.
duplicative: Having the quality of subdividing into two by natural growth."Duplicative subdivision." Carpenter.
doggerman: A sailor belonging to a dogger.
distributer: One who, or that which, distributes or deals out anything; adispenser. Addison.
deglutitory: Serving for, or aiding in, deglutition.
dominion: A supposed high order of angels; dominations. See Domination,3. Milton.By him were all things created . . . whether they be thrones, ordominions, or principalities, or powers. Col. i. 16.
dishabille: An undress; a loose, negligent dress; deshabille.They breakfast in dishabille. Smollett.
day-net: A net for catching small birds.
digger: One who, or that which, digs. Digger wasp (Zoöl.), any one ofthe fossorial Hymenoptera.
disdeign: To disdain. [Obs.]Guyon much disdeigned so loathly sight. Spenser.
dirige: A service for the dead, in the Roman Catholic Church, being thefirst antiphon of Matins for the dead, of which Dirige is the firstword; a dirge.Evensongs and placebo and dirige. Wyclif.Resort, I pray you, unto my sepulture To sing my dirige with greatdevotion. Lamentation of Mary Magdalene.
despiteful: Full of despite; expressing malice or contemptuous hate;malicious.-- De*spite"ful*ly, adv.-- De*spite"ful*ness, n.Haters of God, despiteful, proud, boasters. Rom. i. 30.Pray for them which despitefully use you. Matt. v. 44.Let us examine him with despitefulness and fortune. Book of Wisdomii. 19.
dentalium: A genus of marine mollusks belonging to the Scaphopoda, havinga tubular conical shell.
deferrer: One who defers or puts off.
determent: The act of deterring; also, that which deters. Boyle.
dialist: A maker of dials; one skilled in dialing.
deuce: Two; a card or a die with two spots; as, the deuce of hearts.
depressor: A muscle that depresses or tends to draw down a part. Depressornerve (Physiol.), a nerve which lowers the activity of an organ; as,the depressor nerve of the heart.
dispensation: a system of principles, promises, and rules ordained andadministered; scheme; economy; as, the Patriarchal, Mosaic, andChristian dispensations.Neither are God's methods or intentions different in hisdispensations to each private man. Rogers.
depiction: A painting or depicting; a representation.
dissilient: Starting asunder; bursting and opening with an elastic force;dehiscing explosively; as, a dissilient pericarp.
drown: To be suffocated in water or other fluid; to perish in water.Methought, what pain it was to drown. Shak.
desegmentation: The loss or obliteration of division into segments; as, adesegmentation of the body.
definitude: Definiteness. [R.]Definitude . . . is a knowledge of minute differences. Sir W.Hamilton.
digitorium: A small dumb keyboard used by pianists for exercising thefingers; -- called also dumb piano.
deviltry: Diabolical conduct; malignant mischief; devilry. C. Reade.
downiness: The quality or state of being downy.
dislimb: To tear limb from limb; to dismember. [Obs.] Bailey.
diacid: Divalent; -- said of a base or radical as capable of saturatingtwo acid monad radicals or a dibasic acid. Cf. Dibasic, a., andBiacid.
disallowance: The act of disallowing; refusal to admit or permit; rejection.
debasement: The act of debasing or the state of being debased. Milton.
demigorge: Half the gorge, or entrance into a bastion, taken from theangle of the flank to the center of the bastion.
disappearance: The act of disappearing; cessation of appearance; removal fromsight; vanishing. Addison.
double-tonguing: A peculiar action of the tongue by flute players inarticulating staccato notes; also, the rapid repetition of notes incornet playing.
draughts: A mild vesicatory. See Draught, n., 3 (c).
disjoint: Disjointed; unconnected; -- opposed to conjoint. Milton.
decolorize: To deprive of color; to whiten. Turner.-- De*col`or*i*za"tion, n.
distasture: Something which excites distaste or disgust. [Obs.] Speed.
diastatic: Relating to diastase; having the properties of diastase;effecting the conversion of starch into sugar.The influence of acids and alkalies on the diastatic action ofsaliva. Lauder Brunton.
doughy: Like dough; soft and heavy; pasty; crude; flabby and pale; as,a doughy complexion.
digenous: Sexually reproductive. Digenous reproduction. (Biol.) Same asDigenesis.
decastere: A measure of capacity, equal to ten steres, or ten cubicmeters.
disquietal: The act of disquieting; a state of disquiet. [Obs.][It] roars and strives 'gainst its disquietal. Dr. H. More.
determinism: The doctrine that the will is not free, but is inevitably andinvincibly determined by motives.Its superior suitability to produce courage, as contrasted withscientific physical determinism, is obvious. F. P. Cobbe.
decide: To determine; to form a definite opinion; to come to aconclusion; to give decision; as, the court decided in favor of thedefendant.Who shall decide, when doctors disagree Pope.
despise: To look down upon with disfavor or contempt; to contemn; toscorn; to disdain; to have a low opinion or contemptuous dislike of.Fools despise wisdom and instruction. Prov. i. 7.Men naturally despise those who court them, but respect those who donot give way to them. Jowett (Thucyd. ).
discontentive: Relating or tending to discontent. [R.] "Pride is everdiscontentive." Feltham.
diatribist: One who makes a diatribe or diatribes.
discipleship: The state of being a disciple or follower in doctrines andprecepts. Jer. Taylor.
drawbore: A hole bored through a tenon nearer to the shoulder than theholes through the cheeks are to the edge or abutment against whichthe shoulder is to rest, so that a pin or bolt, when driven into it,will draw these parts together. Weale.
desecrator: One who desecrates. "Desecrators of the church." Morley.
divedapper: A water fowl; the didapper. See Dabchick.
decimalize: To reduce to a decimal system; as, to decimalize the currency.-- Dec`i*mal*i*za"tion, n.
diclinous: Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers. Gray.
diaphragm: The muscular and tendinous partition separating the cavity ofthe chest from that of the abdomen; the midriff.
doing: Anything done; a deed; an action good or bad; hence, in theplural, conduct; behavior. See Do.To render an account of his doings. Barrow.
disfurniture: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.[Obs.]
dammara: A large tree of the order Coniferæ, indigenous to the EastIndies and Australasia; -- called also Agathis. There are severalspecies.
dentist: One whose business it is to clean, extract, or repair naturalteeth, and to make and insert artificial ones; a dental surgeon.
disdained: Disdainful. [Obs.]Revenge the jeering and disdained contempt Of this proud king. Shak.
displantation: The act of displanting; removal; displacement. Sir W. Raleigh.
despiteous: Feeling or showing despite; malicious; angry to excess; cruel;contemptuous. [Obs.] "Despiteous reproaches." Holland.
despitous: Despiteous; very angry; cruel. [Obs.]He was to sinful man not despitous. Chaucer.- De*spit"ous*ly, adv. [Obs.]
disaccommodate: To put to inconvenience; to incommode. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
disherit: To disinherit; to cut off, or detain, from the possession orenjoyment of an inheritance. [Obs.] Spenser.
dew-point: The temperature at which dew begins to form. It varies with thehumidity and temperature of the atmosphere.
dotard: One whose mind is impaired by age; one in second childhood.The sickly dotard wants a wife. Prior.
dyne: The unit of force, in the C. G. S. (Centimeter Gram Second)system of physical units; that is, the force which, acting on a gramfor a second, generates a velocity of a centimeter per second.
damnify: To cause loss or damage to; to injure; to imparir. [R.]This work will ask as many more officials to make expurgations andexpunctions, that the commonwealth of learning be not damnified.Milton.
dishonest: To disgrace; to dishonor; as, to dishonest a maid. [Obs.]I will no longer dishonest my house. Chapman.
dreamless: Free from, or without, dreams. Camden.-- Dream"less*ly, adv.
despection: A looking down; a despising. [R.] W. Montagu.
diligence: Process by which persons, lands, or effects are seized fordebt; process for enforcing the attendance of witnesses or theproduction of writings. To do one's diligence, give diligence, usediligence, to exert one's self; to make interested and earnestendeavor.And each of them doth all his diligence To do unto the festéreverence. Chaucer.
disprivilege: To deprive of a privilege or privileges. [R.]
deporture: Deportment. [Obs.]Stately port and majestical deporture. Speed.
deadwood: A mass of timbers built into the bow and stern of a vessel togive solidity.
disimprove: To make worse; -- the opposite of improve. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
drent: Drenched; drowned. [Obs.] "Condemned to be drent." Spenser.
degenerous: Degenerate; base. [Obs.] "Degenerous passions." Dryden."Degenerous practices." South.
depulsion: A driving or thrusting away. [R.] Speed.
deep-sea: Of or pertaining to the deeper parts of the sea; as, a deep-sealine (i. e., a line to take soundings at a great depth); deep-sealead; deep-sea soundings, explorations, etc.
disembark: To remove from on board a vessel; to put on shore; to land; todebark; as, the general disembarked the troops.
defamer: One who defames; a slanderer; a detractor; a calumniator.
disenchanter: One who, or that which, disenchants.
dijudication: The act of dijudicating; judgment. [R.] Cockeram.
disquantity: To diminish the quantity of; to lessen. [Obs.] Shak.
delectus: A name given to an elementary book for learners of Latin orGreek. G. Eliot.
dimission: Leave to depart; a dismissing. [Obs.] Barrow.
dissert: To discourse or dispute; to discuss. [R.]We have disserted upon it a little longer than was necessary.Jeffrey.
deuterogenic: Of secondary origin; -- said of certain rocks whose materialhas been derived from older rocks.
distemper: To mix (colors) in the way of distemper; as, to distempercolors with size. [R.]
deniable: Capable of being, or liable to be, denied.
depilation: Act of pulling out or removing the hair; unhairing. Dryden.
desophisticate: To clear from sophism or error. [R.] Hare.
directorate: The office of director; also, a body of directors takenjointly.
deerlet: A chevrotain. See Kanchil, and Napu.
decertation: Contest for mastery; contention; strife. [R.] Arnway.
displacency: Want of complacency or gratification; envious displeasure;dislike. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
discurrent: Not current or free to circulate; not in use. [Obs.] Sir E.Sandys.
desmoid: Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament;ligamentous.
diallage: A figure by which arguments are placed in various points ofview, and then turned to one point. Smart.
deoxidize: To deprive of oxygen; to reduce from the state of an oxide.
depressomotor: Depressing or diminishing the capacity for movement, asdepressomotor nerves, which lower or inhibit muscular activity.-- n.
darkle: To grow dark; to show indistinctly. Thackeray.
deutzia: A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.
dart: A fish; the dace. See Dace. Dart sac (Zoöl.), a sac connectedwith the reproductive organs of land snails, which contains a dart,or arrowlike structure.
drop: Any medicine the dose of which is measured by drops; as,lavender drops.
delete: To blot out; to erase; to expunge; to dele; to omit.I have, therefore, . . . inserted eleven stanzas which do not appearin Sir Walter Scott's version, and have deleted eight. Aytoun.
dulcified: Sweetened; mollified. Dulcified spirit or spirits, a compoundof alcohol with mineral acids; as, dulcified spirits of niter.
demurrer: A stop or pause by a party to an action, for the judgment ofthe court on the question, whether, assuming the truth of the matteralleged by the opposite party, it is sufficient in law to sustain theaction or defense, and hence whether the party resting is bound toanswer or proceed further. Demurrer to evidence, an exception takenby a party to the evidence offered by the opposite party, and anobjecting to proceed further, on the allegation that such evidence isnot sufficient in law to maintain the issue, and a reference to thecourt to determine the point. Bouvier.
devolvement: The act or process of devolving;; devolution.
diabetes: A disease which is attended with a persistent, excessivedischarge of urine. Most frequently the urine is not only increasedin quantity, but contains saccharine matter, in which case thedisease is generally fatal. Diabetes mellitus Etym: [NL., sweetdiabetes], that form of diabetes in which the urine containssaccharine matter.-- Diabetes insipidus Etym: [NL., lit., diabetes], the form ofdiabetes in which the urine contains no abnormal constituent.
disglorify: To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity. [R.]Disglorified, blasphemed, and had in scorn. Milton.
discernibly: In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly. Hammond.
dropping: That which falls in drops; the excrement or dung of animals.Dropping bottle, an instrument used to supply small quantities of afluid to a test tube or other vessel.-- Dropping fire, a continued irregular discharge of firearms.-- Dropping tube, a tube for ejecting any liquid in drops.
dorsoventral: From the dorsal to the ventral side of an animal; as, thedorsoventral axis.
drumming: The act of beating upon, or as if upon, a drum; also, the noisewhich the male of the ruffed grouse makes in spring, by beating hiswings upon his sides.
disbeliever: One who disbelieves, or refuses belief; an unbeliever.Specifically, one who does not believe the Christian religion. I.Watts.
